questions.text: All of the following are risk factors for perforation of appendix except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Retrocaecal appendix

 

  • While the retrocecal position is one of the most common anatomical locations for the appendix, it is not inherently associated with an increased risk of perforation. 
  • Perforation depends on factors like obstruction, delayed diagnosis, or other underlying conditions, rather than the anatomical position itself.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fecolith obstruction: Fecolith obstruction is one of the most common causes of acute appendicitis and contributes to increased intraluminal pressure, ischemia, and subsequent perforation.

 

Option C. Immunosuppression: Immunosuppressed patients have a higher risk of delayed diagnosis and perforation due to atypical presentations and impaired immune responses to inflammation.

 

Option D. Very old patient: Extremes of age, including elderly patients, are at higher risk for perforation due to delayed diagnosis, atypical presentations, and coexisting medical conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The retrocecal position of the appendix is not a risk factor for perforation. 
  • Perforation is influenced by factors such as fecolith obstruction, immunosuppression, extremes of age, previous abdominal surgery, pelvic positioning, and comorbidities like diabetes mellitus.

questions.text: A 3-day-old male neonate is brought to the neonatal ICU following a surgical procedure for congenital diaphragmatic hernia repair. While recovering in the postoperative ward, the neonate develops shallow breathing, hypotonia, and pinpoint pupils. The mother had an uncomplicated pregnancy and denied drug use. Which of the following medications is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Opioid

 

  • Neonatal respiratory depression with pinpoint pupils and hypotonia strongly suggests opioid toxicity.
  • Opioids are commonly used in neonatal surgery for analgesia. 
  • Neonates are particularly sensitive to opioids due to their immature hepatic metabolism (reduced glucuronidation in the liver) and underdeveloped respiratory drive, increasing their risk for respiratory depression. 
  • This condition is typically managed with opioid discontinuation or administration of naloxone, an opioid antagonist.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Propofol: Propofol can cause respiratory depression, but it is less commonly used in neonates due to the risk of propofol infusion syndrome and limited safety data. Its effects do not cause pinpoint pupils.

 

Option C. Furosemide: Furosemide is a loop diuretic that does not cause respiratory depression. It is more commonly associated with electrolyte disturbances.

 

Option D. Heparin: Heparin is an anticoagulant with no direct impact on respiratory drive.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Opioids used for analgesia in neonates can cause respiratory depression due to their immaturity of hepatic and respiratory systems.
  • Pinpoint pupils and shallow breathing are hallmarks of opioid toxicity in neonates.

choices.text: Supervising Indoor Residual Spray (IRS) spraying operations
Managing case-based surveillance at the community level
Coordinating with the state government for procurement of IRS materials
Overseeing malaria inspectors and assistant malaria officers

questions.text: A district health officer is auditing malaria control activities under the NVBDCP. Which of the following tasks is not a responsibility of the District Malaria Officer?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Managing case-based surveillance at the community level

 

  • Case-based surveillance is carried out by Multi-purpose Workers (MPWs) and ASHAs at the community level, not by the District Malaria Officer. 
  • The District Malaria Officer is responsible for supervising IRS operations, coordinating with the state government, and managing staff involved in malaria control activities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Supervising IRS spraying operations: This is a primary responsibility of the District Malaria Officer.

 

Option C. Coordinating with the state government for IRS materials: The District Malaria Officer works with the state government for logistical support.

 

Option D. Overseeing malaria inspectors and assistant malaria officers: This falls under the District Malaria Officer’s supervision duties.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The District Malaria Officer oversees operational and logistical aspects of malaria control but does not directly manage community-level surveillance, which is the responsibility of MPWs and ASHAs.

questions.text: Which of the following tests confirms the identification of Micrococcus species and differentiates it from fermentative gram-positive cocci?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hugh-Leifson oxidation-fermentation test

 

  • Micrococci are oxidative in the Hugh-Leifson oxidation-fermentation test, whereas fermentative gram-positive cocci such as staphylococci show a fermentative pattern.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Catalase test: The catalase test is positive for both Micrococcus and Staphylococcus aureus.

 

Option B. Coagulase test:  The coagulase test differentiates S. aureus from other staphylococci but is not relevant for Micrococcus.

 

Option D. Gram stain morphology: Gram stain morphology (tetrads for Micrococcus) is helpful but not confirmatory.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Hugh-Leifson oxidation-fermentation test differentiates Micrococcus species (oxidative) from fermentative gram-positive cocci like staphylococci.

questions.text: Identify the equipment shown in the image below and its primary purpose:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Phototherapy unit

 

  • The image shows a Phototherapy unit, which is primarily used in the treatment of neonatal jaundice.
  • It works by emitting light that converts unconjugated bilirubin in the skin into a water-soluble form (lumirubin), allowing it to be excreted by the liver and kidneys.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Electronic weighing scale: Used for weighing newborns but has no role in the management of jaundice.

 

Option B. Resuscitator: Used for neonatal resuscitation and is unrelated to jaundice management.

 

Option C. Radiant warmer: Used to maintain the body temperature of neonates but does not play a role in bilirubin reduction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Recognize the utility of phototherapy units in the management of neonatal hyperbilirubinemia and distinguish between various neonatal care devices.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female is brought to the psychiatry clinic by her family with complaints of bizarre behavior over the past three months. She claims that she has been chosen by a divine force to save the world and frequently tells her family that she is in communication with celestial beings. Additionally, she reports that her neighbors are conspiring to harm her and interfere with her divine mission. Based on her symptoms, which type of delusion is she most likely experiencing?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Delusion of grandeur and persecution

 

  • The patient presents with delusions of grandeur, as evidenced by her belief that she has been chosen by a divine force to save the world and communicates with celestial beings. 
  • She also exhibits delusions of persecution, as she believes her neighbors are conspiring to harm her and interfere with her mission. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Delusion of grandeur and reference: A delusion of reference involves the belief that ordinary events, objects, or behaviors of others have special and personal significance. While this is not described here, the patient clearly has delusions of grandeur and persecution instead.

 

Option C. Delusion of persecution: While the patient does experience persecutory delusions (e.g., believing her neighbors are conspiring against her), this diagnosis alone does not account for the grandiose delusions about her divine mission.

 

Option D. Delusion of grandeur: Although the patient has grandiose delusions, her paranoid persecutory beliefs indicate that the diagnosis is broader and involves multiple types of delusions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In the delusion of grandeur/grandiosity, the patient believes that he has some special power/role/identity. 
  • For example, "I am so powerful that I can push a train with my bare hands." In the delusion of persecution, the patient believes that he is being harmed.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency department after a blunt trauma to the perineal region sustained while straddling a bicycle. He is experiencing swelling and bruising in the perineum and scrotum, and physical examination reveals blood pooling in the area. There is suspicion of a rupture of the penile urethra. In this scenario, extravasation of blood is least likely to extend into which of the following spaces?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ischiorectal fossa

 

  • Rupture of the penile urethra, particularly in the bulbar region, commonly results in the extravasation of blood and urine into the superficial perineal pouch.
  • This can extend into surrounding structures such as the scrotum, perineum, and even the anterior abdominal wall if the injury is severe enough. 
  • However, the ischiorectal fossa, which is located laterally and posteriorly to the perineal region, is typically not involved because it is separated by the perineal membrane and fascial layers. 
  • As a result, blood does not usually extend into the ischiorectal fossa in cases of penile urethral rupture.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Skin around the scrotum: The superficial perineal pouch is continuous with the subcutaneous tissue of the scrotum. In cases of penile urethral rupture, extravasation of blood commonly extends into the skin around the scrotum. 

 

Option C. Superficial perineal pouch: Blood and urine from a ruptured penile urethra primarily accumulate in the superficial perineal pouch, as the urethra lies within this space. 

 

Option D. Deep perineal pouch: While blood extravasation is more common in the superficial perineal pouch, injury to structures deep to the perineal membrane (such as in more extensive trauma) can occasionally involve the deep perineal pouch.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The ischiorectal fossa is typically spared from extravasation of blood following penile urethral rupture due to its separation by fascial layers and the perineal membrane.

choices.text: Housing conditions (number of persons per room)

questions.text: An epidemiologist is tasked with preparing a report on the socio-economic indicators of health for a developing nation. While reviewing data, she notices that a commonly used parameter is mistakenly considered a socio-economic indicator, despite not being classified as such. Which of the following is not a recognized socio-economic indicator of health?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Annual family income

 

  • Annual family income, although associated with economic status, is not considered a socio-economic indicator of health.
  • Socio-economic indicators, such as housing conditions, literacy rates, and unemployment levels, are used to assess broader structural and population-level determinants of health.
  • These indicators provide insights into the social and economic disparities influencing health outcomes across communities.
  • Annual family income is more of a household-level measure and lacks the broader systemic implications necessary for classification as a socio-economic indicator.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Housing conditions (number of persons per room): This is a socio-economic indicator because overcrowded housing increases the risk of communicable diseases, mental health stress, and poor living conditions, which all affect health outcomes.

 

Option C. Literacy rate, especially female literacy: Female literacy is a critical socio-economic indicator because it is closely linked to improved health outcomes, particularly in maternal and child health. Educated women are more likely to access healthcare, understand health risks, and adopt preventive measures.

 

Option D. Unemployment level: Unemployment is a socio-economic indicator because it affects access to healthcare, income stability, and overall living conditions. High unemployment rates can lead to increased poverty and worsened health outcomes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Socio-economic Indicators [Mnemonic: He FLAGGED] include Housing, Family size, Literacy rate, Availability per capita calorie, GNP per capita, Growth rate, UnEmployment level, Dependency ratio

questions.text: A 34-year-old gravida 2 woman, who was induced at 34 weeks gestation due to severe preeclampsia, has just delivered. What is the most appropriate uterotonic drug to administer during the third stage of labor to prevent postpartum hemorrhage?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Inj Oxytocin 10 IU IV

 

  • Oxytocin is the uterotonic drug of choice for the active management of the third stage of labor, especially in women with preeclampsia.
  •  It is effective in promoting uterine contractions, thereby reducing the risk of postpartum hemorrhage.
  •  Oxytocin is preferred because it has a rapid onset of action, is effective, and is associated with fewer side effects compared to other uterotonics. 
  • In preeclamptic patients, oxytocin is particularly favored because it does not raise blood pressure, unlike methylergometrine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Misoprostol 600 mcg PO: Misoprostol is an alternative uterotonic that can be used when oxytocin is not available. However, it is usually administered rectally or sublingually rather than orally for this purpose. While effective, it is not the first-line drug in this situation.

 

Option B. Inj Methylergometrine 200 mcg IV: Methylergometrine can cause significant vasoconstriction and increase blood pressure, which is particularly risky in a patient with preeclampsia. Therefore, it is contraindicated in such patients.

 

Option D. Inj Carboprost IM: Carboprost is another uterotonic agent that can be used for controlling postpartum hemorrhage, particularly in cases where oxytocin is ineffective. However, it is typically reserved for cases where there is a lack of response to initial treatment due to its side effects, such as bronchospasm and gastrointestinal disturbances. It is not the first-line choice in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Oxytocin is the first-line uterotonic agent for the prevention of postpartum hemorrhage during the third stage of labor, especially in women with preeclampsia, as it is effective and does not increase blood pressure.

choices.text: Type of protective respiratory equipment used

questions.text: A factory worker with a history of occupational exposure to asbestos presents with progressive respiratory symptoms. Which of the following factors is most critical in determining the pathogenesis of pneumoconiosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Particle size of inhaled dust

 

  • The most critical factor in pneumoconiosis, including asbestosis, is the size of the inhaled particles. 
  • Particles in the range of 0.5–3.0 microns are the most dangerous as they can bypass the upper respiratory defenses, lodge in the alveoli, and cause chronic inflammation and fibrosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Duration of asbestos exposure: While prolonged exposure increases the risk, particle size plays a more direct role in pathogenesis.

 

Option C. Type of protective respiratory equipment used: Protective equipment is important for prevention but does not influence the pathogenesis once exposure has occurred.

 

Option D. Immune response to inhaled fibers: The immune response contributes to inflammation, but the size and type of particles play the primary role.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The size of inhaled dust particles (0.5–3.0 microns) is the most critical factor in the development of pneumoconiosis, as these particles can penetrate deep into the alveoli and trigger fibrosis.

choices.text: Uneven gas exchange in the alveoli caused by areas of consolidated lung tissue
Delayed resuscitation efforts resulting in partial aeration of the lungs
Atelectasis in some lobes of the lung due to obstruction of the alveolar ducts
Decomposition gases causing a combination of false-positive and false-negative results

questions.text: A newborn dies shortly after birth, and the hydrostatic test shows partial lung aeration, with some lung pieces floating and others sinking. The autopsy reveals that the infant suffered from severe congenital pneumonia. What is the most likely mechanism behind the mixed hydrostatic test results?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Uneven gas exchange in the alveoli caused by areas of consolidated lung tissue

 

  • Congenital pneumonia can cause uneven aeration of the lungs due to inflammation and consolidation in certain areas, while other parts may remain aerated. 
  • This results in a mixed hydrostatic test, with some lung pieces floating due to air and others sinking due to consolidated tissue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Delayed resuscitation efforts resulting in partial aeration of the lungs: Delayed resuscitation would typically produce generalized partial aeration, not a mixed pattern.

 

Option C. Atelectasis in some lobes of the lung due to obstruction of the alveolar ducts: Atelectasis causes lung collapse, leading to all lung pieces sinking rather than a mixed result.

 

Option D. Decomposition gases causing a combination of false-positive and false-negative results: Decomposition gases would produce generalized floating, not a combination of floating and sinking.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Partial lung aeration on the hydrostatic test may occur in congenital pneumonia due to uneven gas exchange and areas of lung consolidation.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with profuse watery diarrhea resembling "rice water" stools, severe dehydration, and electrolyte imbalance. His symptoms are consistent with an infection leading to increased intestinal permeability. Damage to which of the following cellular structures is most likely responsible for the increased fluid loss?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Zona occludens

 

  • Zona occludens (tight junctions) are responsible for maintaining the paracellular barrier that regulates the passage of ions, solutes, and water between epithelial cells. 
  • Infections such as cholera disrupt these tight junctions through the action of bacterial toxins, leading to a loss of barrier integrity and massive fluid secretion into the intestinal lumen, causing severe watery diarrhea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gap junction: Gap junctions facilitate cell-to-cell communication by allowing the passage of ions and small molecules between adjacent cells. They are not involved in maintaining the integrity of the paracellular barrier.

 

Option B. Hemidesmosomes: Hemidesmosomes anchor epithelial cells to the basement membrane and play a role in structural support, not in regulating paracellular permeability.

 

Option C. Adherent junction: Adherent junctions provide mechanical stability by linking the actin cytoskeletons of neighboring cells. Although they contribute to cell adhesion, they do not directly regulate the passage of fluid or solutes between cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Zona occludens (tight junctions) are essential for maintaining epithelial barrier function by regulating paracellular transport. 
  • Disruption of tight junctions by bacterial toxins can lead to increased intestinal permeability and massive fluid loss, as seen in cholera-related rice-water diarrhea.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with complaints of infertility and light menstrual periods for the past year. She has a history of multiple miscarriages that required dilation and curettage (D&C). Which diagnostic procedure is the most appropriate to confirm and potentially treat her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hysteroscopy

 

Explanation:

 

The patient's history of multiple miscarriages requiring dilation and curettage (D&C), along with symptoms of infertility and light menstrual periods (hypomenorrhea), is suggestive of Asherman syndrome (intrauterine adhesions). Intrauterine adhesions form due to trauma to the endometrium, commonly after repeated D&Cs.

 

Hysteroscopy is the gold standard for diagnosing and treating Asherman syndrome. It provides a direct view of the uterine cavity, enabling precise identification of adhesions and simultaneous adhesiolysis (removal of adhesions). This approach helps restore the endometrial cavity’s normal structure, improving the chances of conception and alleviating symptoms like hypomenorrhea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pelvic ultrasound: Pelvic ultrasound is a non-invasive imaging method commonly used to evaluate the uterus and adnexa for abnormalities like fibroids or ovarian cysts. However, it cannot provide direct visualization of adhesions or intrauterine scarring, making it suboptimal for diagnosing Asherman syndrome. The adhesions may not always alter the thickness of the endometrium in a way that is visible on an ultrasound, limiting its diagnostic accuracy in this scenario.

 

Option B. MRI pelvis: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the pelvis provides detailed imaging of soft tissue structures and is effective in diagnosing complex uterine conditions like adenomyosis, fibroids, and congenital uterine anomalies. However, it is not typically the investigation of choice for evaluating suspected intrauterine adhesions, as it lacks the resolution needed to directly visualize intrauterine pathology and cannot be used for therapeutic purposes.

 

Option C. Saline infusion sonography: Saline infusion sonography (sonohysterography) involves instilling saline into the uterine cavity to enhance visualization of the endometrial lining and detect abnormalities such as polyps or adhesions. While this method can detect adhesions as filling defects, it cannot provide direct visualization or treatment of adhesions. Hysteroscopy remains superior because it allows both diagnosis and immediate treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hysteroscopy is the gold standard for the diagnosis and treatment of intrauterine adhesions (Asherman syndrome), providing direct visualization of the uterine cavity and allowing for adhesiolysis in the same session.

choices.text: Synergistic estrogenic effect with ethinyl Estradiol

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman is prescribed a fixed-dose combination (FDC) of drospirenone and ethinyl estradiol as an oral contraceptive. Three months into therapy, she develops mild hyperkalemia on routine bloodwork. Which property of drospirenone is most likely responsible for this finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anti-mineralocorticoid action

 

  • Drospirenone, a fourth-generation progestin, exhibits anti-mineralocorticoid activity, similar to spironolactone. 
  • This property can lead to potassium retention and mild hyperkalemia, especially in individuals predisposed to electrolyte imbalances. 
  • The estrogen component (ethinyl estradiol) does not directly affect potassium levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anti-androgenic action: Incorrect. Drospirenone has anti-androgenic effects, but this property does not explain the development of hyperkalemia.

 

Option C. Synergistic estrogenic effect with ethinyl estradiol: Incorrect. While the combination provides effective contraception, it does not cause hyperkalemia.

 

Option D. Inhibition of aldosterone synthesis: Incorrect. Drospirenone does not inhibit aldosterone synthesis but antagonizes its receptor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Drospirenone is a progestin with anti-mineralocorticoid activity that can cause mild hyperkalemia due to its potassium-retaining effects.

questions.text: A baby assessed at 5 minutes after birth had pink extremities, a heart rate of 99/min, strong crying, active movement, and responded to stimulation by crying. The APGAR score for this newborn is ________.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 9

 

  • Colour: Pink extremities = Score 2
  • Heart Rate: less than 100/min = Score 1
  • Respiration: Strong crying = Score 2
  • Muscle Tone: Active movement = Score 2
  • Reflex Irritability: Response to stimulation by crying = Score 2
  • Total APGAR score = 9

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • APGAR scoring evaluates five objective signs at 1 and 5 minutes after birth: color, heart rate, respiration, muscle tone, and reflex irritability. A perfect score of 10 indicates a healthy and well-adapted newborn.

choices.text: Scleral fixation of the intraocular lens due to zonular instability
Posterior chamber intraocular lens implantation after cataract extraction
Extra-capsular cataract extraction to remove the opacified lens

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with a history of primary open-angle glaucoma and visually significant cataracts presents for surgical evaluation. His intraocular pressure remains uncontrolled despite maximal medical therapy, and he reports significant glare and visual impairment. A combined surgical approach is planned to address both conditions. Which of the following procedures is least likely to be included in the standard triple procedure for glaucoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Scleral fixation of the intraocular lens due to zonular instability

 

  • The standard triple procedure for glaucoma includes trabeculectomy to lower intraocular pressure, extra-capsular cataract extraction to remove the opacified lens, and posterior chamber intraocular lens implantation to restore vision. 
  • Scleral fixation of the intraocular lens, while necessary in cases of significant zonular instability, is not a standard component of the triple procedure. 
  • It represents a modification to address a specific complication or anatomical abnormality.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trabeculectomy to lower intraocular pressure: Trabeculectomy is a key part of the standard triple procedure for glaucoma, helping to lower intraocular pressure by creating a new drainage pathway.

 

Option C. Posterior chamber intraocular lens implantation after cataract extraction: Posterior chamber intraocular lens implantation is included in the triple procedure to replace the natural lens and restore visual function.

 

Option D. Extra-capsular cataract extraction to remove the opacified lens: Extra-capsular cataract extraction is the preferred method of lens removal in the triple procedure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The triple procedure for glaucoma includes trabeculectomy, extra-capsular cataract extraction, and posterior chamber intraocular lens implantation. 
  • Additional modifications, such as scleral fixation of the intraocular lens, may be required in cases of anatomical abnormalities (e.g., zonular weakness) but are not standard components.

questions.text: A study analyzing pressure-volume loops in different cardiac conditions observes a leftward shift in the loop. Which of the following conditions is most likely associated with this finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aortic stenosis

 

  • A leftward shift in the pressure-volume loop indicates decreased left ventricular end-diastolic volume (LVEDV), often due to increased ventricular stiffness and reduced compliance. 
  • Aortic stenosis causes left ventricular hypertrophy (concentric), leading to decreased ventricular compliance and an increase in diastolic pressure for a given volume. 
  • This results in a lower LVEDV and an upward and leftward shift of the loop, indicating a "stiff" ventricle.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aortic regurgitation: Aortic regurgitation results in an increased end-diastolic volume due to backflow of blood into the left ventricle, causing a rightward and widened shift of the pressure-volume loop.

 

Option B. Congestive heart failure: In heart failure, the pressure-volume loop shifts rightward due to ventricular dilation and increased end-diastolic volume. The overall loop may also shrink with reduced stroke volume and increased preload.

 

Option D. Mitral regurgitation: In mitral regurgitation, there is a volume overload, resulting in an increased stroke volume and a rightward shift of the loop with a wider width due to the backflow of blood into the left atrium during systole.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A leftward shift of the pressure-volume loop indicates decreased ventricular compliance, commonly seen in aortic stenosis due to concentric left ventricular hypertrophy. 
  • This results in higher filling pressures and reduced end-diastolic volume.

questions.text: A pregnant woman in the labor room is undergoing fetal monitoring as part of routine assessment during labor. Which of the following best describes this procedure?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cardiotocography (CTG)

 

  • This is an image of a Cardiotocography (CTG)
  • Cardiotocography (CTG) is a non-invasive procedure used to monitor fetal well-being during pregnancy and labor. 
  • It records:
    1. Fetal heart rate (FHR) via an ultrasound transducer.
    2. Uterine contractions using a tocodynamometer placed on the abdomen.
  • CTG provides information on the baseline fetal heart rate, variability, accelerations, decelerations, and contraction patterns, which help assess fetal distress or uterine hyperstimulation.
  •  It is commonly used to monitor fetal status during labor.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amniotic fluid index (AFI) determination: This involves measuring the amniotic fluid pockets via ultrasound to assess fetal hydration and well-being. It is not related to recording fetal heart rate and contractions.

 

Option B. MCA Doppler: Middle cerebral artery (MCA) Doppler assesses fetal blood flow to detect signs of fetal anemia or hypoxia. It is used in cases of intrauterine growth restriction or Rh incompatibility, not for routine labor monitoring.

 

Option D. Amniocentesis: Amniocentesis is an invasive procedure involving needle aspiration of amniotic fluid for diagnostic purposes, such as fetal karyotyping or infection assessment, not fetal heart rate monitoring.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cardiotocography (CTG) is used to monitor fetal heart rate and uterine contractions during pregnancy and labor, providing critical information about fetal well-being and identifying signs of fetal distress.

questions.text: Mr. Keerthi, 18-year-old man presents to the emergency department with retrosternal chest pain and pain with swallowing that started abruptly the previous morning and has progressively worsened. The pain is burning in nature and worse with swallowing solids. He has been limiting his diet to soft foods due to discomfort. His medical history includes frequent tension headaches for which he uses ibuprofen as needed. He smokes a half pack of cigarettes daily and drinks alcohol socially. His mother has Crohn disease. On examination, his temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), blood pressure is 118/76 mm Hg, and pulse is 88/min. There are no oropharyngeal lesions, lymphadenopathy, or abnormalities on lung auscultation, cardiac examination, or abdominal examination. Endoscopy was done and the image is shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Recommend ibuprofen discontinuation

 

  • This patient's symptoms of retrosternal chest pain and odynophagia (painful swallowing) are consistent with pill esophagitis, likely caused by frequent ibuprofen use. 
  • Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) are a common cause of direct mucosal injury in the esophagus, leading to localized inflammation and pain. 
  • Discontinuing the offending agent is the primary management step.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Obtain barium esophagram: Barium studies are not first-line for diagnosing pill esophagitis. They are more appropriate for evaluating structural abnormalities like strictures or achalasia, which are not suggested by this patient's history.

 

Option B. Perform HIV testing: HIV testing is indicated if symptoms suggest opportunistic infections like esophagitis due to Candida, herpes simplex virus, or cytomegalovirus. This patient lacks risk factors (e.g., immunosuppression, candidiasis) or findings suggestive of these conditions.

 

Option C. Prescribe swallowed fluticasone spray: Swallowed fluticasone is used for eosinophilic esophagitis, which typically presents with chronic dysphagia, food impaction, or a history of atopic conditions. The acute onset of symptoms in this case makes eosinophilic esophagitis unlikely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pill esophagitis should be suspected in patients with retrosternal chest pain and odynophagia, especially in the context of recent NSAID or other pill use. 
  • Management involves discontinuing the offending agent and advising on proper pill-swallowing techniques to prevent recurrence.

questions.text: Which of the following fibers originates from this indicated structure?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dentato-rubral fibers

 

  • The indicated structure in the provided image is the dentate nucleus. The dentate nucleus is the largest and most lateral of the deep cerebellar nuclei. It plays a crucial role in the coordination of voluntary movements, particularly fine motor control. 
  • The dentate nucleus sends projections to the contralateral red nucleus via the dentato-rubral tract, which then relays information to the motor cortex through the thalamus. 
  • This pathway is involved in motor planning and precision movements.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cerebello-reticular fibers: These fibers originate from the fastigial nucleus and project to the reticular formation, primarily involved in regulating posture and balance.

 

Option C. Cerebello-vestibular fibers: These originate from the fastigial nucleus and directly project to the vestibular nuclei, assisting in balance and equilibrium.

 

Option D. Cerebello-rubral fibers: This is a less specific term, as the dentato-rubral fibers are the primary rubral connections of the cerebellum, originating specifically from the dentate nucleus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The dentate nucleus of the cerebellum is involved in motor coordination and sends output to the red nucleus via dentato-rubral fibers, contributing to fine motor control and voluntary movement precision.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man with a 10-year history of Parkinson's disease is on levodopa/carbidopa therapy. Over the last few months, he has developed visual hallucinations and delusions. He denies suicidal ideation or harming others. His motor symptoms are well-controlled. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Start quetiapine

 

  • Quetiapine is an atypical antipsychotic with low dopamine D2 receptor antagonism and a favorable safety profile in patients with Parkinson's disease who develop psychosis.
  • It effectively treats psychotic symptoms without exacerbating motor symptoms. Psychosis in Parkinson's disease is often due to dopaminergic therapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increase the dose of levodopa: Increasing levodopa can worsen psychosis by further stimulating dopamine receptors in the brain.

 

Option C. Discontinue levodopa therapy: Abrupt cessation can lead to severe motor decline or withdrawal effects, such as neuroleptic malignant-like syndrome.

 

Option D. Initiate haloperidol: Haloperidol is a typical antipsychotic with strong D2 receptor antagonism and can worsen Parkinsonian symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Quetiapine and clozapine are the preferred agents for treating psychosis in Parkinson's disease due to their minimal impact on motor function.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man with a history of asthma and chronic rhinosinusitis presents with shortness of breath. Three days ago, he developed an upper respiratory infection, followed by increased sinus headache and mild dyspnea. Despite using diphenhydramine, albuterol, ibuprofen, and his regular fluticasone/salmeterol inhaler, his dyspnea worsened over 3 hours. He has a history of nasal polyps and sinus surgeries. On examination, he is in mild respiratory distress with a pulse of 115/min and respirations of 23/min. Pulse oximetry shows 98% on 2L oxygen via nasal cannula. Rhinorrhea, diffuse bilateral wheezes, conjunctival injection, and facial erythema are noted. He is treated with methylprednisolone and albuterol nebulizations, leading to symptom improvement over 24 hours. In addition to tapering doses of prednisone, which of the following would most likely benefit this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Montelukast

 

  • This patient likely has aspirin-exacerbated respiratory disease (AERD), a condition characterized by asthma, chronic rhinosinusitis with nasal polyps, and sensitivity to nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) like ibuprofen. 
  • Leukotriene receptor antagonists such as montelukast reduce airway inflammation and improve asthma control in AERD by blocking the effects of leukotrienes, which play a significant role in this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Discontinuation of salmeterol: Salmeterol, a long-acting beta-agonist (LABA), is part of the combination therapy with fluticasone for asthma control. It should not be discontinued unless there is an alternative asthma control strategy, as LABAs are essential for preventing exacerbations when used with inhaled corticosteroids.

 

Option B. Macrolide antibiotic: Macrolides are not indicated in this case, as there is no evidence of bacterial infection. This patient’s symptoms are more consistent with AERD and asthma exacerbation, not an infectious process.

 

Option D. Referral for anti-IgE therapy: Anti-IgE therapy (omalizumab) is used in moderate-to-severe allergic asthma that is IgE-mediated. There is no indication of allergic asthma or elevated IgE levels in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Aspirin-exacerbated respiratory disease (AERD) is associated with asthma, chronic rhinosinusitis with nasal polyps, and NSAID sensitivity. 
  • Management includes leukotriene-modifying agents such as montelukast to improve airway inflammation and control symptoms.

questions.text: In the electron transport chain, which of the following respiratory components directly interacts with molecular oxygen during oxidative phosphorylation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cytochrome c oxidase (Complex IV)

 

  • The ETC has 4 main complexes (I–IV) plus ATP synthase (Complex V).
  • Complex IV = Cytochrome c oxidase is the terminal enzyme in the chain.
    • It accepts electrons from cytochrome c.
    • Transfers them to molecular oxygen (O₂).
    • Reduces O₂ to water (H₂O)
  • This step is essential for maintaining the proton gradient that drives ATP synthesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Complex I (NADH dehydrogenase): Accepts electrons from NADH → passes to Coenzyme Q. No direct O₂ involvement.

 

Option B. Complex II (Succinate dehydrogenase): Accepts electrons from FADH₂ → passes to CoQ. No direct O₂ interaction.

 

Option D. Complex V (ATP synthase): Uses proton gradient to synthesize ATP. Does not handle O₂.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset shortness of breath and sharp left-sided chest pain. He denies fever, loss of consciousness, or orthopnea. His medical history is significant for metastatic pancreatic cancer diagnosed three months ago. On examination, his lungs are clear, heart sounds are normal, and his abdomen is soft and non-tender. There is trace edema in the right leg, and neurologic examination is unremarkable. Laboratory findings reveal elevated serum troponin levels (0.9 ng/mL), normal complete blood count, and normal renal function. A right leg ultrasound reveals a thrombus in the popliteal vein, and a CT angiogram of the chest shows bilateral filling defects. Which of the following would be the most effective long-term treatment to prevent recurrent thromboembolism in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Enoxaparin

 

  • Low molecular weight heparin (LMWH), such as enoxaparin, is the preferred long-term anticoagulant in patients with cancer-associated thromboembolism due to its superior efficacy in preventing recurrence compared to warfarin. 
  • LMWH is associated with fewer drug and dietary interactions and is not dependent on hepatic metabolism, making it a better choice in cancer patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Unfractionated heparin: Unfractionated heparin is useful for initial anticoagulation but requires continuous intravenous administration and monitoring. It is not suitable for long-term management.

 

Option C. Warfarin: Warfarin is less effective than LMWH in cancer-associated thrombosis and has significant interactions with diet and medications, making it less practical in cancer patients.

 

Option D. Warfarin and IVC filter: Inferior vena cava (IVC) filters are indicated in patients with contraindications to anticoagulation. This patient has no contraindication and would benefit more from anticoagulation therapy alone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In cancer-associated thromboembolism, LMWH is the treatment of choice for long-term prevention of recurrent thromboembolism due to its superior efficacy and safety profile compared to other anticoagulants.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the quadruple marker test?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Unconjugated estradiol (uE2)

 

  • The quadruple marker test is a prenatal screening performed in the second trimester (15–20 weeks gestation) to assess the risk of chromosomal abnormalities such as Down syndrome (trisomy 21), trisomy 18, and neural tube defects.
  •  It includes:
    1. Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP): A fetal protein; elevated levels suggest neural tube defects, while decreased levels indicate trisomy 21 or 18.
    2. Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG): Elevated levels are associated with trisomy 21.
    3. Inhibin-A: Increased in trisomy 21.
    4. Unconjugated estriol (uE3): Reduced in cases of trisomy 21 and 18.

  • However, unconjugated estradiol is not a part of the quadruple marker test. Estradiol is a form of estrogen that plays a role in maintaining pregnancy but is not used as a diagnostic marker in the screening panel.

     

Educational Objective:

 

  • The quadruple marker test includes AFP, hCG, inhibin-A, and unconjugated estriol (uE3). Unconjugated estradiol is not part of the test and is not used for prenatal screening of chromosomal or structural fetal abnormalities.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents with a history of recurrent pregnancy loss. She has no other significant medical history or bleeding tendencies. Which of the following tests is most appropriate to evaluate the likely underlying cause of her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Dilute Russell's viper venom time (dRVVT)

 

  • Recurrent miscarriages in the absence of other significant medical history are highly suggestive of antiphospholipid syndrome (APS), an autoimmune disorder characterized by the presence of antiphospholipid antibodies. 
  • These antibodies promote a hypercoagulable state, leading to thrombotic events, pregnancy loss, and fetal demise. 
  • The dilute Russell's viper venom time (dRVVT) is a sensitive and specific test used to detect lupus anticoagulant, a key diagnostic marker for APS. Prolongation of dRVVT that does not correct with mixing studies but corrects with the addition of phospholipids confirms the presence of lupus anticoagulant.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clot retraction time: Clot retraction time measures platelet function and clot stabilization but is not used to evaluate hypercoagulable states or APS.

 

Option B. Bleeding time: Bleeding time is used to evaluate platelet function and primary hemostasis, typically prolonged in conditions like von Willebrand disease or thrombocytopenia. It is not relevant in the evaluation of APS.

 

Option C. Prothrombin time (PT): PT measures the extrinsic coagulation pathway and is prolonged in conditions like vitamin K deficiency or liver disease. It does not help diagnose APS or detect lupus anticoagulant.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Dilute Russell's viper venom time (dRVVT) is a key test for detecting lupus anticoagulant, an important marker in diagnosing antiphospholipid syndrome, a common cause of recurrent pregnancy loss due to its pro-thrombotic effects.

questions.text: A 45-year-old diabetic patient presents with complaints of discoloration of his toenail for the past 4 months, as shown in the image below . Microscopic examination of a sample is shown below. Which of the following organisms is the most likely cause of his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Trichophyton rubrum

 

  • Onychomycosis, or fungal infection of the nail, is most commonly caused by dermatophytes. 
  • Trichophyton rubrum is the leading cause of distal subungual onychomycosis, especially in diabetic and immunocompromised individuals.
  •  The condition is characterized by discoloration, thickening, and dystrophy of the nails, as seen in the image.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Trichophyton schoenleinii: This organism is typically associated with tinea favosa (favus), a chronic fungal infection of the scalp, characterized by yellow crusts. It is not a common cause of onychomycosis.

 

Option C. Epidermophyton floccosum: While this dermatophyte can cause tinea corporis and tinea cruris, it is rarely implicated in nail infections. It primarily affects the skin rather than nails.

 

Option D. Microsporum gypseum This is a geophilic dermatophyte associated with soil exposure. It is not a common cause of onychomycosis, as it primarily causes tinea corporis or tinea capitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Trichophyton rubrum is the most common cause of distal subungual onychomycosis, especially in patients with risk factors like diabetes or immunosuppression. 
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by clinical features and KOH preparation showing fungal elements.

questions.text: A postmenopausal woman is being treated with exemestane for estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer. What is the most likely side effect associated with this medication?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Osteoporosis

 

  • Aromatase inhibitors like exemestane reduce circulating estrogen levels, which can lead to decreased bone mineral density and an increased risk of osteoporosis and fractures. 
  • This is a significant concern in postmenopausal women, who already have a baseline risk for bone loss due to estrogen deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thromboembolism: This is more commonly associated with SERMs like tamoxifen, not aromatase inhibitors.

 

Option B. Endometrial hyperplasia: Tamoxifen is associated with endometrial hyperplasia and cancer, while exemestane does not carry this risk.

 

Option D. Hepatic toxicity: Exemestane has a low risk of hepatotoxicity and this is not a common side effect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Aromatase inhibitors, such as exemestane, reduce estrogen synthesis and are associated with an increased risk of osteoporosis due to their effect on bone mineral density.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with shortness of breath and lower extremity swelling. On auscultation, a soft, low-pitched sound (S3) is heard after S2. This sound is closely associated with which phase of the cardiac cycle?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Passive atrial emptying

 

  • The S3 heart sound occurs during the rapid filling phase of diastole, also known as passive atrial emptying. 
  • It results from the sudden deceleration of blood as it enters a volume-overloaded or non-compliant ventricle. 
  • An S3 is considered physiological in children and young adults but pathological in conditions like heart failure, dilated cardiomyopathy, or significant mitral regurgitation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atrial systole: Atrial systole occurs at the end of diastole and corresponds to the active contraction of the atria. This phase is more closely associated with the S4 heart sound, which reflects atrial contraction against a stiff ventricle.

 

Option C. Active atrial emptying: This is another term for atrial systole and is also linked to the S4 heart sound, not S3.

 

Option D. Isovolumetric relaxation: Isovolumetric relaxation is the phase after ventricular ejection, during which the ventricles relax but the valves remain closed. It is not associated with the S3 heart sound.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The S3 heart sound occurs during the rapid ventricular filling phase of diastole (passive atrial emptying) and is typically caused by sudden deceleration of blood into a distended or non-compliant ventricle.

choices.text: The absolute risk reduction (ARR) is 5%, and the relative risk reduction (RRR) is 25%.
The absolute risk reduction (ARR) is 5%, and the number needed to treat (NNT) is 20.
The relative risk reduction (RRR) is 10%, and the number needed to treat (NNT) is 50.
The absolute risk reduction (ARR) is 10%, and the relative risk reduction (RRR) is 50%.

questions.text: A clinical trial evaluates the safety profile of a new medication compared to a placebo in preventing adverse events. The study enrolled 20,000 participants, evenly randomized into two groups (new drug vs. placebo). After one year of follow-up, 1,500 participants in the new drug group and 2,000 participants in the placebo group experienced adverse events. Based on these findings, which of the following is the most accurate calculation regarding the efficacy of the new drug?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The absolute risk reduction (ARR) is 5%, and the number needed to treat (NNT) is 20.

 

  • The absolute risk reduction (ARR) is calculated by subtracting the event rate in the new drug group from the event rate in the placebo group:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The absolute risk reduction (ARR), relative risk reduction (RRR), and number needed to treat (NNT) are critical measures used to evaluate the efficacy of an intervention. ARR provides the direct difference in risk, RRR highlights the proportional reduction in risk, and NNT quantifies the number of individuals needed to treat to prevent one adverse outcome. 
  • Accurate calculation of these measures is essential for understanding clinical trial results and their application in practice.

questions.text: A 6-month-old baby presents with generalized seizures and irritability. The mother reports poor feeding and delayed developmental milestones. A detailed history and clinical findings suggest vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) deficiency as the cause of the seizures. Which of the following tests is most useful to confirm a diagnosis of vitamin B6 deficiency?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Xanthurenic acid test

 

  • The xanthurenic acid test measures the accumulation of xanthurenic acid in the urine after administering a tryptophan load. 
  • In vitamin B6 deficiency, the enzyme kynureninase, which requires pyridoxal phosphate (active form of vitamin B6) as a coenzyme, becomes deficient. 
  • This leads to incomplete metabolism of tryptophan, resulting in the accumulation of xanthurenic acid, which is excreted in the urine. 
  • Elevated xanthurenic acid levels confirm a deficiency of vitamin B6.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transketolase test: The transketolase test is used to assess thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency. Transketolase activity in red blood cells increases significantly when thiamine pyrophosphate is added in cases of deficiency. This test is unrelated to vitamin B6 deficiency.

 

Option B. D-Xylose absorption test: The D-xylose absorption test is used to evaluate carbohydrate absorption in the small intestine. It helps identify malabsorption syndromes but is unrelated to vitamin B6 metabolism.

 

Option D. Glutathione reductase test: The glutathione reductase test is used to diagnose riboflavin (vitamin B2) deficiency. It measures the activity of glutathione reductase, an enzyme that requires flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD) as a cofactor. This test does not indicate vitamin B6 levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The xanthurenic acid test is used to diagnose vitamin B6 deficiency by measuring the accumulation of xanthurenic acid in the urine after a tryptophan load. 
  • In vitamin B6 deficiency, the impaired conversion of tryptophan leads to elevated urinary excretion of xanthurenic acid.

questions.text: Which of the following vaccines is administered intradermally in the right upper arm during infancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) IPV fractional dose

 

  • IPV (Inactivated Poliovirus Vaccine) is given as two fractional doses at 6 and 14 weeks of age. 
  • Each dose is 0.1 mL and is administered intradermally in the right upper arm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hepatitis B: This is given intramuscularly on the antero-lateral side of the mid-thigh, not intradermally.

 

Option B. OPV-0: This is administered orally as 2 drops.

 

Option D. Pentavalent vaccine: This is given intramuscularly on the antero-lateral side of the mid-thigh.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Understand the route, dosage, and site of administration of vaccines in the immunization schedule for infants. 
  • IPV fractional dose is uniquely administered intradermally in the right upper arm at 6 and 14 weeks.

questions.text: A 20-year-old college student is brought to the emergency department due to progressive lethargy and confusion. His friend reports a history of chills and diarrhea since last night. Three days ago, the patient sustained a nasal fracture during a bar fight, which was reduced and stabilized with nasal packing at another hospital. He has no known medical conditions, medications, or drug allergies. On examination, his temperature is 39.4°C (102.9°F), blood pressure is 84/42 mm Hg, pulse is 126/min, and respirations are 18/min. The patient appears ill with diffuse erythema involving mucous membranes, palms, and soles. Anterior nasal packing is visible in the left nostril, and there is mild pitting edema in both legs. Laboratory results reveal thrombocytopenia, acute kidney injury, hyponatremia, elevated liver enzymes, and metabolic acidosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial antimicrobial therapy for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Vancomycin, cefepime, and clindamycin

 

  • This patient presents with toxic shock syndrome (TSS), a life-threatening condition caused by toxins produced by Staphylococcus aureus or Streptococcus pyogenes. 
  • His history of nasal packing and symptoms of fever, hypotension, confusion, diffuse erythroderma, and multiorgan dysfunction are consistent with TSS.

 

Empiric therapy includes:

 

  • Vancomycin: Covers methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA).
  • Cefepime: Broad-spectrum coverage for potential gram-negative organisms.
  • Clindamycin: Inhibits toxin production by Staphylococcus aureus and Streptococcus pyogenes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ceftriaxone and azithromycin: This regimen is appropriate for community-acquired pneumonia but does not cover TSS pathogens or inhibit toxin production.

 

Option B. Doxycycline: Doxycycline is used for tick-borne diseases and atypical infections but is not adequate for TSS.

 

Option C. Penicillin G benzathine: Penicillin G benzathine is used for specific infections like syphilis but lacks the broad-spectrum and toxin-inhibiting properties needed in TSS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Toxic shock syndrome requires prompt recognition and treatment with broad-spectrum antibiotics, including agents that inhibit toxin production (e.g., clindamycin). 
  • Nasal packing is a recognized risk factor for Staphylococcus aureus TSS. 
  • Rapid initiation of antibiotics and aggressive supportive care are essential to reduce mortality

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is enrolled in a pharmacokinetics study. During the study, he is administered a drug that is known to follow first-order kinetics. The researchers measure the plasma concentration and clearance of the drug over time. Which of the following graphs correctly illustrates the relationship between clearance and plasma concentration for this drug?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 

 

 

  • In first-order kinetics, the rate of drug elimination is proportional to the plasma concentration. 
  • However, the clearance (volume of plasma cleared of the drug per unit time) remains constant, regardless of plasma concentration. This is because a fixed fraction of the drug is eliminated per unit of time, rather than a fixed amount.
  • Therefore, the graph illustrating first-order kinetics shows clearance as a flat line across varying plasma concentrations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: Incorrect. This pattern suggests dose-dependent kinetics or non-linear elimination, not characteristic of first-order kinetics.

 

Option C: Incorrect. This represents saturable processes such as Michaelis-Menten kinetics, where enzymes or transporters involved in elimination become saturated at higher concentrations.

 

Option D: Incorrect. This pattern is associated with certain physiological processes like threshold-based clearance or transporters that exhibit cooperative binding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In first-order kinetics, the clearance of a drug remains constant irrespective of plasma concentration, as a constant fraction of the drug is eliminated per unit time. 
  • This is in contrast to non-linear or zero-order kinetics, where clearance may change with plasma concentration due to saturation of metabolic or excretory pathways.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with muscle weakness, exercise intolerance, and failure to thrive. He also has a history of cardiomyopathy. Genetic testing reveals a mitochondrial disorder consistent with Barth syndrome, which affects the composition of the inner mitochondrial membrane. Which of the following molecules is defective in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cardiolipin

 

  • Barth syndrome is an X-linked disorder caused by mutations in the TAZ gene, which encodes tafazzin, an enzyme involved in remodeling cardiolipin, a key phospholipid of the inner mitochondrial membrane. 
  • Cardiolipin is essential for maintaining mitochondrial structure and function, particularly for stabilizing the electron transport chain complexes. 
  • Defective cardiolipin synthesis disrupts ATP production, leading to mitochondrial dysfunction, muscle weakness, cardiomyopathy, and other clinical features of Barth syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lecithin: Lecithin (phosphatidylcholine) is a major phospholipid of cell membranes, but it is not involved in mitochondrial membrane stability and is not affected in Barth syndrome.

 

Option B. Lysolecithin: Lysolecithin is a derivative of lecithin, formed when one fatty acid is removed. It is associated with inflammation and cell membrane damage but has no direct role in mitochondrial function.

 

Option D. Phosphatidylserine: Phosphatidylserine is a phospholipid involved in apoptosis signaling and cell membrane composition but does not play a direct role in mitochondrial inner membrane function or Barth syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Barth syndrome is characterized by defective cardiolipin due to mutations in the TAZ gene, leading to mitochondrial dysfunction, cardiomyopathy, and muscle weakness. 
  • Cardiolipin is critical for maintaining the integrity of the mitochondrial inner membrane and efficient ATP production.

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman presents with a 2-week history of sudden-onset vertigo and progressive hearing loss in her right ear. She denies tinnitus or otalgia. On examination, she has no signs of facial weakness or other neurological deficits. Imaging reveals a mass located in the anterosuperior quadrant of the internal auditory canal (IAC). Which of the following structures is most likely affected by the mass?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Facial nerve

 

  • The internal auditory canal (IAC) contains four key nerves, which are organized anatomically as follows:
    1. Anterosuperior quadrant: Facial nerve.
    2. Anteroinferior quadrant: Cochlear nerve.
    3. Posterosuperior quadrant: Superior vestibular nerve.
    4. Posteroinferior quadrant: Inferior vestibular nerve.
  • If the mass is located in the anterosuperior part of the IAC, the facial nerve is most likely to be affected, leading to facial weakness, twitching, or other motor symptoms related to the facial nerve. 
  • Although vertigo and hearing loss may be present due to the involvement of neighboring structures, the anterosuperior location directly implicates the facial nerve.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cochlear nerve: The cochlear nerve is located in the anteroinferior quadrant of the IAC. While this nerve mediates hearing, it is not located in the anterosuperior part of the IAC, where the facial nerve lies.

 

Option B. Superior vestibular nerve: The superior vestibular nerve is found in the posterosuperior quadrant of the IAC. It transmits signals related to balance from the superior semicircular canal but is not affected by a mass in the anterosuperior quadrant.

 

Option C. Inferior vestibular nerve: The inferior vestibular nerve occupies the posteroinferior quadrant of the IAC. It also transmits balance information but is not located in the anterosuperior quadrant.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The facial nerve occupies the anterosuperior quadrant of the internal auditory canal (IAC). A mass in this region is most likely to affect the facial nerve, potentially causing facial motor symptoms.

questions.text: A renal biopsy reveals the characteristic appearance shown in the image below. Which of the following conditions is most likely associated with this gross finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Malignant hypertension

 

  • The image shows a gross specimen of a kidney with a "flea-bitten" appearance. 
  • This characteristic appearance is due to numerous small, red, pinpoint hemorrhages scattered over the cortical surface of the kidney. 
  • The hemorrhages are indicative of vascular injury, consistent with conditions that cause arteriolar necrosis and capillary rupture, such as malignant hypertension.
  • Malignant hypertension is characterized by an accelerated rise in blood pressure, leading to fibrinoid necrosis of arterioles and capillaries. This results in pinpoint hemorrhages on the surface of the kidney, producing the "flea-bitten" appearance. 
  • The glomeruli show fibrinoid necrosis and hyperplastic arteriolosclerosis (onion-skinning), which contributes to ischemic damage. Clinically, malignant hypertension presents with signs of end-organ damage, including renal dysfunction, papilledema, and encephalopathy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Polyarteritis nodosa: This condition involves segmental necrotizing inflammation of medium-sized arteries, sparing the glomeruli, and does not typically cause a flea-bitten kidney appearance.

 

Option B. Lupus nephritis: Lupus nephritis can present with wire-loop lesions due to immune complex deposition and can lead to nephritic or nephrotic syndrome but does not characteristically cause a flea-bitten kidney.

 

Option C. Goodpasture syndrome: This condition results in crescentic glomerulonephritis with linear deposition of anti-GBM antibodies on immunofluorescence. It may lead to hematuria and renal failure but does not produce the flea-bitten appearance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The "flea-bitten" kidney appearance with pinpoint hemorrhages is a hallmark of malignant hypertension due to fibrinoid necrosis and capillary rupture.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with mid-abdominal pain and vomiting for two days, along with dark stools and decreased appetite. He reports feeling "down" for the past week and has noticed a rash over both thighs. He denies fever, chills, back pain, or diarrhea. His history includes mild intermittent asthma, recent camping in Vermont, and travel to Eastern Europe six months ago with bouts of diarrhea. He is sexually active with regular condom use and has no significant substance use history apart from occasional marijuana. On examination, his temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), blood pressure is 122/76 mm Hg, and pulse is 98/min. The abdomen is mildly tender without rebound. A stool occult blood test is positive, and skin changes are shown below. Laboratory studies reveal mild anemia, normal platelets, and elevated ESR. Urinalysis shows proteinuria and hematuria. Which of the following is most likely to establish this patient’s diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Skin biopsy

 

  • This patient’s presentation of abdominal pain, dark stools (suggestive of gastrointestinal bleeding), non-blanching purpuric rash, and evidence of mild kidney involvement (proteinuria, hematuria) is consistent with Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP), also known as IgA vasculitis. 
  • A skin biopsy of the purpuric lesions showing leukocytoclastic vasculitis with IgA deposition would confirm the diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abdominal imaging: While abdominal imaging may identify bowel wall thickening or intussusception associated with HSP, it is not diagnostic and cannot confirm the underlying vasculitis.

 

Option B. Autoantibody testing: Autoantibody testing (e.g., ANA, anti-dsDNA) is used for systemic autoimmune diseases like lupus, which is not suggested by this patient’s presentation. HSP is an IgA-mediated vasculitis, not associated with these autoantibodies.

 

Option C. Peripheral blood smear: A blood smear is helpful in cases of hemolysis or thrombocytopenia, neither of which is present in this patient. It does not contribute to the diagnosis of HSP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP) is an IgA-mediated small-vessel vasculitis characterized by a purpuric rash, abdominal pain, renal involvement, and arthralgia. A skin biopsy demonstrating leukocytoclastic vasculitis with IgA deposition confirms the diagnosis.

choices.text: Low effectiveness of the drug in chelating cardiac iron
Limited ability to chelate intracellular tissue iron
Insufficient excretion of the drug by the kidneys
Ineffective binding of dietary iron in the gastrointestinal tract

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman with beta-thalassemia major is being treated with Deferiprone for transfusion-associated iron overload. Despite her treatment, her physician notes persistent liver iron overload and considers adding a second chelator. Which of the following is the most likely reason for the incomplete efficacy of her current therapy?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Limited ability to chelate intracellular tissue iron

 

  • Deferiprone is an oral iron chelator that primarily binds free iron (Fe3+) in the plasma and extracellular fluid, facilitating its excretion in the urine. 
  • While Deferiprone is highly effective in reducing cardiac iron overload, its ability to chelate intracellular iron stored in tissues, such as the liver, is limited. 
  • This is because intracellular iron is bound to storage molecules like ferritin and hemosiderin, which are not directly targeted by Deferiprone.
  • In cases of significant hepatic iron overload, combination therapy with another chelator, such as Desferrioxamine, which has better penetration into intracellular compartments, may be required to achieve adequate iron reduction.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Low effectiveness of the drug in chelating cardiac iron: Incorrect. Deferiprone is particularly effective in reducing cardiac iron levels and is often preferred for managing iron-induced cardiomyopathy.

 

Option C. Insufficient excretion of the drug by the kidneys: Incorrect. Deferiprone and its iron complexes are excreted efficiently via the kidneys. The issue in this case is not drug excretion but the drug's limited ability to chelate intracellular iron.

 

Option D. Ineffective binding of dietary iron in the gastrointestinal tract: Incorrect. Dietary iron is not a significant contributor to iron overload in transfusion-dependent patients. The source of iron overload in such patients is from repeated transfusions, not dietary intake.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Deferiprone is effective at chelating free iron in plasma and extracellular fluid, with high efficacy in reducing cardiac iron. 
  • However, its limited ability to target intracellular iron stored in tissues like the liver necessitates combination therapy in patients with significant hepatic iron overload.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman is in her first trimester of pregnancy. On her anomaly scan, the fetus is found to have tricuspid valve insufficiency, atrialization of the right ventricle, and right atrial enlargement. Which of the following drugs is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lithium

 

  • Lithium use in pregnancy, especially during the first trimester, is associated with Ebstein anomaly, a congenital heart defect characterized by downward displacement of the tricuspid valve, resulting in right atrial enlargement and atrialization of the right ventricle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. ACE inhibitors: Associated with renal agenesis and hypoplasia, leading to oligohydramnios and organ hypoplasia, not cardiac anomalies like Ebstein anomaly.

 

Option C. Phenytoin: Associated with cardiac defects like VSD, ASD, and coarctation of the aorta but not Ebstein anomaly.

 

Option D. Topiramate: Associated with cleft lip and palate, not congenital heart defects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Lithium use in the first trimester is associated with Ebstein anomaly, a rare but severe congenital heart defect. Careful risk-benefit assessment and monitoring are crucial in pregnant women with bipolar disorder who require lithium therapy.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with a history of chronic nasal obstruction, crusting, and nasal deformity. The patient is diagnosed with rhinoscleroma. In which stage of rhinoscleroma is "tapir nose" most commonly observed?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cicatricial stage

 

  • The cicatricial stage of rhinoscleroma is characterized by fibrosis, leading to adhesions, nasal stenosis, and the classic "tapir nose" deformity. 
  • This stage is the final phase of rhinoscleroma following the granulomatous stage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atrophic stage: The atrophic stage involves purulent discharge and crusting due to tissue destruction but does not involve fibrosis or nasal deformity.

 

Option B. Granulomatous stage: The granulomatous stage is marked by the formation of painless subdermal nodules with a woody consistency ("woody nose" or Hebra nose), but "tapir nose" is not a feature of this stage.

 

Option D. Active inflammatory stage: This term is not part of the recognized stages of rhinoscleroma (atrophic, granulomatous, and cicatricial stages).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • "Tapir nose," a nasal deformity caused by fibrosis and stenosis, is a hallmark of the cicatricial stage of rhinoscleroma.

questions.text: A 35-year-old pregnant woman at 26 weeks of gestation presents with newly diagnosed gestational hypertension. She has no prior medical history and is otherwise asymptomatic. Blood pressure is 160/95 mm Hg, and a urinalysis shows no proteinuria. Which of the following medications is contraindicated in her treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Enalapril

 

  • Enalapril is an ACE inhibitor and is contraindicated in pregnancy due to its teratogenic effects, including renal dysgenesis, oligohydramnios, and fetal growth restriction. 
  • The preferred antihypertensives in pregnancy include labetalol, methyldopa, and nifedipine, as they are safe and effective.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Methyldopa: A centrally acting alpha-2 agonist and first-line agent for hypertension in pregnancy.

 

Option B. Labetalol: A combined alpha and beta-blocker safe for use in pregnancy.

 

Option D. Nifedipine: A calcium channel blocker commonly used for pregnancy-associated hypertension.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • ACE inhibitors and ARBs are contraindicated in pregnancy due to their teratogenic effects, whereas methyldopa, labetalol, and nifedipine are safe options.

choices.text: Radical vulvectomy with bilateral inguinofemoral lymph node dissection

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman is diagnosed with a 4-cm squamous cell carcinoma of the vulva that involves the urethral meatus. Her medical history includes systemic lupus erythematosus. What is the most appropriate treatment option for her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Radical vulvectomy with bilateral inguinofemoral lymph node dissection

 

  • The involvement of the urethral meatus with a 4-cm squamous cell carcinoma of the vulva indicates a locally advanced vulvar cancer.
  •  The standard treatment for such cases is radical vulvectomy with bilateral inguinofemoral lymph node dissection to remove the primary tumor and assess for lymph node metastases. 
  • This approach is curative and helps prevent regional spread of the disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pelvic exenteration: Pelvic exenteration involves the removal of multiple pelvic organs and is reserved for patients with recurrent or metastatic disease that has failed primary treatment. It is not indicated for initial management of vulvar cancer with urethral involvement.

 

Option B. Chemoradiation followed by radical vulvectomy: This approach may be used in cases where tumor reduction is required before surgery due to extensive local disease. However, for a resectable tumor involving the urethral meatus, upfront radical surgery is the standard.

 

Option C. Chemoradiation: Chemoradiation alone is used in non-surgical candidates or for palliation, but it is not considered curative for operable vulvar cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For locally advanced vulvar cancer involving the urethral meatus, the standard treatment is radical vulvectomy with bilateral inguinofemoral lymph node dissection to achieve local control and prevent metastasis.

choices.text: Branching septate hyphae on Gomori methenamine silver stain
Broad, ribbon-like aseptate hyphae on histopathology
Yeast cells with thick capsules on India ink preparation
Spherules filled with endospores on biopsy

questions.text: A 56-year-old patient undergoing chemotherapy for acute myeloid leukemia presents with fever, pleuritic chest pain, and hemoptysis. A CT scan of the chest shows a cavitating lesion in the right upper lobe with a surrounding halo sign. Serum galactomannan levels are elevated. Which of the following findings would be most consistent with the suspected diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Branching septate hyphae on Gomori methenamine silver stain

 

  • Elevated galactomannan is specific for Aspergillus infections. 
  • On histopathology, Aspergillus species are seen as branching septate hyphae at acute angles on Gomori methenamine silver stain.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Broad, ribbon-like aseptate hyphae on histopathology: This is characteristic of Mucor species, which are not associated with galactomannan.

 

Option C. Yeast cells with thick capsules on India ink preparation: This describes Cryptococcus neoformans, which does not produce galactomannan.

 

Option D. Spherules filled with endospores on biopsy: This is characteristic of Coccidioides spp., not Aspergillus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Galactomannan is specific for Aspergillus infections, which are identified histologically as branching septate hyphae on Gomori methenamine silver stain.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man with a history of HIV infection presents with progressive memory loss, difficulty concentrating, and gait disturbances over the past several months. MRI of the brain shows diffuse atrophy and hyperintense lesions in the white matter. A brain biopsy reveals perivascular lymphocytes and microglial nodules. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) HIV encephalitis

 

  • HIV encephalitis is a condition commonly seen in patients with advanced HIV infection or AIDS. 
  • It is characterized by perivascular lymphocytic infiltration and the formation of microglial nodules around small blood vessels in the central nervous system (CNS). 
  • These findings reflect the inflammatory response to HIV and are typically associated with cognitive decline and neurological symptoms like memory loss, confusion, and motor dysfunction. 
  • This pattern is considered pathognomonic for HIV-associated neurocognitive disorder (HAND).

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Multiple sclerosis: Incorrect. Multiple sclerosis (MS) is characterized by demyelinating plaques within the white matter of the CNS with perivascular cuffing of inflammatory cells. However, the typical histopathological findings in MS are not microglial nodules but rather perivenular inflammation and demyelination.

 

Option C. Bacterial meningitis: Incorrect. Bacterial meningitis presents with neutrophilic infiltration in the subarachnoid space, leading to pus and inflammation. Microglial nodules and perivascular lymphocytes are not characteristic of bacterial meningitis, which primarily shows acute inflammation rather than a chronic inflammatory pattern seen in HIV encephalitis.

 

Option D. CMV meningitis: Incorrect. CMV meningitis typically occurs in immunocompromised patients, such as those with HIV/AIDS. While CMV can cause inflammation in the brain, its hallmark features include owl-eye inclusions in infected cells and necrotizing ventriculoencephalitis rather than perivascular lymphocytic infiltrates and microglial nodules.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • HIV encephalitis is characterized by perivascular lymphocytic infiltrates and microglial nodules in the central nervous system. These histopathological findings are indicative of HIV-associated neurocognitive disorder (HAND), which can occur in advanced HIV/AIDS patients, presenting with cognitive decline and neurological deficits.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with second-degree burns is being treated with topical medications. After a few days, the patient develops signs of metabolic acidosis. The burn team suspects the topical cream as a potential cause. Which of these burns creams causes metabolic acidosis ?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mafenide acetate

 

  • Mafenide acetate is a topical antimicrobial agent commonly used in the treatment of burns. 
  • However, it is associated with metabolic acidosis because it inhibits carbonic anhydrase, leading to increased excretion of bicarbonate in the urine. 
  • This loss of bicarbonate can result in a metabolic acidosis in burn patients. 
  • Although effective against gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria, this side effect limits its use.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Silver nitrate: Silver nitrate is used for its broad-spectrum antibacterial properties in burn treatment, but it does not cause metabolic acidosis. Instead, it may cause electrolyte imbalances, such as hyponatremia and hypochloremia.

 

Option B. Silver sulphadiazine: Silver sulphadiazine is a commonly used burn cream with broad-spectrum antimicrobial coverage. It is generally well-tolerated and does not cause metabolic acidosis.
