Option D. Cerium nitrate: Cerium nitrate, used in combination with silver sulphadiazine, helps to form a sterile eschar on the burned area, but it is not associated with metabolic acidosis. It also helps reduce immunosuppression seen in burn patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Mafenide acetate is a topical burn treatment associated with metabolic acidosis due to its inhibition of carbonic anhydrase, which leads to the loss of bicarbonate.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with persistent hoarseness of voice for the past month. Laryngoscopic examination shows mild irregularity in vocal cord movement but no structural abnormalities. The physician explains that the vocal ligaments, which are critical for phonation, attach to the thyroid cartilage anteriorly at the anterior commissure via a specific ligament. Which ligament anchors the vocal processes to the thyroid cartilage at the anterior commissure?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Broyle's ligament

 

  • Broyle's ligament is the structure that anchors the vocal processes of the arytenoid cartilages to the thyroid cartilage at the anterior commissure. 
  • This attachment provides stability to the vocal cords and plays a vital role in their function during phonation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cricothyroid ligament: The cricothyroid ligament connects the cricoid cartilage to the thyroid cartilage and is not involved in the attachment of the vocal ligaments.

 

Option C. Thyrohyoid ligament: The thyrohyoid ligament connects the thyroid cartilage to the hyoid bone and does not play a role in the attachment of the vocal processes or vocal ligaments.

 

Option D. Vestibular ligament: The vestibular ligament forms the false vocal cords and is anatomically distinct from the true vocal ligaments. It does not attach at the anterior commissure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The vocal ligaments attach to the thyroid cartilage at the anterior commissure through Broyle's ligament, providing critical stability and function for the vocal cords.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman with symptomatic uterine fibroids is scheduled for surgery. During the procedure, the surgeon uses the instrument shown in the image. What procedure is this instrument most commonly used for?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Open myomectomy

 

  • The instrument shown in the image is a Bonney’s myomectomy clamp, which is primarily used in open myomectomy procedures.
  •  This clamp is designed to provide hemostasis by occluding blood vessels in the uterine tissue during the removal of fibroids (myomas). 
  • Myomectomy is a surgical procedure used to excise uterine fibroids while preserving the uterus, often performed in women who desire future fertility or want to avoid hysterectomy.
  •  The Bonney clamp allows the surgeon to control bleeding during the excision of fibroids, which is critical due to the high vascularity of the uterus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Laparoscopic hysterectomy: While laparoscopic instruments are used in hysterectomy, the Bonney’s myomectomy clamp is specifically designed for open procedures, not for use in laparoscopic surgeries.

 

Option B. Endometrial ablation: Endometrial ablation is a minimally invasive procedure used to remove or destroy the lining of the uterus to treat heavy menstrual bleeding. This procedure does not involve the use of a Bonney’s clamp, as it focuses on the endometrium rather than uterine fibroids.

 

Option D. Cervical biopsy: Cervical biopsies are small tissue samples taken from the cervix, typically during a colposcopy. A Bonney’s clamp is not needed for this procedure, which involves much smaller instruments.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Bonney’s myomectomy clamp is commonly used during an open myomectomy to control bleeding while removing uterine fibroids.

choices.text: Oocysts are immediately infective, leading to autoinfection
Sporulation of the oocysts occurs in soil, prolonging environmental exposure
Intracellular trophozoites evade the host immune system through antigenic variation
Sporozoites invade the colonic mucosa, causing extensive tissue destruction

questions.text: A 35-year-old HIV-positive man presents with severe watery diarrhea, abdominal cramping, and weight loss. Kinyoun stain of stool samples is showing cysts measuring 4-6 µm, as in the image below . Which of the following best explains the persistence of symptoms in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Oocysts are immediately infective, leading to autoinfection

 

  • In Cryptosporidium infections, oocysts are immediately infective upon excretion and can cause autoinfection, leading to persistent symptoms, especially in immunocompromised individuals like those with HIV.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sporulation of the oocysts occurs in soil, prolonging environmental exposure: This describes Cyclospora and Cystoisospora but not Cryptosporidium.

 

Option C. Intracellular trophozoites evade the host immune system through antigenic variation: Antigenic variation is not a known mechanism in Cryptosporidium infections.

 

Option D. Sporozoites invade the colonic mucosa, causing extensive tissue destruction: Cryptosporidium primarily infects the small intestinal epithelium and causes non-inflammatory diarrhea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cryptosporidium oocysts are immediately infective upon excretion and can cause autoinfection, leading to persistent diarrhea in immunocompromised hosts.

questions.text: A 30-year-old primigravida in active labor reports a frequent urge to pass urine and premature bearing down. On examination, there is infra-umbilical flattening, and fetal heart sounds are best auscultated on the lateral side. What is the most likely fetal presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Occipito-posterior

 

The occipito-posterior (OP) position is a fetal head presentation where the back of the fetal head (occiput) faces the maternal sacrum.

 

In this position:

 

  • The pregnant woman often feels a premature urge to bear down due to the increased pressure from the fetal head pressing against the rectum and bladder.
  • Infra-umbilical flattening is noted because the fetal back is aligned posteriorly.
  • Fetal heart sounds are auscultated laterally, often closer to the maternal flanks.
  • This position can result in prolonged labor due to suboptimal fetal positioning and is a common cause of back labor.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Right dorso-anterior: This is a type of breech presentation where the fetal back is anterior, and the heart sounds are typically heard in the upper abdomen. This presentation does not match the findings described, such as infra-umbilical flattening and the bearing-down sensation.

 

Option C. Brow presentation: In brow presentation, the largest diameter of the fetal head presents, making vaginal delivery difficult or impossible. It is associated with a high station, slow labor, and no characteristic lateral fetal heart auscultation.

 

Option D. Knee presentation: A knee presentation is a rare type of breech where the knees are the presenting part. Fetal heart sounds in breech presentations are usually heard above the umbilicus, not laterally.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Occipito-posterior position of the fetus during labor is characterized by lateral fetal heart sound auscultation, infra-umbilical flattening, and an increased urge to push due to the fetal head pressing on the maternal bladder and rectum

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with a previous lower segment cesarean section is admitted for evaluation of labor induction at 39 weeks of gestation. Which of the following methods for labor induction is contraindicated in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Prostaglandin tablet

 

  • In patients with a history of a previous cesarean section, the use of prostaglandins (gel or tablet) for labor induction is contraindicated due to the increased risk of uterine rupture. 
  • Prostaglandins cause strong uterine contractions, which can exert excessive pressure on the scar from the previous cesarean section, leading to rupture. 
  • Safer alternatives, such as oxytocin and mechanical methods (e.g., Foley catheter), are typically preferred in patients with a history of uterine surgery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oxytocin drip: Oxytocin can be used for labor induction in women with a history of cesarean section, but it must be administered carefully under close monitoring to avoid hyperstimulation of the uterus.

 

Option C. Membrane stripping: Membrane stripping involves mechanical separation of the membranes from the uterine wall to release natural prostaglandins and promote labor. It is generally safe for patients with a previous cesarean section as it is less aggressive.

 

Option D. Foley catheter placement: A Foley catheter is a mechanical method of cervical ripening and is considered safe in patients with a prior cesarean section. It works by dilating the cervix without inducing strong contractions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In women with a history of cesarean section, the use of prostaglandins for labor induction is contraindicated due to the increased risk of uterine rupture.
  •  Safer alternatives include oxytocin and mechanical methods.

choices.text: Most common type of stone in infected urine is triple phosphate
Stones > 5 mm can be managed conservatively with pharmacotherapy
Soft stones can’t be removed by ESWL
Uric acid stones are seen on X ray KUB

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with a history of recurrent episodes of renal colic. Imaging studies reveal the presence of renal stones. The physician explains the possible types of renal stones and their management. Which of the following statements regarding renal stones is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Most common type of stone in infected urine is triple phosphate

 

  • The most common type of kidney stones are calcium oxalate stones. However, triple phosphate stones, also known as struvite or staghorn calculi, are associated with infections caused by urease-producing bacteria, like Proteus mirabilis. 
  • These stones form in an alkaline urine environment. On the other hand, calcium oxalate stones can form in various pH conditions and are by far the most common.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Stone > 5 mm can be managed conservatively with pharmacotherapy:  This is false, as small stones (<5 mm) are expected to pass naturally, such as those under 5 mm in diameter. Various medications can aid in stone passage or dissolve specific types of stones.

 

Option C.  Soft stones can’t be removed by ESWL: Extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy (ESWL) is effective for breaking down soft stones, particularly those under 2 cm in size, allowing them to pass more easily.

 

Option D. Uric acid stones are seen on X ray KUB: This is incorrect, As they are radiolucent

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The most common type of renal stones in infected urine are triple phosphate (struvite) stones.

choices.text: Ventral rami of S1 and S2

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with chronic hip pain and difficulty with external rotation of the thigh. Neurological testing suggests an injury affecting the inferior gemellus muscle. Which nerve is responsible for innervating this muscle?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nerve to quadratus femoris

 

  • The inferior gemellus muscle is one of the lateral rotators of the hip joint. 
  • It functions alongside the quadratus femoris and is innervated by the nerve to quadratus femoris (L4, L5, S1). 
  • This nerve supplies both the quadratus femoris and the inferior gemellus muscles.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nerve to obturator internus: This nerve supplies the obturator internus and superior gemellus muscles, not the inferior gemellus.

 

Option C. Nerve to obturator externus: The obturator externus is innervated by the posterior branch of the obturator nerve (L2–L4), not the nerve to quadratus femoris.

 

Option D. Ventral rami of S1 and S2: The ventral rami of S1 and S2 contribute to the nerve to piriformis and the sciatic nerve, but they do not innervate the inferior gemellus directly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The inferior gemellus muscle is innervated by the nerve to quadratus femoris (L4, L5, S1). 
  • Recognizing the innervation of the muscles involved in hip rotation helps in localizing neuromuscular injuries during clinical assessment.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to the clinic with chronic wrist pain and reduced range of motion in her forearm. She has a history of wrist deformity since childhood, which has progressively worsened. An X-ray of her forearm is obtained, as shown below. What is the most likely deformity identified in this X-ray?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Madelung deformity

 

  • Madelung deformity is a congenital wrist abnormality caused by defective growth of the distal radius, leading to abnormal alignment of the wrist. 
  • It is characterized by shortening and bowing of the radius, increased volar tilt, and dislocation or subluxation of the ulnar head. 
  • The hand appears deviated toward the ulnar side, and there is often a prominent distal ulna. 
  • The deformity typically presents during adolescence but can worsen with age, as shown in this X-ray.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Garden spade deformity: This deformity is associated with Smith's fracture, where the distal fragment of the radius is displaced volarly (toward the palm), causing a deformity resembling a garden spade. This is a post-traumatic deformity, not a congenital or developmental issue like Madelung deformity.

 

Option B. Swan neck deformity: Swan neck deformity is a condition involving the fingers, not the wrist. It presents with hyperextension of the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints and flexion of the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joints, commonly seen in rheumatoid arthritis or connective tissue disorders.

 

Option D. Dinner fork deformity: The dinner fork deformity is seen in Colles' fracture, a fracture of the distal radius with dorsal displacement of the distal fragment, giving the wrist a shape resembling an inverted dinner fork. It is typically seen after a fall on an outstretched hand and does not resemble the congenital bowing and shortening seen in Madelung deformity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Madelung deformity is a congenital growth disturbance of the distal radius, leading to ulnar deviation of the wrist and bowing of the forearm. X-rays typically show radial shortening, increased volar tilt, and subluxation of the distal ulna.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes can utilize both NAD⁺ and NADP⁺ as cofactors?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Glutamate dehydrogenase

 

  • Glutamate dehydrogenase catalyzes the reversible reaction that converts glutamate to α-ketoglutarate and releases ammonia. 
  • This enzyme can utilize both NAD⁺ (for oxidative deamination) and NADP⁺ (for reductive amination), making it unique among dehydrogenases. 
  • This dual cofactor usage allows the enzyme to participate in both catabolic and anabolic processes, depending on the energy requirements of the cell.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Isocitrate dehydrogenase: This enzyme catalyzes the conversion of isocitrate to α-ketoglutarate in the TCA cycle and can use either NAD⁺ or NADP⁺, but this specificity depends on the isoform. The mitochondrial TCA cycle isoform strictly uses NAD⁺, not both interchangeably like glutamate dehydrogenase.

 

Option B. Lactate dehydrogenase: Lactate dehydrogenase catalyzes the interconversion of pyruvate and lactate using NAD⁺ as a cofactor. It does not utilize NADP⁺.

 

Option D. Pyruvate dehydrogenase: Pyruvate dehydrogenase catalyzes the conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA and specifically requires NAD⁺ as a cofactor. It does not use NADP⁺ in its reactions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Glutamate dehydrogenase is unique in its ability to use both NAD⁺ and NADP⁺ as cofactors, playing an important role in nitrogen metabolism and maintaining the balance between catabolism and anabolism.

choices.text: Add a potassium-binding agent to the treatment regimen
Discontinue eplerenone and re-evaluate renal function
Continue eplerenone with dietary potassium restriction

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman with resistant hypertension is prescribed eplerenone. One month later, she presents for follow-up, and her laboratory results show potassium of 5.8 mEq/L and a creatinine of 1.4 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most appropriate management strategy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Discontinue eplerenone and re-evaluate renal function

 

  • Eplerenone, like spironolactone, can cause hyperkalemia, especially in patients with declining renal function. 
  • Elevated potassium levels and rising creatinine indicate worsening renal function.
  • Discontinuing eplerenone and re-evaluating renal function is necessary to prevent further complications, including life-threatening hyperkalemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Discontinue eplerenone and initiate spironolactone: Spironolactone has a similar risk of hyperkalemia and would not be appropriate.

 

Option B. Add a potassium-binding agent to the treatment regimen: This may temporarily lower potassium but does not address the underlying renal dysfunction.

 

Option D. Continue eplerenone with dietary potassium restriction: This is insufficient for managing the severity of hyperkalemia and worsening renal function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hyperkalemia is a significant adverse effect of aldosterone antagonists, particularly in patients with impaired renal function. 
  • Discontinuation and reassessment of renal function are essential in such cases.

questions.text:
Mr. Sinha, 76-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with 6 hours of shortness of breath and chest pain. On arrival, his blood pressure is 102/72 mm Hg, pulse is 102/min, and oxygen saturation is 82% on 15 litres of oxygen via face mask. Bilateral rales are heard over the lower to middle lung fields. His ECG reveals sinus tachycardia and a left bundle branch block. He undergoes successful percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) for an occluded proximal left anterior descending artery, with restoration of coronary flow. A pulmonary artery catheter is placed for hemodynamic monitoring. Six hours after the procedure, his blood pressure drops to 78/48 mm Hg, and his pulse is 120/min and regular. Hemodynamic readings from the pulmonary artery catheter are as follows:

 

  • Right atrial pressure: 10 mm Hg
  • Right ventricular pressure: 36/15 mm Hg
  • Pulmonary artery pressure: 42/18 mm Hg
  • Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure: 24 mm Hg
  • Cardiac index: 1.5 L/min/m²
  • Systemic vascular resistance: 1365 dynes/sec/cm⁵

 

Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s hypotension?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cardiogenic shock

 

  • Cardiogenic shock is characterized by low cardiac output, elevated filling pressures (pulmonary capillary wedge pressure >18 mm Hg), and increased systemic vascular resistance due to compensatory vasoconstriction. 
  • In this patient, the hemodynamic findings (elevated pulmonary capillary wedge pressure, low cardiac index, and high systemic vascular resistance) are consistent with pump failure caused by extensive myocardial infarction, leading to cardiogenic shock.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Early sepsis: Early sepsis causes hypotension with low systemic vascular resistance (vasodilation) and high cardiac output (hyperdynamic circulation). This patient’s elevated systemic vascular resistance and low cardiac index are inconsistent with septic shock.

 

Option C. Hypovolemia: Hypovolemia typically leads to low right atrial pressure, pulmonary capillary wedge pressure, and cardiac index. This patient has elevated filling pressures, ruling out hypovolemia as the cause of hypotension.

 

Option D. Pericardial tamponade: Pericardial tamponade presents with equalization of intracardiac pressures, including right atrial, right ventricular diastolic, and pulmonary capillary wedge pressures, which is not seen in this patient. His hemodynamic findings are more consistent with cardiogenic shock.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cardiogenic shock is a severe complication of acute myocardial infarction, characterized by elevated filling pressures, reduced cardiac output, and compensatory vasoconstriction. 
  • Early recognition and management with inotropes or mechanical support are critical to improve outcomes.

choices.text: It cannot be offered in pregnancy
Axillary lymph node clearance is mandatory
A margin of 1 cm grossly is targeted during excision of tumor
Prior chest radiation is a contra-indication

questions.text: Which of these is not true about breast conservation therapy for malignancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Axillary lymph node clearance is mandatory

 

  • Axillary lymph node clearance is not always mandatory in breast conservation therapy. 
  • Sentinel lymph node biopsy is often preferred to assess the status of the axilla. 
  • Axillary lymph node dissection is only performed if sentinel node biopsy is positive for metastasis, reducing the risk of complications such as lymphedema.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It cannot be offered in pregnancy: This is correct. Breast conservation therapy typically involves radiation therapy postoperatively, which is contraindicated during pregnancy due to the potential harm to the fetus. Mastectomy is generally preferred in pregnant patients.

 

Option C. A margin of 1 cm grossly is targeted during excision of tumor: This is correct. During BCT, a gross margin of approximately 1 cm around the tumor is targeted to ensure complete removal of the malignancy while preserving as much normal breast tissue as possible.

 

Option D. Prior chest radiation is a contraindication: This is correct. Prior chest radiation is a contraindication for BCT because additional radiation therapy, which is a critical component of BCT, increases the risk of significant complications and toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Breast conservation therapy is a viable option for many patients with breast cancer, but it requires careful consideration of factors such as prior radiation exposure, the need for postoperative radiation, and axillary node involvement. 
  • Sentinel lymph node biopsy, rather than routine axillary clearance, is the standard for axillary evaluation in BCT.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents to the clinic with a noticeable bulge in his upper arm after hearing a "pop" while lifting a heavy object. He reports weakness in elbow flexion but minimal pain. On physical examination, there is a prominent bulge in the mid-arm ("Popeye sign"). Which tendon rupture is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Long head of biceps tendon

 

  • The "Popeye sign" occurs due to a rupture of the long head of the biceps tendon.
  • This tendon typically tears at its proximal attachment near the supraglenoid tubercle of the scapula. 
  • When the tendon ruptures, the muscle belly retracts distally, forming a prominent bulge in the upper arm, resembling "Popeye’s" flexed bicep. 
  • This rupture commonly occurs due to chronic degenerative changes, particularly in older individuals or during heavy lifting.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Proximal tendon of biceps: The proximal biceps tendon has two heads (long and short). The rupture of the short head is very rare and does not produce the Popeye sign.

 

Option C. Brachialis tendon: The brachialis muscle inserts on the ulna and plays a role in elbow flexion. Its rupture does not cause a mid-arm bulge but may lead to weak elbow flexion.

 

Option D. Distal tendon of biceps: The rupture of the distal biceps tendon at its insertion in the radial tuberosity results in a bulge higher in the arm and significantly weakens forearm supination rather than causing the Popeye deformity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The long head of the biceps tendon is the most common tendon to rupture and causes a "Popeye sign" due to retraction of the biceps muscle belly. 
  • It typically presents with a noticeable bulge and mild weakness in flexion and supination.

choices.text: IgG intercellular "FISH NET staining in pemphigus
Linear IgA deposition along the basement membrane in bullous pemphigoid
Granular IgA deposits in the dermal papillae of dermatitis herpetiformis

questions.text: A 40-year-old adult presents with blisters on both the skin and mucous membranes. To differentiate among various blistering disorders, direct immunofluorescence (DIF) studies are ordered. Which of the following DIF findings is not typically associated with the suspected condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Linear IgA deposition along the basement membrane in bullous pemphigoid

 

  • Direct immunofluorescence (DIF) is a pivotal diagnostic tool in distinguishing various blistering skin diseases by identifying specific patterns of immunoglobulin and complement deposition. 
  • Bullous pemphigoid is primarily characterized by linear deposits of IgG and/or C3 along the basement membrane zone (BMZ) on DIF. 
  • The presence of linear IgA deposition is not a feature of bullous pemphigoid; instead, it is indicative of linear IgA disease, a distinct blistering disorder. 
  • Therefore, the statement that bullous pemphigoid exhibits linear IgA deposition is false.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Negative immunofluorescence in Hailey-Hailey disease: Hailey-Hailey disease, also known as benign familial pemphigus, is a genetic disorder caused by mutations in the ATP2C1 gene. It does not involve the formation of autoantibodies, resulting in negative findings on direct immunofluorescence studies.

 

Option B. IgG intercellular "Fish net" staining in pemphigus: Pemphigus vulgaris and pemphigus foliaceus are autoimmune conditions where IgG autoantibodies target desmosomal proteins, leading to acantholysis. DIF in pemphigus typically shows IgG deposits in an intercellular, "net-like" or "fishnet" pattern within the epidermis.

 

Option D. Granular IgA deposits in the dermal papillae of dermatitis herpetiformis: Dermatitis herpetiformis is associated with celiac disease and is characterized by granular deposits of IgA in the dermal papillae on DIF. This pattern is a key diagnostic feature distinguishing it from other blistering disorders.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pemphigus: Displays IgG in an intercellular "net-like" pattern.
  • Bullous Pemphigoid: Shows linear IgG and/or C3 along the basement membrane zone.
  • Dermatitis Herpetiformis: Exhibits granular IgA deposits in the dermal papillae.
  • Hailey-Hailey Disease: Presents negative findings on direct immunofluorescence

choices.text: Increasing the availability of advanced medical care
Promoting the use of contraception and family planning
Improving economic opportunities in rural areas
Expanding immunization coverage for childhood diseases

questions.text: Which of the following interventions would be most effective in helping a country escape a demographic trap?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Promoting the use of contraception and family planning

 

  • Demographic trap: Applies to a country whose population is growing rapidly due to a high birth rate and low death rate. 
  • To escape the demographic trap, countries need to lower fertility rates. 
  • Promoting family planning and contraception reduces birth rates, helping to stabilize population growth and reduce pressure on resources.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increasing the availability of advanced medical care: This reduces death rates further but does not address high fertility rates.

 

Option C. Improving economic opportunities in rural areas: This may have an indirect effect but does not directly address high fertility.

 

Option D. Expanding immunization coverage for childhood diseases: This primarily reduces child mortality and death rates, exacerbating the demographic trap if fertility rates remain high.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Promoting family planning and contraception is the most effective intervention to escape the demographic trap by reducing high fertility rates.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents to the clinic with complaints of recurrent epistaxis and easy bruising. Laboratory tests show a prolonged bleeding time but normal platelet count. A peripheral blood smear shows large platelets. A platelet aggregation study reveals an abnormal response to ristocetin but a normal response to ADP and collagen. Which of the following deficiencies is most likely causing her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glycoprotein Ib/IX

 

  • Bernard-Soulier syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a deficiency of glycoprotein (Gp) Ib/IX, which is necessary for platelet adhesion to von Willebrand factor (vWF) at sites of endothelial injury. 
  • Without Gp Ib/IX, platelets cannot properly bind to the subendothelial vWF, leading to impaired platelet plug formation and prolonged bleeding time.
  • A hallmark finding is large platelets on a peripheral smear due to dysfunctional platelet production.
  • The abnormal ristocetin-induced aggregation test (which depends on Gp Ib/IX binding to vWF) further supports the diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glycoprotein IIb/IIIa: This glycoprotein complex is involved in platelet-platelet aggregation by binding fibrinogen. Its deficiency leads to Glanzmann thrombasthenia, which presents with abnormal aggregation to ADP, collagen, and thrombin, but normal ristocetin aggregation.

 

Option C. Von Willebrand factor (vWF): Deficiency or dysfunction of vWF causes von Willebrand disease, characterized by defective platelet adhesion. Unlike Bernard-Soulier syndrome, von Willebrand disease presents with normal platelet size and often involves reduced levels of factor VIII (since vWF stabilizes factor VIII).

 

Option D. Factor VIII: Deficiency of factor VIII results in hemophilia A, which presents with normal bleeding time (platelet function is intact) but prolonged partial thromboplastin time (PTT) due to impaired intrinsic coagulation. Hemarthrosis and deep tissue bleeding are common presentations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Bernard-Soulier syndrome is caused by a deficiency of glycoprotein Ib/IX, which plays a critical role in platelet adhesion to von Willebrand factor. 
  • It is characterized by large platelets, prolonged bleeding time, and defective platelet aggregation in response to ristocetin.

questions.text: Despite being a major producer of ketone bodies, the liver is unable to utilize them for energy. This inability is due to the absence of which of the following enzymes?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Thiophorase

 

  • Thiophorase (succinyl-CoA: acetoacetate CoA transferase) is the enzyme required to convert acetoacetate (a ketone body) into acetoacetyl-CoA, an intermediate that can enter the TCA cycle for energy production. 
  • The liver lacks thiophorase, which prevents it from metabolizing the ketone bodies it produces. 
  • This ensures that ketone bodies synthesized by the liver are released into the bloodstream to supply peripheral tissues, such as the brain and muscles, during prolonged fasting or insulin deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carnitine palmitoyltransferase I: This enzyme is involved in fatty acid transport into mitochondria for β-oxidation, not in ketone body utilization.

 

Option B. HMG-CoA synthase: HMG-CoA synthase catalyzes the synthesis of HMG-CoA, a crucial intermediate in the production of ketone bodies. However, its role is in the generation of ketone bodies, not their utilization.

 

Option C. Thiolase: Thiolase catalyzes the conversion of acetyl-CoA to acetoacetyl-CoA, an early step in ketogenesis. While important for ketone body production, it is not required for ketone body utilization.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The liver cannot utilize ketone bodies because it lacks thiophorase (succinyl-CoA: acetoacetate CoA transferase), the enzyme necessary for converting acetoacetate into acetoacetyl-CoA for energy production. 
  • This ensures that ketone bodies are available for peripheral tissues during periods of energy deprivation.

questions.text: A patient receiving a new medication reports worsening symptoms, which the physician attributes to a psychodynamic effect rather than the drug itself. Which of the following terms best explains this phenomenon?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nocebo effect

 

  • The nocebo effect refers to a negative psychodynamic response in a patient due to pessimistic expectations about the treatment.
  • It occurs without any pharmacological basis and is often influenced by the patient’s attitudes or beliefs about the drug or healthcare providers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Placebo effect: The placebo effect involves positive psychodynamic responses, not negative effects.

 

Option C. Excipient toxicity: Excipients are pharmacologically inert and typically do not cause toxicity unless there is an allergy or hypersensitivity.

 

Option D. Drug intolerance: Intolerance refers to adverse pharmacological reactions to a drug, not psychodynamic effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The nocebo effect represents a negative psychological response to treatment, emphasizing the importance of addressing patient perceptions and expectations in clinical practice.

questions.text: Match the following disinfectant tests in Column A with their corresponding key features in Column B:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-C, 2-A, 3-D, 4-B

 

  • 1-C. Rideal Walker test:  The Rideal Walker test evaluates the efficacy of a disinfectant compared to phenol under standardized conditions. It calculates the phenol coefficient, which is the ratio of the dilution of the disinfectant to that of phenol required to sterilize Salmonella Typhi. Tests disinfectant efficacy compared to phenol under standardized conditions.
  • 2-A. Chick Martin test: The Chick Martin test is a modification of the Rideal Walker test that simulates real-world conditions by assessing the disinfectant's efficacy in the presence of organic matter (e.g., dried yeast, feces). This test reflects the natural environment in which disinfectants are used. Determines disinfectant's efficacy in the presence of organic matter.
  • 3-D. Capacity test (Kelsey-Sykes): The Capacity test evaluates a disinfectant’s ability to retain its activity under repeated microbiological loading. This is particularly important for disinfectants used frequently in high-load environments, such as hospitals. Assesses disinfectant's activity under repeated microbiological loading.
  • 4-B. In-use test (Kelsey and Maurer): The In-use test determines whether a disinfectant solution actively used in clinical settings has become microbiologically contaminated. This test ensures the safety and sterility of disinfectants in hospitals and is recommended every three months. Evaluates microbiological contamination of actively used disinfectants in hospitals.

 

Educational Objective:


Understand the specific purpose and limitations of various disinfectant testing methods:

 

  • The Rideal Walker test is a standardized method comparing disinfectants to phenol.
  • The Chick Martin test includes organic matter to simulate real-world conditions.
  • The Capacity test assesses disinfectant efficacy under repeated microbial load.
  • The In-use test detects contamination in actively used disinfectant solutions.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with anterior neck pain, fatigue, and fever. On physical examination, her thyroid gland is tender to palpation. Laboratory tests reveal an elevated ESR, elevated T4, and suppressed TSH. A radioactive iodine uptake (RAIU) test shows decreased iodine uptake. Which of the following findings is most consistent with this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Multinucleated giant cells and granulomas

 

  • The described condition is sub-acute granulomatous thyroiditis.
  • Sub-acute granulomatous thyroiditis, also known as De Quervain thyroiditis, is an inflammatory thyroid condition, often triggered by a viral infection. It presents with:
    • Painful, tender thyroid gland
    • Systemic symptoms such as fever and malaise
    • Elevated ESR and transient thyrotoxicosis due to thyroid follicle damage Histopathological findings include multinucleated giant cells surrounding granulomas and disrupted follicles. Decreased radioactive iodine uptake occurs due to reduced synthesis despite leakage of stored hormones.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diffuse lymphocytic infiltration: Characteristic of Hashimoto’s thyroiditis, a chronic autoimmune disorder leading to hypothyroidism. The gland is firm, but not tender.

 

Option B. Hurthle cell metaplasia: Refers to eosinophilic changes in follicular cells, commonly seen in Hashimoto’s thyroiditis, but not in sub-acute thyroiditis.

 

Option D. Fibrous replacement of thyroid tissue: Seen in Riedel thyroiditis, where extensive fibrosis replaces normal thyroid tissue, causing a "rock-hard," painless gland.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sub-acute granulomatous thyroiditis is characterized by tender thyroid gland, elevated ESR, decreased RAIU, and multinucleated giant cells with granulomas on histology, typically following a viral upper respiratory infection.

choices.text: Repair of double-strand breaks by error-prone homologous recombination
Removal of mismatched bases from the 3′-end of Okazaki fragments by a methyl-directed process
Removal of pyrimidine dimers from DNA by nucleotide excision repair
Removal of uracil from DNA by base excision repair

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl is brought by her parents to the dermatologist. She has many freckles on her face, neck, arms, and hands, and the parents report that she is unusually sensitive to sunlight. Two basal cell carcinomas are identified on her face. Based on the clinical presentation, which of the following processes is most likely to be defective in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Removal of pyrimidine dimers from DNA by nucleotide excision repair

 

  • This clinical presentation is characteristic of xeroderma pigmentosum (XP), a rare autosomal recessive disorder caused by defective nucleotide excision repair (NER). 
  • This repair mechanism is responsible for removing DNA lesions caused by UV-induced damage, particularly pyrimidine dimers (covalent linkages between adjacent pyrimidine bases such as thymine and cytosine).
  • Patients with XP are hypersensitive to UV radiation and prone to developing multiple skin cancers (basal cell carcinoma, squamous cell carcinoma, and melanoma) at a young age due to the accumulation of unrepaired DNA damage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Repair of double-strand breaks by error-prone homologous recombination: This describes a repair process involved in fixing double-strand breaks in DNA. Defects in homologous recombination are associated with conditions like BRCA mutations, which lead to breast and ovarian cancers. However, this mechanism is not involved in repairing UV-induced DNA damage.

 

Option B. Removal of mismatched bases from the 3′-end of Okazaki fragments by a methyl-directed process: This describes mismatch repair (MMR), which corrects errors introduced during DNA replication. Mutations in MMR genes (e.g., MLH1, MSH2) are associated with Lynch syndrome, but MMR does not play a role in UV-induced pyrimidine dimer repair.

 

Option D. Removal of uracil from DNA by base excision repair: This describes base excision repair (BER), which corrects small, non-helical-distorting base lesions such as deaminated cytosine (uracil). BER is involved in fixing endogenous DNA damage but not in the removal of UV-induced pyrimidine dimers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Xeroderma pigmentosum (XP) is caused by a defect in nucleotide excision repair (NER), which removes UV-induced pyrimidine dimers from DNA. 
  • Patients with XP are extremely sensitive to sunlight and are at high risk for early-onset skin cancers.

choices.text: Provide oxygen via nasal cannula and monitor

questions.text: A 34-year-old male is brought to the emergency department by his friends after being found unconscious. His friends report that he had been using heroin earlier in the day. On examination, the patient is unresponsive, his respiratory rate is 6 breaths per minute, pupils are pinpoint, and his oxygen saturation is 85% on room air. What is the most appropriate immediate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Administer intravenous naloxone

 

  • The patient presents with symptoms of opioid overdose, characterized by unresponsiveness, respiratory depression (respiratory rate of 6 breaths/min), pinpoint pupils, and low oxygen saturation (85%). 
  • The most appropriate immediate management is the administration of naloxone, an opioid receptor antagonist that rapidly reverses opioid-induced respiratory depression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation: While intubation may be required in severe cases where naloxone is ineffective, it is not the initial management. Naloxone should be administered first, as it can rapidly improve respiratory effort and prevent the need for intubation.

 

 Option C. Start intravenous fluids and observe: IV fluids do not address the respiratory depression caused by opioid overdose and are not the primary treatment in this case.

 

Option D. Provide oxygen via nasal cannula and monitor: While supplemental oxygen is important to correct hypoxemia, it does not address the underlying cause (opioid-induced respiratory depression). Naloxone remains the priority intervention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The opioids are lethal in overdose.

 

 

The drug of choice for treatment of opioid overdose is i.v. naloxone (short-acting opioid antagonist).

questions.text: A child is born with sensorineural hearing loss, salt-and-pepper retinopathy, and congenital heart defects, including patent ductus arteriosus. Which of the following is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rubella

 

Rubella is associated with sensorineural hearing loss, salt-and-pepper retinopathy, cataracts, and congenital heart defects, especially patent ductus arteriosus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Varicella zoster virus: Associated with limb hypoplasia and cicatricial skin lesions.

 

Option C. Zika virus: Associated with microcephaly and subcortical calcifications, not cardiac defects.

 

Option D. Cytomegalovirus (CMV): Commonly causes periventricular calcifications and microcephaly, not congenital heart defects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Congenital rubella syndrome presents with sensorineural hearing loss, salt-and-pepper retinopathy, and congenital heart defects like patent ductus arteriosus. Prevention via maternal vaccination is critical.

choices.text: Posterior chamber fixation through zonular support, ideal for aphakia with intact posterior capsule
Scleral fixation with trans-scleral sutures, ideal for patients with corneal scarring
Iris claw fixation with anterior chamber placement, ideal for aphakia with deficient capsular support
Anterior chamber fixation with angle-supported lens, contraindicated in patients with glaucoma

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with a history of complicated cataract surgery presents for evaluation of a dislocated posterior chamber intraocular lens (PCIOL). Examination reveals significant visual impairment due to malpositioned lens fragments. The patient is planned for implantation of the intraocular lens shown in the image. Which of the following best describes the mechanism and indication for this type of lens?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Iris claw fixation with anterior chamber placement, ideal for aphakia with deficient capsular support

 

  • The image shows an iris claw lens (Singh and Worst's lens), which is designed for fixation to the iris in cases of aphakia where there is inadequate capsular or zonular support. 
  • The lens is attached to the anterior or posterior surface of the iris using claw-like extensions, providing stable positioning without the need for scleral sutures. 
  • This lens is typically used when the posterior capsule is deficient, as in cases of complicated cataract surgery or trauma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Posterior chamber fixation through zonular support, ideal for aphakia with intact posterior capsule: Posterior chamber fixation is not applicable here because the iris claw lens is not supported by the zonules or posterior capsule.

 

Option B. Scleral fixation with trans-scleral sutures, ideal for patients with corneal scarring: Scleral fixation lenses are attached using sutures passed through the sclera and are not claw lenses.

 

Option D. Anterior chamber fixation with angle-supported lens, contraindicated in patients with glaucoma: Anterior chamber angle-supported lenses rest in the iridocorneal angle and are not the same as iris claw lenses. These lenses are contraindicated in patients with glaucoma or corneal endothelial compromise.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Iris claw lenses are designed for anterior or posterior fixation to the iris in patients with aphakia and deficient capsular support. 
  • They offer a safe and effective alternative to scleral-fixated or angle-supported lenses in appropriate cases.

choices.text: Hemagglutinin binding to sialic acid receptors on host cells
Lipid envelope derived from host cell membranes

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with lethargy and vomiting a week after recovering from influenza. A nasopharyngeal swab confirms the presence of influenza A virus. What is the primary structural feature of this virus that enables its association with secondary syndromes such as Reye’s syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Segmented RNA genome allowing reassortment

 

  • Influenza A virus has a segmented RNA genome, which allows for genetic reassortment. 
  • While this characteristic does not directly cause Reye’s syndrome, it contributes to the virus's ability to evade immunity and remain a significant public health problem, leading to widespread aspirin use in children with influenza in the past.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Neuraminidase activity facilitating viral release: While this is essential for viral replication and spread, it is not directly linked to Reye’s syndrome.

 

Option C. Hemagglutinin binding to sialic acid receptors on host cells: This is critical for initial infection but does not explain the virus's association with Reye’s syndrome.

 

Option D. Lipid envelope derived from host cell membranes: While the lipid envelope helps the virus evade immune detection, it is not directly linked to Reye’s syndrome pathogenesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The segmented RNA genome of influenza allows for genetic reassortment, contributing to its epidemiological significance and historical association with Reye’s syndrome in children treated with aspirin.

questions.text: A 10-year- old male patient presented with an elbow deformity. He had an associated h/o traumatic fracture around the elbow 3 years ago which was managed by plaster cast application. The most common cause of the elbow deformity shown in the picture below is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mal-United Supracondylar Humerus Fracture

 

  • A supracondylar humerus fracture is a common injury in children, typically occurring from a fall onto an outstretched hand. These fractures can be classified as Type I (non-displaced), Type II (displaced with intact posterior cortex), and Type III (completely displaced).
  • A mal union occurs when the fractured bone heals in an incorrect position. In the case of a supracondylar humerus fracture, mal-union may lead to an elbow deformity such as cubitus varus (inward angulation) or cubitus valgus (outward angulation), depending on the direction of the mal-alignment.
  • A mal-united supracondylar fracture can result in significant elbow deformity and functional limitations. This deformity often becomes noticeable during childhood as the child grows.
  • Cubitus varus is the most common deformity resulting from mal-united supracondylar fractures.
  • Treatment may involve surgical intervention to correct the alignment and improve function.
  • Most common cause of elbow deformity in children after a supracondylar fracture is mal union, especially when improperly treated or inadequately realigned after the fracture heals.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Non-Union Supracondylar Fracture:

 

  • Non-union occurs when a fractured bone fails to heal within an expected time frame. A non-union supracondylar fracture means that the bone fragments do not join together properly.
  • Non-union of a supracondylar fracture is less common than mal-union and often requires surgical intervention such as bone grafting or internal fixation.
  • While non-union may result in elbow dysfunction, it does not usually lead to a deformity such as cubitus varus or valgus directly. The deformity caused by non-union is more likely to be due to instability or dysfunction in the elbow rather than bone alignment issues.
  • Non-union does not typically cause the common deformity seen in this clinical context. Therefore, it is less likely to be the cause of the deformity in this patient.

 

Option C. Mal-United Lateral Condyle Humerus Fracture:

 

  • A lateral condyle humerus fracture occurs when there is a fracture of the distal humerus at the lateral epicondyle, often involving the growth plate (physis) in children.
  • A mal union of a lateral condyle fracture can lead to deformities or growth disturbances in the elbow joint.
  • Mal-union of a lateral condyle fracture can cause issues such as angular deformity and elbow instability, but it is less common than mal-union following a supracondylar fracture.
  • The lateral condyle fractures are more likely to affect the joint surface and lead to problems with joint movement, rather than producing the more typical cubitus varus or valgus seen with mal-united supracondylar fractures.

 

Option D. Non-Union Lateral Condyle Humerus Fracture:

 

  • Like non-union supracondylar fractures, a non-union lateral condyle fracture refers to when the bone fragments fail to heal properly.
  • Non-union of a lateral condyle fracture can result in functional impairment, as the distal humerus might fail to grow normally, and there can be elbow instability or limitation in range of motion.
  • A non-union of a lateral condyle fracture might lead to joint stiffness or growth disturbances, but it is unlikely to cause a specific deformity like cubitus varus or valgus.
  • While it can cause elbow dysfunction, non-union of lateral condyle fractures does not typically lead to the deformity described here, making it an unlikely cause.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Mal-United Supracondylar Humerus Fracture is the most likely cause of the elbow deformity in this child, as mal-union of a supracondylar fracture is a common cause of deformities such as cubitus varus (inward angulation of the elbow).

questions.text: A patient presents with groin swelling which worsens on coughing. The swelling appears to arise above the inguinal crease, but reaches the bottom of scrotum. On occlusion of deep ring, the swelling doesn’t appear. What is the pathology?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Indirect inguinal hernia

 

  • An indirect inguinal hernia arises when abdominal contents pass through the deep inguinal ring, traveling along the inguinal canal, and may reach the scrotum.
  • In this case, the swelling appears above the inguinal crease and extends into the scrotum. 
  • The deep ring occlusion test is a confirmatory test for indirect inguinal hernia. 
  • When the deep ring is occluded, the swelling does not appear, indicating that the herniated contents are passing through the deep inguinal ring.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Femoral hernia: A femoral hernia arises below the inguinal crease and protrudes through the femoral canal. It is more common in women and does not reach the scrotum.

 

Option B. Direct inguinal hernia: A direct inguinal hernia protrudes directly through the posterior wall of the inguinal canal and is medial to the inferior epigastric vessels. It does not pass through the deep ring and usually does not extend into the scrotum.

 

Option D. Paraumbilical hernia: A paraumbilical hernia occurs near the umbilicus and is unrelated to the inguinal region. It presents as a swelling near the umbilical area, not the groin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • An indirect inguinal hernia arises from the deep inguinal ring and is the most common type of hernia in both men and women. 
  • It can be distinguished from a direct inguinal hernia by its location and the deep ring occlusion test.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with end-stage renal disease undergoes a kidney transplant. Within minutes of the transplanted organ being connected to the recipient’s circulation, the transplanted kidney turns pale and fails to function. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this hyperacute rejection?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Preformed antibodies

 

  • Hyperacute rejection occurs due to the presence of preformed antibodies against donor antigens in the recipient's circulation. 
  • These antibodies may be directed against ABO blood group antigens or major histocompatibility complex (MHC) antigens. 
  • Upon transplantation, these antibodies rapidly bind to the endothelial cells of the graft, activating the complement system and leading to thrombosis and ischemia of the transplanted organ.

 

Key Features of Hyperacute Rejection:

 

  • Timeframe: Minutes to hours after transplantation.
  • Pathophysiology: Antibody-mediated injury due to preexisting antibodies (often due to prior blood transfusions, previous transplants, or pregnancies).
  • Clinical Presentation: Immediate graft failure with mottling, thrombosis, and ischemia.

 

This form of rejection is largely preventable by proper cross-matching and screening for anti-donor antibodies before transplantation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cytotoxic T-lymphocytes: T-lymphocytes are involved in acute rejection, not hyperacute rejection. Acute rejection typically occurs within days to weeks and is mediated by T-cells recognizing donor antigens presented by antigen-presenting cells.

 

Option B. Circulating macrophages: Macrophages are more commonly associated with chronic rejection, which develops over months to years due to chronic inflammation and fibrosis. Macrophages are not the primary mediators of hyperacute rejection.

 

Option C. Antidonor antibodies produced after transplantation: This describes acute antibody-mediated rejection (AMR), which occurs days to weeks after transplantation due to the development of new antidonor antibodies. Hyperacute rejection, however, is caused by preexisting antibodies that are already present at the time of transplantation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hyperacute rejection occurs due to the presence of preformed antibodies in the recipient, typically directed against donor MHC or ABO antigens. 
  • This leads to immediate vascular thrombosis, ischemia, and graft failure, emphasizing the importance of cross-matching and antibody screening prior to transplantation.

choices.text: Mass vaccination of the local population
Distribution of doxycycline prophylaxis to at-risk populations
Implementation of rodent and flea control programs
Improvement of water supply and sanitation infrastructure

questions.text: A public health team is investigating an outbreak of febrile illness in a coastal city. Patients present with fever, myalgia, and maculopapular rash Laboratory testing identifies Rickettsia typhi. Which of the following interventions would be most effective in preventing future outbreaks in this area?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Implementation of rodent and flea control programs

 

  • Rickettsia typhi, the causative agent of murine (endemic) typhus, is transmitted by fleas, with rats serving as the primary reservoir. 
  • Controlling the rodent population and eliminating fleas are the most effective strategies for preventing future outbreaks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mass vaccination of the local population: No vaccine is available for murine typhus.

 

Option B. Distribution of Doxycycline prophylaxis to at-risk populations: While effective in treatment, routine prophylaxis is impractical for endemic control.

 

Option D. Improvement of water supply and sanitation infrastructure: This is more relevant for waterborne diseases, not flea-borne typhus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Preventing murine typhus outbreaks requires effective rodent and flea control measures, as the disease is transmitted through fleas and maintained in rodent populations.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child is brought to the clinic by his parents due to persistent mouth breathing and snoring at night. On examination, the child has an elongated face, open mouth, and a high-arched palate, as shown in the image. The parents report that the child often appears tired during the day and struggles with focus in school. Which of the following conditions is most likely associated with this facial morphology?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Obstructive sleep apnea

 

  • The child in the image exhibits adenoid facies, which is commonly associated with adenoid hypertrophy and obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). Features of adenoid facies include:
    • Chronic mouth breathing due to nasal obstruction.
    • A dull, expressionless face.
    • An elongated face with an open mouth and high-arched palate.
  • Adenoid hypertrophy can block the nasopharynx, leading to disrupted airflow and OSA. Symptoms such as snoring, daytime fatigue, and poor school performance further support the diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cleft palate: Cleft palate typically presents with feeding difficulties, speech problems, and recurrent infections but does not lead to the characteristic adenoid facies seen in this case.

 

Option B. Down syndrome: Down syndrome is characterized by facial features such as a flat nasal bridge, epicanthal folds, and upslanting palpebral fissures, which are not present in this child.

 

Option C. Chronic allergic rhinitis: Chronic allergic rhinitis can cause nasal obstruction and mouth breathing, but it does not lead to the long-term structural facial changes (adenoid facies) associated with chronic nasal obstruction due to adenoid hypertrophy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Adenoid facies, characterized by a dull, expressionless face with mouth breathing, is a classic feature of adenoid hypertrophy and obstructive sleep apnea in children.

choices.text: Liver dysfunction due to iron overload

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a history of hemochromatosis develops a rapidly progressive wound infection after sustaining a minor cut on his hand while cleaning fish. On examination, there is swelling, erythema, and hemorrhagic bullae at the site of the wound. Laboratory culture shows lactose-fermenting, oxidase-positive colonies on thiosulfate citrate bile salts sucrose (TCBS) agar. Which of the following is the most important host factor predisposing this patient to severe infection with the organism identified?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Liver dysfunction due to iron overload

 

  • Vibrio vulnificus is a halophilic, lactose-fermenting gram-negative bacterium often found in saltwater environments. 
  • It causes severe wound infections and septicemia, particularly in patients with underlying liver disease or iron overload, such as in hemochromatosis. 
  • Iron promotes the growth of Vibrio vulnificus, contributing to its pathogenicity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diabetes mellitus: While diabetes increases susceptibility to some bacterial infections, it is not a significant risk factor for Vibrio vulnificus.

 

Option C. Chronic kidney disease: Although it may impair immunity, CKD is not directly associated with Vibrio vulnificus infections.

 

Option D. Immunosuppressive therapy: Immunosuppression increases the risk of opportunistic infections, but the specific susceptibility to Vibrio vulnificus is primarily related to iron overload or liver dysfunction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Patients with liver disease or iron overload are at high risk for severe Vibrio vulnificus infections due to the bacterium's dependence on iron for growth and virulence.

questions.text: A pregnant woman with a history of a stillbirth at 28 weeks reports having had a painless vulvar sore in the past and mentions a history of sexual activity with multiple partners. What is the most appropriate initial investigation to evaluate the likely cause of her obstetric history?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) VDRL

 

  • The patient's history of a painless vulvar sore (likely a chancre) and stillbirth are highly suggestive of syphilis. 
  • Syphilis during pregnancy can lead to congenital syphilis, miscarriage, and stillbirth. 
  • The VDRL (Venereal Disease Research Laboratory) test is a non-treponemal screening test that detects antibodies formed in response to Treponema pallidum infection. 
  • It is the recommended initial screening test for syphilis during pregnancy.
  •  If the VDRL result is positive, confirmation with a treponemal-specific test, such as FTA-ABS (fluorescent treponemal antibody absorption test), is required.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HIV ELISA: HIV testing is essential during pregnancy but is unrelated to the painless ulcer and stillbirth described in this case. HIV typically predisposes to recurrent infections due to immunosuppression, but it does not present with chancre-like lesions.

 

Option B. Dark ground microscopy: Dark ground microscopy is used to detect Treponema pallidum in active lesions, such as chancres. Since the sore is no longer present, this test is not applicable in this case.

 

Option D. FTA-ABS: The FTA-ABS is a confirmatory treponemal test used after a positive non-treponemal screening test (e.g., VDRL). It is more specific but not typically used as the initial screening test.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The VDRL test is a non-treponemal screening test used to detect syphilis during pregnancy, especially in patients with a history of painless ulcers and adverse pregnancy outcomes such as stillbirth.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man undergoes enucleation due to an intraocular melanoma involving the uveal tract. Histological examination reveals that the tumor originated in the uveal melanocytes. From which embryological layer are these cells derived?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Neural crest

 

  • Uveal melanocytes are derived from the neural crest. 
  • The neural crest gives rise to several structures in the eye, including the iris and choroidal stroma and uveal melanocytes, which contribute to pigmentation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Neural ectoderm: Neural ectoderm contributes to the retina, ciliary epithelium, and muscles of the iris but not melanocytes.

 

Option B. Surface ectoderm: Surface ectoderm contributes to the corneal and conjunctival epithelium, not melanocytes.

 

Option D. Mesoderm: Mesoderm contributes to vascular endothelium and muscles but not melanocytes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Uveal melanocytes are derived from the neural crest, which contributes to the pigmentation of the iris, choroid, and other ocular structures.

questions.text: A 9-month-old infant is brought for a routine check-up. Which of the following speech and language milestones is expected to be achieved by this age?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bisyllables 

 

  • At 9 months, a child typically starts producing bisyllables, such as "mama" or "baba." This milestone reflects the infant's developing language skills and cognitive ability to combine syllables.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Coos (musical vowel sounds): Coos are seen as early as 2 months of age and represent the earliest form of vocalization.

 

Option B. Monosyllables (e.g., "ma", "ba"): These are expected at around 6 months when the infant starts experimenting with simple sounds.

 

Option D. 1-2 words with meaning: This milestone is achieved around 12 months, marking the transition to meaningful speech.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Speech and language milestones are essential for assessing a child’s developmental progress. 
  • At 9 months, the expected milestone is the use of bisyllables like "mama" and "baba."

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents with joint pain, fatigue, and facial rash that worsens upon sun exposure. Laboratory evaluation includes an antinuclear antibody (ANA) test, and the immunofluorescence staining pattern is shown in the image below. Which of the following best describes the ANA staining pattern seen in this patient's test?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Centromeric

 

  • The image depicts a centromeric pattern in the ANA immunofluorescence test, which is characterized by discrete speckles in the nucleus that align with the centromeres of chromosomes.
  • This pattern is often seen in patients with limited scleroderma (CREST syndrome) but can also be present in other autoimmune conditions. 
  • It is important in diagnosing scleroderma when correlated with clinical features like Raynaud's phenomenon, calcinosis, esophageal dysmotility, sclerodactyly, and telangiectasia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nucleolar: Incorrect. Nucleolar pattern is characterized by large, homogeneous staining of the nucleolus. It is often associated with systemic sclerosis but differs from the centromeric pattern, which shows discrete dots in the nuclei.

 

Option C. Speckled: Incorrect. A speckled pattern shows numerous fine speckles throughout the nuclei. It is common in a variety of autoimmune diseases, such as mixed connective tissue disease and Sjogren's syndrome, but the pattern in the image is more consistent with the centromeric type.

 

Option D. Peripheral (rim): Incorrect. The peripheral (rim) pattern shows a more uniform, ring-like staining around the periphery of the nucleus and is commonly seen in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). The pattern in the image, however, shows distinct dots more typical of the centromeric pattern.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The centromeric ANA staining pattern is characterized by discrete nuclear dots and is commonly associated with limited scleroderma (CREST syndrome).

questions.text: A young child presents with developmental delay and specific facial dysmorphism. Genetic testing reveals a deletion at chromosome 15q11-q13. The clinical presentation differs based on whether the genetic deletion is inherited from the mother or father. What is the genetic phenomenon responsible for this difference?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Genomic imprinting

 

  • Genomic imprinting is an epigenetic phenomenon where gene expression is determined by the parent of origin. In the case of a 15q11-q13 deletion:
  • Paternal deletion leads to Prader-Willi syndrome, characterized by hypotonia, hyperphagia, and developmental delay.
  • Maternal deletion leads to Angelman syndrome, characterized by seizures, ataxia, and a "happy demeanor" with severe developmental delay.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Incomplete penetrance: Refers to situations where not all individuals with a mutation show the associated phenotype, which does not explain parental origin-specific effects.

 

Option B. Anticipation: Refers to disorders that worsen in severity or have earlier onset in successive generations (e.g., Huntington’s disease). This is unrelated to parent-specific gene expression.

 

Option C. Gonadal mosaicism: Refers to the presence of a mutation only in germline cells, which can result in the passing of a genetic disorder without it being present in somatic cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Genomic imprinting results in different clinical presentations depending on the parent of origin for specific deletions or mutations, such as Prader-Willi (paternal deletion) and Angelman syndrome (maternal deletion) on chromosome 15q11-q13.

choices.text: Live vaccines are contraindicated even after chemotherapy is completed.
Live vaccines can be safely administered during chemotherapy as long as the patient is afebrile.
Live vaccines are contraindicated in immunocompromised states, but household contacts can safely receive them.
Live vaccines are contraindicated in leukemia patients only if they are in remission.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient undergoing chemotherapy for leukemia presents for vaccination counseling. Which of the following statements regarding live vaccines is accurate for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans.  C) Live vaccines are contraindicated in immunocompromised states, but household contacts can safely receive them.

 

  • Live vaccines are contraindicated in immunocompromised patients (e.g., during chemotherapy or advanced leukemia) due to the risk of uncontrolled replication of the attenuated pathogen.
  • However, household contacts can safely receive live vaccines, as secondary transmission of the attenuated pathogen is rare, and it helps protect the immunocompromised individual through herd immunity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Live vaccines are contraindicated even after chemotherapy is completed: Incorrect. Live vaccines can often be administered 3–6 months after completing chemotherapy once immune function is restored.

 

Option B. Live vaccines can be safely administered during chemotherapy as long as the patient is afebrile: Incorrect. Live vaccines are contraindicated during active immunosuppression, regardless of febrile status.

 

Option D. Live vaccines are contraindicated in leukemia patients only if they are in remission: Incorrect. Live vaccines are contraindicated during active disease and immunosuppression, not just remission.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Live vaccines are contraindicated in immunocompromised individuals but can be safely administered to household contacts to provide indirect protection.

choices.text: Presence of HGPRTase enzyme in hybridomas, allowing salvage pathway activation.
Ability of myeloma cells to produce nucleotides via the de novo pathway.
Selective resistance of B-cells to aminopterin toxicity.
Antibody secretion by myeloma cells neutralizes aminopterin in the medium.

questions.text: A researcher is culturing hybridomas in HAT medium to produce monoclonal antibodies. Which of the following properties ensures that only hybridoma cells survive in the culture?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Presence of HGPRTase enzyme in hybridomas, allowing salvage pathway activation.

 

  • In HAT medium, aminopterin inhibits the de novo nucleotide synthesis pathway. 
  • Myeloma cells lack HGPRTase and cannot use the salvage pathway, leading to cell death. 
  • Hybridomas inherit HGPRTase from spleen cells, allowing them to use the salvage pathway for survival.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ability of myeloma cells to produce nucleotides via the de novo pathway: This is incorrect because aminopterin inhibits the de novo pathway.

 

Option C. Selective resistance of B-cells to aminopterin toxicity: B-cells have HGPRTase but cannot replicate indefinitely, so they die out.

 

Option D. Antibody secretion by myeloma cells neutralizes aminopterin in the medium: Antibody secretion does not neutralize aminopterin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hybridomas survive in HAT medium due to the HGPRTase enzyme, which supports nucleotide synthesis through the salvage pathway.

choices.text: Difference in airway resistance during inspiration and expiration
Difference in alveolar pressure during inspiration and expiration
Inspiration is active and expiration is passive
Difference in concentration of surfactant during inspiration and expiration

questions.text: The difference in the trajectory between the inspiratory and expiratory loops in the pressure-volume curve shown is due to:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Difference in concentration of surfactant during inspiration and expiration

 

  • The phenomenon shown in the curve is hysteresis, which refers to the difference in the lung’s pressure-volume relationship during inspiration and expiration. 
  • This is primarily due to the behavior of pulmonary surfactant:
  • During inspiration, the alveoli expand, and the surfactant molecules are spread over a larger surface area, reducing their effectiveness and requiring more pleural pressure to achieve the same lung volume.
  • During expiration, as the alveoli deflate, surfactant molecules concentrate, stabilizing the alveoli and reducing surface tension, which facilitates easier deflation.
  • Thus, the difference in surfactant concentration during these phases explains the hysteresis observed in the curve.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Difference in airway resistance during inspiration and expiration: While airway resistance plays a role in airflow, it does not account for the hysteresis observed in the pressure-volume relationship of the lung.

 

Option B. Difference in alveolar pressure during inspiration and expiration: Alveolar pressure differences influence airflow but do not directly cause the hysteresis seen in this curve, which is related to the mechanics of the lung tissue and surfactant.

 

Option C. Inspiration is active and expiration is passive: Although this is true for normal breathing, it does not explain the hysteresis in the pressure-volume curve, as the phenomenon is independent of muscle activity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hysteresis in the lung’s pressure-volume curve is primarily caused by differences in surfactant concentration during inspiration and expiration. 
  • This property stabilizes alveoli and ensures efficient lung mechanics during the respiratory cycle.

choices.text: Compound A is produced in the presence of soda-lime and baralyme, and it primarily causes distal tubular necrosis
The use of Amsorb as a CO2 absorbent increases the generation of Compound A
Low fresh gas flow rates during sevoflurane administration increase the production of Compound A
Compound A production is prevented by administering a fresh gas flow rate of less than 2 L/min

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the production of Compound A during anesthesia with sevoflurane?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Low fresh gas flow rates during sevoflurane administration increase the production of Compound A.

 

  • Compound A, a haloalkene, is formed when sevoflurane reacts with strong bases like sodium hydroxide or potassium hydroxide in soda-lime or baralyme. 
  • Low flow anesthesia increases the concentration of Compound A, enhancing its potential for toxicity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Compound A is produced in the presence of soda-lime and baralyme, and it primarily causes distal tubular necrosis: Incorrect. Compound A causes proximal tubular necrosis, not distal tubular necrosis.

 

Option B. The use of Amsorb as a CO2 absorbent increases the generation of Compound A: Incorrect. Amsorb is an inert CO2 absorbent that reduces the degradation of sevoflurane and minimizes Compound A production.

 

Option D. Compound A production is prevented by administering a fresh gas flow rate of less than 2 L/min: Incorrect. A fresh gas flow of at least 2 L/min is required to prevent the accumulation of Compound A.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Compound A, a byproduct of sevoflurane degradation in soda-lime and baralyme, is associated with proximal tubular necrosis. 
  • Risk factors for its production include low fresh gas flow, prolonged anesthesia, and the use of dry soda-lime or baralyme. 
  • Switching to Amsorb and maintaining a fresh gas flow of at least 2 L/min reduces the risk.

choices.text: Brainstem at the level of the medulla oblongata
Brainstem at the level of the midbrain
Cerebral cortex in the distribution of the middle cerebral artery

questions.text: Mr. Madhusudhan, 65-year-old man presents with acute onset of headache, double vision, slurred speech, and left-sided weakness. His headache is described as throbbing at the back of the head. Examination reveals complete ptosis of the right eye, which is depressed and deviated laterally, with a dilated and nonreactive pupil. He also has left-sided hemiplegia with an extensor plantar response, left lower facial droop, and increased cogwheel rigidity in the left upper extremity. A non-contrast CT scan of the head is negative for acute hemorrhage. A lesion in which of the following areas is most likely responsible for this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Brainstem at the level of the midbrain

 

  • The combination of right-sided cranial nerve III palsy (ptosis, "down and out" eye, dilated pupil) and left-sided hemiplegia localizes the lesion to the midbrain. 
  • This presentation is characteristic of Weber syndrome, typically caused by an ischemic lesion affecting the oculomotor nerve and descending corticospinal tracts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Brainstem at the level of the medulla oblongata: Medullary lesions commonly affect cranial nerves IX, X, or XII, causing dysphagia, dysarthria, or tongue deviation, which are absent in this case.

 

Option C. Cerebellar hemisphere: Cerebellar lesions produce ipsilateral ataxia and intention tremor, not oculomotor nerve palsy or hemiplegia.

 

Option D. Cerebral cortex in the distribution of the middle cerebral artery: MCA lesions cause contralateral hemiparesis and aphasia but do not involve cranial nerve III or cause ptosis and "down and out" eyes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Midbrain lesions can present with ipsilateral cranial nerve III palsy and contralateral hemiplegia, a hallmark of Weber syndrome. 
  • Recognizing cranial nerve involvement is crucial for brainstem localization.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with excessive weight gain and an insatiable appetite despite eating regular meals. Damage to which part of the hypothalamus is most likely causing his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ventromedial Nucleus

 

  • The ventromedial nucleus (VMN) of the hypothalamus is the "satiety center" that signals fullness and inhibits appetite. 
  • Damage to this region impairs the ability to regulate food intake, leading to hyperphagia (excessive hunger) and weight gain. 
  • Lesions in this nucleus are associated with obesity due to the absence of inhibitory signals that control feeding behavior.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Paraventricular Nucleus: Primarily involved in regulating water balance, stress response, and food intake by releasing hormones like oxytocin and vasopressin. While it has a minor role in appetite regulation, it is not the primary satiety center.

 

Option C. Arcuate Nucleus: The arcuate nucleus integrates signals from peripheral hormones such as leptin, ghrelin, and insulin to regulate hunger and satiety. However, it modulates appetite rather than being the primary satiety center like the ventromedial nucleus.

 

Option D. Suprachiasmatic Nucleus: This nucleus regulates circadian rhythms, including the sleep-wake cycle, but does not play a direct role in appetite regulation or weight control.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The ventromedial nucleus of the hypothalamus acts as the satiety center, and damage to this region leads to hyperphagia and weight gain.
