questions.text: A 30-year-old individual presents with multiple blistering skin lesions. A skin biopsy reveals acantholysis, characterized by the loss of adhesion between keratinocytes. Which of the following conditions is least likely to display acantholytic cells on histological examination?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Human papillomavirus (HPV) infection

 

  • Acantholysis refers to the separation and loss of adhesion between keratinocytes within the epidermis, leading to the formation of distinct "acantholytic cells." This histological feature is a hallmark of several dermatological conditions. 
  • In the context of the presented case, the presence of acantholysis suggests a disorder that disrupts keratinocyte connections. 
  • Pemphigus, herpes simplex infection, and bullous impetigo are all associated with such disruptions, resulting in acantholytic cells. 
  • However, Human papillomavirus (HPV) infection is characterized by a different cytopathic effect known as koilocytic change. 
  • This involves perinuclear halos and nuclear atypia in keratinocytes, which are distinct from the acantholytic changes observed in other conditions. 
  • Therefore, HPV infection does not typically exhibit acantholysis and is least likely to present with acantholytic cells on histological examination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pemphigus: Pemphigus is an autoimmune blistering disorder where autoantibodies target Desmogleins, components of desmosomes that facilitate keratinocyte adhesion. This disruption leads to prominent acantholysis and intraepidermal blister formation.

 

Option C. Herpes simplex infection: Herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection causes ballooning degeneration of keratinocytes, leading to vesicle formation accompanied by acantholysis. Histology may also reveal multinucleated giant cells and viral inclusions.

 

Option D. Bullous impetigo: Bullous impetigo, often caused by Staphylococcus aureus producing exfoliative toxins, leads to the cleavage within the epidermis and acantholysis, resulting in blister formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Acantholysis, the loss of keratinocyte adhesion, is observed in conditions such as pemphigus, herpes simplex infection, and bullous impetigo, but not typically in Human papillomavirus (HPV) infection, which instead causes koilocytic changes.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child is brought to the clinic with episodes of hypoglycemia, fatigue, and abdominal distension. On examination, hepatomegaly is noted. Lab results show elevated liver enzymes. A biopsy reveals accumulation of abnormally branched glycogen, referred to as "limit dextrin." What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cori’s disease

 

  • Cori’s disease (glycogen storage disease type III) is caused by a deficiency of the debranching enzyme (α-1,6-glucosidase). 
  • This leads to incomplete glycogen breakdown, resulting in the accumulation of limit dextrin, a branched glycogen structure. 
  • Affected children present with hepatomegaly, hypoglycemia during fasting, and elevated liver transaminases. 
  • Unlike Von Gierke's disease, gluconeogenesis remains intact in Cori's disease, so hypoglycemia tends to be milder.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anderson’s disease: Anderson’s disease (glycogen storage disease type IV) is due to a deficiency of the branching enzyme. Instead of limit dextrins, there is the accumulation of abnormally long, unbranched glycogen chains, which leads to cirrhosis and liver failure rather than hypoglycemia and hepatomegaly.

 

Option B. McArdle’s disease: McArdle’s disease (glycogen storage disease type V) is caused by a deficiency of muscle glycogen phosphorylase and primarily affects skeletal muscle. It presents with exercise intolerance, muscle cramps, and myoglobinuria but does not cause hepatomegaly or hypoglycemia.

 

Option D. Pompe’s disease: Pompe’s disease (glycogen storage disease type II) is caused by a deficiency of acid α-glucosidase (lysosomal enzyme). It results in glycogen accumulation in lysosomes, affecting both skeletal and cardiac muscles, causing cardiomegaly, muscle weakness, and respiratory failure, but not limit dextrin accumulation or hypoglycemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cori’s disease (glycogen storage disease type III) is caused by a deficiency in the debranching enzyme, leading to the accumulation of limit dextrin (branched glycogen) and resulting in hepatomegaly and fasting hypoglycemia.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents with a 4-day history of fever, retro-orbital headache, arthralgia, and a diffuse erythematous maculopapular rash. He recently returned from a trip to Brazil, where both Zika and Dengue viruses are endemic. Laboratory findings reveal mild leukopenia and thrombocytopenia, with no evidence of hemoconcentration. Which of the following tests would be most specific in confirming the diagnosis of Zika virus infection in this patient during the acute phase?
questions.solution:
Ans.  C) Multiplex real-time RT-PCR

 

  • Multiplex real-time RT-PCR is the most specific diagnostic test for Zika virus infection during the acute phase, as it detects viral RNA in blood or other body fluids. 
  • It also allows simultaneous differentiation from Dengue and Chikungunya viruses by targeting specific regions of each viral genome, such as the NS5 region of Zika virus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IgM ELISA for Zika virus: Although useful, IgM ELISA lacks specificity due to cross-reactivity with Dengue virus antibodies.

 

Option B. Plaque-reduction neutralization test: While highly specific, this test is labor-intensive and impractical for routine clinical use.

 

Option D. Hemagglutination inhibition assay: This test is not commonly used in clinical settings and has poor specificity for differentiating between flaviviruses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Multiplex real-time RT-PCR is the diagnostic test of choice for acute Zika virus infection due to its specificity in detecting viral RNA and differentiating it from other arboviruses.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents with severe sore throat, difficulty swallowing, and a muffled "hot potato" voice. On examination, there is medial displacement of the left tonsil and deviation of the uvula to the right. The patient is diagnosed with a peritonsillar abscess and undergoes incision and drainage, followed by a course of antibiotics. After how many weeks from abscess drainage is an interval tonsillectomy typically performed?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 6 weeks

 

  • An interval tonsillectomy is performed 6 weeks after the drainage of a peritonsillar abscess to allow resolution of acute inflammation and infection. 
  • This delay reduces the risk of complications associated with performing a tonsillectomy in an inflamed field.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 2 weeks: Performing tonsillectomy at 2 weeks does not allow sufficient time for inflammation and infection to resolve, increasing the risk of complications.

 

Option B. 4 weeks: Four weeks may be too early for complete resolution of inflammation, making 6 weeks the standard interval.

 

Option D. 8 weeks: Eight weeks is unnecessarily delayed, as most patients are fit for surgery by 6 weeks after drainage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Interval tonsillectomy is typically performed 6 weeks after abscess drainage to allow the resolution of infection and reduce surgical complications.

choices.text: Continue the pregnancy with the IUCD in place
Remove the IUCD and terminate the pregnancy

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with an intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD) in place is confirmed to be pregnant. On speculum examination, the IUCD strings are visible at the cervix. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Remove the IUCD

 

  • In cases of pregnancy with an IUCD in situ, removal of the IUCD is recommended if the strings are visible. 
  • This significantly reduces the risk of spontaneous abortion, infection, and preterm labor. 
  • The IUCD can be safely removed during the first trimester when accessible via the cervix. 
  • Continuation of the pregnancy after IUCD removal is possible if the patient desires it.
  • If the IUCD is not removed, the risk of miscarriage, preterm labor, and chorioamnionitis increases.
  •  However, termination of the pregnancy is not mandatory if the patient desires to continue the pregnancy after removing the IUCD.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Continue the pregnancy with the IUCD in place: This increases the risk of spontaneous abortion, infection, and other complications. If the strings are visible, the IUCD should be removed.

 

Option C. Terminate the pregnancy (MTP): Termination is not the first-line option unless the patient opts for it. Many pregnancies can proceed normally after IUCD removal.

 

Option D. Remove the IUCD and terminate the pregnancy: Removal of the IUCD does not necessitate termination. This option is only chosen if the patient decides to terminate the pregnancy voluntarily.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In cases of pregnancy with an intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD) in situ, the IUCD should be removed if the strings are visible to reduce the risk of adverse outcomes such as miscarriage and infection. 
  • Continuation of the pregnancy is possible after removal.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy with a history of recurrent urinary tract infections is being evaluated for possible renal scarring. Which of the following is the best imaging study to detect this renal cortical scarring?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) DMSA (Dimercaptosuccinic acid scan)

 

  • A DMSA (dimercaptosuccinic acid) renal scan is the most sensitive and specific imaging modality for detecting renal cortical scarring. 
  • It provides detailed images of the renal cortex and can localize areas of scarring as photopenic (cold) spots due to decreased uptake in areas of non-functioning or damaged renal parenchyma. 
  • DMSA scans are widely used to assess long-term damage following recurrent pyelonephritis or severe UTIs. 
  • It is considered the gold standard for detecting renal scarring.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. DTPA (Diethylenetriaminepentaacetic acid) scan: A DTPA scan is primarily used to assess renal function and perfusion, often in the evaluation of renal clearance and obstructive uropathies. However, it is less accurate in detecting cortical scarring and does not provide detailed images of the renal cortex.

 

Option B. CT (Computed Tomography) scan: CT imaging can visualize structural changes in the kidneys and detect areas of renal damage. However, it is typically not the preferred modality for assessing renal cortical scarring in pediatric patients due to its radiation exposure and lower sensitivity compared to DMSA scans for detecting subtle scarring.

 

Option C. MCU (Micturating Cystourethrogram): An MCU is primarily used to evaluate vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) and structural abnormalities of the urethra and bladder during urination. Although VUR can predispose a patient to renal scarring, the MCU itself does not directly visualize the renal parenchyma or detect scarring.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A DMSA renal scan is the gold standard for detecting renal cortical scarring and provides precise localization of non-functioning or damaged renal tissue. 
  • It is particularly useful in children with a history of recurrent urinary tract infections or pyelonephritis.

choices.text: Integration of bacteriophage DNA into the bacterial genome

questions.text: Which of the following best explains how Streptococcus pyogenes acquires the ability to produce pyrogenic exotoxins A and C?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Integration of bacteriophage DNA into the bacterial genome

 

  • Pyrogenic exotoxins A and C are phage-mediated toxins encoded by bacteriophage DNA that integrates into the Streptococcus pyogenes genome via lysogeny. 
  • This process enhances the virulence of the bacteria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Conjugation with a plasmid-containing bacterium: Conjugation transfers plasmids, not phage DNA.

 

Option B. Transformation from environmental DNA: Transformation involves uptake of environmental DNA but does not explain phage-mediated toxins.

 

Option D. Spontaneous chromosomal mutation: Chromosomal mutations do not lead to acquisition of new phage-mediated virulence factors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Phage-mediated lysogeny is the mechanism through which Streptococcus pyogenes acquires genes for pyrogenic exotoxins, increasing its pathogenicity.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the Rockall scoring system for predicting mortality and rebleeding risk in patients with upper gastrointestinal bleeding?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hemoglobin

 

  • The Rockall scoring system evaluates the risk of mortality and rebleeding in upper gastrointestinal bleeding using the following factors:
    1. Age
    2. Presence of shock (systolic blood pressure and pulse)
    3. Comorbidities (such as renal failure, liver failure, or coronary artery disease)
    4. Endoscopic diagnosis
    5. Major stigmata of recent hemorrhage (Forrest grade)
  • Hemoglobin levels are not included in the Rockall scoring system. 

  • However, the Glasgow-Blatchford score, another commonly used scoring system, does incorporate hemoglobin and blood urea nitrogen (BUN) levels to predict the need for intervention in patients with upper GI bleeding.

     

Other Options:

 

Option A. Forrest grade: The Forrest classification assesses stigmata of recent hemorrhage seen on endoscopy and is a key component of the Rockall score. It includes classifications such as active spurting bleeding (Forrest I) or visible vessel (Forrest II).

 

Option B. Presence of coronary artery disease: Comorbid conditions like coronary artery disease, renal failure, and liver failure are included in the Rockall scoring system and significantly impact the overall score.

 

Option C. Systolic BP: Systolic blood pressure and pulse are used to assess the degree of shock in the patient, making them an integral part of the Rockall score.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Rockall scoring system evaluates the risk of mortality and rebleeding in patients with upper gastrointestinal bleeding based on age, comorbidities, systolic BP and pulse (shock), endoscopic findings, and Forrest grade. 
  • Hemoglobin levels are not included in the Rockall score but are part of the Glasgow-Blatchford score.

choices.text: Perform MRI of the brain with and without gadolinium

questions.text: A 78-year-old woman from an assisted living facility is brought to the emergency department after a tonic-clonic seizure. Her caretakers report mild confusion and headache yesterday, followed by involuntary shaking of her right upper and lower extremities before the seizure. The patient has no history of recent travel, sick contacts, or systemic symptoms like cough, diarrhea, or urinary issues. She has hypertension and hyperlipidemia but no known allergies. On examination, her temperature is 38.1°C (100.8°F), blood pressure is 140/88 mm Hg, and pulse is 90/min. She is obtunded and does not follow commands but localizes pain bilaterally and withdraws her lower extremities to pain. Non-contrast CT of the head shows no mass, bleeding, or parenchymal abnormalities. MRI image is shown below. Chest X-ray and urinalysis are unremarkable. A lumbar puncture is attempted but unsuccessful. She is started on intravenous vancomycin, ampicillin, and ceftriaxone. Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Add intravenous acyclovir

 

  • The patient’s fever, confusion, and focal neurological symptoms preceding the generalized seizure are concerning for viral encephalitis, particularly herpes simplex virus (HSV) encephalitis. 
  • HSV encephalitis often presents with fever, headache, focal neurological signs (such as focal seizures), and altered mental status. 
  • Empiric acyclovir should be initiated promptly, as delaying treatment can lead to increased morbidity and mortality.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Add rifampin: Rifampin is used in specific bacterial infections, such as meningitis caused by Neisseria meningitidis (as prophylaxis) or Mycobacterium tuberculosis. There is no evidence to suggest a need for rifampin in this case.

 

Option C. Perform bedside electroencephalogram monitoring: Although an EEG may be helpful in detecting ongoing seizures or nonconvulsive status epilepticus, it does not address the underlying cause of the patient’s symptoms. Empiric treatment for HSV encephalitis takes precedence.

 

Option D. Perform MRI of the brain with and without gadolinium: While MRI is the most sensitive imaging modality for HSV encephalitis, treatment should not be delayed while awaiting imaging. Acyclovir should be started immediately if clinical suspicion for HSV encephalitis is high.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • HSV encephalitis should be suspected in patients with fever, altered mental status, focal neurological deficits, and seizures. 
  • Prompt initiation of intravenous acyclovir is critical, as delayed treatment can lead to severe neurological damage or death. 
  • MRI and lumbar puncture can help confirm the diagnosis but should not delay empiric treatment.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with swelling of the feet, apathy, and a protuberant abdomen. On examination, the child has flaky paint dermatosis and a moon face. Which of the following findings is least likely to be present in this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Loss of subcutaneous fat

 

  • Loss of subcutaneous fat is not typical of kwashiorkor. In kwashiorkor, subcutaneous fat is preserved due to the predominance of protein deficiency over total calorie deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Edema: Prominent edema is a hallmark of kwashiorkor due to hypoalbuminemia.

 

Option B. Fatty liver: Fatty liver is commonly seen in kwashiorkor due to impaired fat metabolism resulting from protein deficiency.

 

Option C. Severe muscle wasting: Muscle wasting in kwashiorkor is mild or absent, unlike marasmus, where it is severe.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Kwashiorkor is characterized by protein deficiency, resulting in edema, apathy, flaky paint dermatosis, moon face, and fatty liver. 
  • Subcutaneous fat is typically preserved, and severe muscle wasting is uncommon compared to marasmus.

questions.text: A clinical trial compares survival outcomes between three cancer treatment groups using Kaplan-Meier curves. Which of the following is the most suitable test to evaluate differences across all groups?
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) Log-rank test

 

  • The log-rank test is commonly used to compare survival distributions across two or more groups when Kaplan-Meier survival curves are generated.
  •  It evaluates whether there are statistically significant differences in survival across the groups.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Breslow test: This test is an alternative to the log-rank test but is more sensitive to early differences in survival.

 

Option C. Cox proportional hazards test: Used to assess the impact of covariates on survival, not for comparing Kaplan-Meier curves directly.

 

Option D. Kruskal-Wallis test: Used for comparing medians across groups, not survival curves.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The log-rank test is the standard approach for comparing survival distributions across multiple groups using Kaplan-Meier survival curves.

questions.text: Avascular necrosis of the femur head is due to which of the following artery:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Medial circumflex femoral artery

 

  • The medial circumflex femoral artery is one of the two main branches of the femoral artery. It is responsible for providing the majority of the blood supply to the femoral head. It supplies blood to the neck of the femur and the femoral head, which is crucial for maintaining the health of the bone and cartilage.
  • Medial circumflex femoral artery provides the primary vascular supply to the femoral head. Damage to this artery (e.g., due to trauma, fractures, or surgeries) can result in a reduction or cessation of blood flow to the femoral head, leading to avascular necrosis (AVN).
  • The ascending branch of the medial circumflex femoral artery is especially important in the blood supply to the femoral head.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lateral Circumflex Femoral Artery:

 

  • The lateral circumflex femoral artery is another branch of the femoral artery that supplies blood to the thigh muscles, particularly the anterior and lateral muscles of the thigh. It does not play a major role in supplying the femoral head.
  • Although it contributes to the blood supply to the hip joint and surrounding structures, it does not significantly supply the femoral head.
  • The lateral circumflex femoral artery supplies more to the surrounding soft tissues (e.g., muscles) rather than the bone of the femoral head.
  • The lateral circumflex femoral artery does not play a significant role in supplying blood to the femoral head, making it unlikely to be the primary cause of AVN in the femur.

 

Option C. Obturator Artery:

 

  • The obturator artery arises from the internal iliac artery and supplies the muscles and ligaments of the medial thigh and the hip joint. It also gives off a branch (the acetabular branch) that contributes to the vascular supply of the femoral head, but this contribution is much less significant than that from the medial circumflex femoral artery.
  • The obturator artery is a secondary source of blood supply to the femoral head, and in some cases, it can play a role in providing collateral circulation.
  • If the primary blood supply (from the medial circumflex femoral artery) is compromised, the contribution from the obturator artery may not be enough to prevent AVN.
  • Although the obturator artery does supply a small branch to the femoral head, it is not the main artery responsible for the blood supply, so it is unlikely to be the primary cause of avascular necrosis of the femoral head.

 

Option D. Profunda Femoris Artery:

 

  • The profunda femoris artery (deep femoral artery) is a branch of the femoral artery that supplies the thigh muscles. It gives off multiple branches, including the medial and lateral circumflex femoral arteries.
  • While the profunda femoris artery is important for supplying the muscles of the thigh, it is not directly responsible for the blood supply to the femoral head.
  • It gives rise to the medial and lateral circumflex femoral arteries, but it does not contribute significantly to the femoral head's blood flow directly.
  • The profunda femoris artery is not directly responsible for supplying the femoral head with blood, though it does give rise to arteries (like the medial and lateral circumflex femoral arteries) that contribute to the vascular supply of the hip region.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The medial circumflex femoral artery is the main artery responsible for supplying the femoral head with blood. 
  • It is the primary artery at risk in conditions like avascular necrosis (AVN) when the blood supply is compromised.

choices.text: Immediate enucleation of the injured eye

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman undergoes enucleation of her left eye following a severe penetrating injury sustained in a car accident. Two months later, she develops photophobia, blurring of vision, and floaters in her right (uninjured) eye. On examination, she has retrolental flare, vitreous cells, and clusters of pigmented epithelioid cells beneath the retinal pigment epithelium (Dalen-Fuchs nodules). What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) High-dose systemic corticosteroids

 

Explanation:

 

High-dose systemic corticosteroids are the first-line treatment for sympathetic ophthalmia to control the immune-mediated inflammation. Enucleation of the injured eye is only preventive and effective within 2 weeks post-injury. Once the condition manifests, the goal is to preserve vision in the sympathizing eye using anti-inflammatory therapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immediate enucleation of the injured eye: This is ineffective for preventing the progression of sympathetic ophthalmia once it has already developed.

 

Option C. Vitrectomy and retinal detachment repair: This is used for mechanical retinal issues but not for immune-mediated uveitis.

 

Option D. Empiric antibiotic therapy for endophthalmitis: There is no evidence of an infectious process in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sympathetic ophthalmia is treated with high-dose corticosteroids to suppress the immune response and prevent further vision loss.

choices.text: Its action as a serotonin (5-HT3) receptor antagonist
Its long plasma half-life of 180 hours
Its ability to cross the blood-brain barrier

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient undergoing chemotherapy is prescribed rolapitant for nausea and vomiting. Which of the following characteristics best explains its suitability for chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Its long plasma half-life of 180 hours

 

  • Rolapitant is a highly selective NK1 receptor antagonist with a plasma half-life of 180 hours. 
  • This prolonged duration of action makes it highly effective for managing delayed chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting, as it allows sustained inhibition of the NK1 receptors involved in emesis pathways.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Its action as a serotonin (5-HT3) receptor antagonist: Rolapitant is not a 5-HT3 receptor antagonist. Drugs like ondansetron fall under this category.

 

Option C. Its ability to cross the blood-brain barrier: While rolapitant acts on central NK1 receptors, its long half-life is the key factor for its use in delayed nausea and vomiting.

 

Option D. Its effect on dopaminergic pathways: Dopaminergic pathway inhibition is the mechanism of drugs like metoclopramide, not rolapitant.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Rolapitant is a selective NK1 receptor antagonist with a long half-life of 180 hours, making it effective for delayed chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting.

choices.text: Casting and avoidance of weight bearing

questions.text:
A 78-year-old woman presents with a red, hot, and swollen right foot for one week. She reports mild pain relieved with acetaminophen and denies fever or chills. She has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus complicated by peripheral neuropathy and chronic kidney disease. The symptoms began after she bumped her foot, but there was no immediate swelling. On examination, she is afebrile with warmth, erythema, and edema of the right foot. Peripheral pulses are symmetric, and monofilament testing reveals decreased sensation in both feet. Blood leukocyte count is normal. Image of the foot is shown below. 

 

 

Aspiration of the right tarsus reveals 200/mm³ red blood cells, 200/mm³ white blood cells (60% neutrophils), no crystals, and a negative Gram stain. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Casting and avoidance of weight bearing

 

  • This patient’s presentation is consistent with Charcot joint (neuropathic arthropathy), a condition commonly seen in patients with diabetes and peripheral neuropathy. 
  • The trauma and lack of sensation lead to repetitive microtrauma, inflammation, and joint destruction. 
  • Warmth, erythema, and swelling are hallmark features, and normal inflammatory markers or leukocyte counts differentiate Charcot joint from infectious causes like cellulitis or septic arthritis. The first step in management is casting and avoidance of weight bearing to reduce further trauma and prevent progression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Intravenous vancomycin: There is no evidence of infection (normal leukocyte count, negative Gram stain). Antibiotics are not indicated in this case.

 

Option C. Orthotic shoe inserts: Orthotic inserts may be used after acute inflammation subsides, but immediate treatment focuses on immobilization and weight-bearing restriction to protect the affected joint.

 

Option D. Physical therapy: Physical therapy is not appropriate during the acute phase, as it could exacerbate joint damage. It may be considered during recovery to improve joint function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Charcot joint is a common complication in diabetic patients with peripheral neuropathy. 
  • Management includes casting and weight-bearing avoidance to prevent further joint destruction and complications. 
  • Early diagnosis and intervention are crucial for preserving joint function.

choices.text: Blood in the superior vena cava has a higher oxygen concentration compared to the inferior vena cava.
Blood in the inferior vena cava bypasses the liver via the ductus arteriosus.
A larger percentage of oxygen-rich blood is perfused to the brain in fetal circulation.
The right ventricle exclusively perfuses the upper extremities in the fetus.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about fetal circulation is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A larger percentage of oxygen-rich blood is perfused to the brain in fetal circulation.

 

  • The blood in the inferior vena cava (IVC) has a higher oxygen concentration compared to the superior vena cava (SVC) because the highly oxygenated blood from the placenta enters the IVC via the umbilical vein and ductus venosus, bypassing the hepatic circulation. 
  • A larger percentage of this oxygen-rich blood is directed to the brain through fetal shunts like the foramen ovale.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blood in the superior vena cava has a higher oxygen concentration compared to the inferior vena cava: Incorrect. Blood in the SVC carries deoxygenated blood returning from the upper body, whereas the IVC carries highly oxygenated blood.

 

Option B. Blood in the inferior vena cava bypasses the liver via the ductus arteriosus: Incorrect. Blood in the IVC bypasses the liver via the ductus venosus, not the ductus arteriosus.

 

Option D. The right ventricle exclusively perfuses the upper extremities in the fetus: Incorrect. The right ventricle primarily perfuses the lower extremities, not the upper extremities, in the fetus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In fetal circulation, the highly oxygenated blood from the placenta preferentially supplies the brain and heart through shunts like the foramen ovale and ductus arteriosus, with the inferior vena cava carrying blood of higher oxygen concentration compared to the superior vena cava.

questions.text: Which of the following ultrasound findings confirms the diagnosis of anencephaly?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Frog-eye sign

 

  • The "frog-eye sign" is a characteristic ultrasound finding in anencephaly. 
  • Anencephaly is a neural tube defect where there is a complete or partial absence of the cranial vault and cerebral tissue. 
  • Due to the absence of the skull bones, the orbits of the fetus appear prominent and protruding on the ultrasound, resembling the eyes of a frog. 
  • This "frog-like" appearance is a hallmark of anencephaly and is typically seen on mid- and late-trimester ultrasounds.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lemon sign: The "lemon sign" is an ultrasound finding commonly associated with spina bifida. It refers to the concave shape of the frontal bones of the fetal skull, giving it the appearance of a lemon. This sign is not related to anencephaly.

 

Option C. T sign: The "T sign" is used in ultrasound to distinguish monochorionic twin pregnancies, where the dividing membrane between the twins inserts at a perpendicular angle (forming a "T" shape). This finding is not relevant to the diagnosis of anencephaly.

 

Option D. Double bubble sign: The "double bubble sign" is an ultrasound finding associated with duodenal atresia. It represents the distended stomach and proximal duodenum separated by the pylorus and is unrelated to neural tube defects or anencephaly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The frog-eye sign on ultrasound is a pathognomonic finding for anencephaly and is characterized by the absence of the cranial vault and protruding orbits resembling a frog's eyes.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man with a history of multiple unprotected sexual encounters presents to the clinic for evaluation. He is concerned about his risk of acquiring viral infections. Among the following, which hepatitis virus is least likely to be transmitted through sexual contact?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hepatitis E

 

  • Hepatitis E is primarily transmitted via the fecal-oral route, often through contaminated water.
  •  It is not commonly associated with sexual transmission. In contrast, Hepatitis B and Hepatitis D (which requires HBV for replication) are frequently transmitted through sexual contact. 
  • Hepatitis C transmission via sexual contact is less common but can occur in high-risk settings, particularly among individuals with co-infections like HIV.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hepatitis B: Hepatitis B is highly transmissible via sexual contact due to its presence in bodily fluids like blood and semen.

 

Option B. Hepatitis C: While primarily transmitted through blood, sexual transmission is possible, particularly in high-risk settings.

 

Option C. Hepatitis D: Hepatitis D requires co-infection with HBV and is transmitted in similar ways, including sexual contact.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hepatitis E is primarily transmitted via the fecal-oral route, making it the least likely hepatitis virus to be transmitted through sexual contact.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman with HER2-positive breast cancer is started on a combination therapy that includes a monoclonal antibody specifically targeting the HER2 receptor. Despite significant improvement, she begins to experience mild infusion-related reactions. Which of the following monoclonal antibodies is least likely to act on the HER1 (EGFR) receptor and most likely targets HER2?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pertuzumab

 

  • Pertuzumab is a monoclonal antibody targeting the HER2 receptor. It works by preventing HER2 dimerization with other HER family receptors, a critical step in downstream signaling in HER2-positive cancers. 
  • It does not act on the HER1 (EGFR) receptor.
  • HER2-targeted therapy is particularly effective in HER2-positive breast cancers when used in combination with trastuzumab and chemotherapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cetuximab: Targets the HER1 (EGFR) receptor and is used in cancers such as colorectal cancer and head and neck cancers.

 

Option C. Necitumumab: A HER1 (EGFR) inhibitor used in metastatic squamous non-small cell lung cancer.

 

Option D. Panitumumab: Another HER1 (EGFR) inhibitor, used for metastatic colorectal cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pertuzumab specifically targets the HER2 receptor and is not associated with HER1 inhibition, distinguishing it from cetuximab, necitumumab, and panitumumab.

choices.text: It ensures that all cases are confirmed by laboratory testing.
It prevents imported cases from being reported as endemic transmission.
It demonstrates the sensitivity of the surveillance system in detecting suspected cases.
It measures the population's herd immunity against measles.

questions.text: During a review of measles elimination criteria, an epidemiologist argues that surveillance systems must detect at least 2 suspected measles cases per 100,000 population annually. Why is this surveillance indicator critical for elimination certification?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It demonstrates the sensitivity of the surveillance system in detecting suspected cases.

 

  • A surveillance system's sensitivity ensures that even sporadic cases of measles are detected and investigated. 
  • The indicator of detecting at least 2 suspected cases per 100,000 population annually ensures that the system is sufficiently robust to identify potential outbreaks and prevent underreporting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It ensures that all cases are confirmed by laboratory testing: Laboratory confirmation is a separate step in case confirmation, not an indicator of surveillance sensitivity.

 

Option B. It prevents imported cases from being reported as endemic transmission: While important, this is not the primary purpose of this indicator.

 

Option D. It measures the population's herd immunity against measles. This indicator assesses surveillance sensitivity, not immunity levels.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • A sensitive surveillance system is critical for detecting and investigating measles cases, a key requirement for elimination certification.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman with a history of Graves' disease presents to the emergency department with severe nausea, vomiting, palpitations, and altered mental status. She was treated with methimazole initially but discontinued it due to a rash. Three days ago, she received radioactive iodine (RAI) therapy. On examination, she is agitated and febrile (39.4°C/103°F) with a blood pressure of 160/90 mm Hg, pulse of 160/min, and respirations of 24/min. She has a diffusely enlarged thyroid, fine hand tremor, and mild lid lag. Laboratory results show markedly suppressed TSH, elevated T3 and free T4 levels, mild hyperglycemia, and elevated liver enzymes. Which of the following is the best next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Propranolol and propylthiouracil

 

  • This patient’s presentation is consistent with thyroid storm, a life-threatening complication of untreated or inadequately treated hyperthyroidism. 
  • It can be triggered by stressors such as RAI therapy. Management involves:
  1. Propranolol: Controls sympathetic overactivity (tachycardia, tremors) and decreases T4 to T3 conversion.
  2. Propylthiouracil (PTU): Inhibits thyroid hormone synthesis and peripheral conversion of T4 to T3.
  3. Dexamethasone: Decreases peripheral conversion of T4 to T3 and provides anti-inflammatory effects (to be added after PTU).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blood cultures and empiric antibiotics: While fever could raise suspicion for infection, this patient’s clinical picture and history of recent RAI therapy strongly suggest thyroid storm as the cause of her symptoms. Empiric antibiotics are not the first step.

 

Option B. Dantrolene: Dantrolene is used for malignant hyperthermia and neuroleptic malignant syndrome, which present with hyperthermia and muscle rigidity. This patient does not have muscle rigidity, and her clinical picture is more consistent with thyroid storm.

 

Option C. Dexamethasone: While dexamethasone is part of thyroid storm management, it is not the initial step. The first priority is controlling thyroid hormone synthesis and effects with PTU and propranolol.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Thyroid storm is a medical emergency requiring immediate treatment with beta-blockers (to control symptoms), antithyroid drugs (to inhibit hormone synthesis), and corticosteroids (to reduce peripheral conversion and inflammation). 
  • Prompt recognition and intervention are critical to reduce mortality.

questions.text: A 47- year-old man with chronic liver disease undergoes evaluation of his liver’s ability to detoxify xenobiotics. Phase 1 hydroxylation reactions, catalyzed by cytochrome P-450 enzymes, are assessed. These reactions require which of the following cofactors for proper enzymatic function?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) NADPH

 

  • The cytochrome P-450 monooxygenase system plays a critical role in Phase 1 detoxification reactions, which include oxidation, hydroxylation, and dealkylation of xenobiotics. 
  • The system requires NADPH as an electron donor to transfer reducing equivalents to cytochrome P-450, which facilitates the activation of molecular oxygen. 
  • This activated oxygen is then incorporated into the substrate (xenobiotic) during hydroxylation. 
  • NADPH is generated in cells primarily through the pentose phosphate pathway and is vital for maintaining reductive biosynthesis and antioxidant defense.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. NADH: NADH is an electron carrier involved in energy production in the mitochondria (e.g., the electron transport chain), but it is not directly involved in the cytochrome P-450 system for hydroxylation reactions. NADH primarily supports oxidative phosphorylation rather than Phase 1 detoxification.

 

Option B. FAD: Flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD) is a cofactor involved in various redox reactions, such as those in the electron transport chain and the TCA cycle. However, FAD is not directly utilized by the cytochrome P-450 system in Phase 1 reactions.

 

Option D. FADH₂: FADH₂ is the reduced form of FAD and donates electrons in the electron transport chain to produce ATP. Similar to FAD, it is not required for cytochrome P-450-mediated detoxification reactions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The cytochrome P-450 monooxygenase system requires NADPH as an essential electron donor for Phase 1 hydroxylation reactions, which are critical for the detoxification and metabolism of xenobiotics.

questions.text: All of these are causes of bilious vomiting in a neonate at birth except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Infantile pyloric stenosis

 

  • Infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS) typically presents with non-bilious projectile vomiting, but it occurs at around 4-8 weeks of age, not at birth. 
  • It results from hypertrophy of the pylorus, leading to gastric outlet obstruction. 
  • Therefore, it is not a cause of vomiting in neonates at birth.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Duodenal atresia: Duodenal atresia is a congenital obstruction of the duodenum, usually presenting with bilious vomiting within the first 24-48 hours of life. It is often associated with the "double bubble" sign on radiographs.

 

Option C. Jejunal atresia: Jejunal atresia also presents with bilious vomiting shortly after birth due to congenital obstruction of the jejunum, leading to intestinal obstruction. It is a cause of neonatal vomiting.

 

Option D. Meconium ileus: Meconium ileus, often associated with cystic fibrosis, is a condition where thick, sticky meconium obstructs the intestine. It presents with bilious vomiting and failure to pass meconium in the first days of life.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis does not present at birth but rather around 4-8 weeks of life with non-bilious vomiting. 
  • In contrast, conditions like duodenal atresia, jejunal atresia, and meconium ileus can cause vomiting in the immediate neonatal period.

choices.text: It acts primarily by activating antithrombin III to inhibit thrombin and factor Xa.
It directly binds to thrombin, leading to fibrinolysis.
It reduces platelet aggregation by inhibiting glycoprotein IIb/IIIa.
It blocks vitamin K epoxide reductase, reducing the synthesis of clotting factors II, VII, IX, and X.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male is undergoing mitral valve replacement surgery. During the procedure, heparin is administered. Post-surgery, he develops gastrointestinal bleeding. Laboratory results show a prolonged aPTT but a normal PT and platelet count. Which of the following properties of heparin contributes most to the observed laboratory findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It acts primarily by activating antithrombin III to inhibit thrombin and factor Xa.

 

  • Heparin enhances the activity of antithrombin III, which inactivates clotting factors IIa (thrombin) and Xa. 
  • This mechanism prolongs the activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) without affecting prothrombin time (PT).
  • The patient’s gastrointestinal bleeding is consistent with the anticoagulant effect of heparin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. It directly binds to thrombin, leading to fibrinolysis: Heparin does not directly bind thrombin; it acts via antithrombin III.

 

Option C. It reduces platelet aggregation by inhibiting glycoprotein IIb/IIIa: This describes the action of antiplatelet agents like abciximab, not heparin.

 

Option D. It blocks vitamin K epoxide reductase, reducing the synthesis of clotting factors II, VII, IX, and X: This describes the action of warfarin, not heparin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Heparin works by activating antithrombin III, leading to the inactivation of thrombin (factor IIa) and factor Xa, resulting in a prolonged aPTT.

choices.text: Initiation of topical antihistamines and mast cell stabilizers to address the underlying allergic inflammation
Patient education to stop manual mucus removal and initiation of topical corticosteroids
Empirical antibiotic therapy with topical erythromycin ointment to address a presumed bacterial infection
Immediate discontinuation of all ophthalmic medications and follow-up after 4 weeks for reassessment

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with chronic eye discomfort, redness, and persistent mucous discharge for the past several months. She admits to using cotton swabs to manually remove mucus from her eyes multiple times a day. On examination, there is hyperemia of the conjunctiva and multiple cobblestone-like papillae on the upper tarsal conjunctiva. Which of the following represents the most effective first-line management strategy for her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Patient education to stop manual mucus removal and initiation of topical corticosteroids

 

  • The patient’s presentation is consistent with mucus fishing syndrome, often secondary to giant papillary conjunctivitis (GPC) caused by repetitive mechanical irritation (e.g., contact lenses or habitual mucus removal). 
  • The key to management is stopping the vicious cycle of mucus production and removal, achieved through patient education. 
  • Topical corticosteroids reduce the underlying inflammation and allow the conjunctiva to heal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Initiation of topical antihistamines and mast cell stabilizers to address the underlying allergic inflammation: Topical antihistamines and mast cell stabilizers are more appropriate for allergic conjunctivitis, not GPC or mucus fishing syndrome.

 

Option C. Empirical antibiotic therapy with topical erythromycin ointment to address a presumed bacterial infection: There is no evidence of bacterial infection; antibiotics are not indicated.

 

Option D. Immediate discontinuation of all ophthalmic medications and follow-up after 4 weeks for reassessment: Stopping all ophthalmic medications without treatment or education will not address the ongoing mechanical irritation and inflammation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Management of mucus fishing syndrome involves breaking the cycle of mucus removal and irritation through patient education and reducing conjunctival inflammation with topical corticosteroids.

questions.text: Which of the following does not qualify as grievous hurt under the BNS?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Abrasion over the cheek

 

  • Grievous hurt under BNS Section 116 includes specific injuries that result in significant or permanent harm. 
  • Disfiguration of the face qualifies as grievous hurt only if it is permanent. 
  • An abrasion over the cheek typically heals without leaving a permanent scar or mark, thus not meeting the criteria for grievous hurt.

 

Grievous Hurt as Defined in BNS Section 116:

 

  1. Emasculation
  2. Permanent privation of the sight of either eye
  3. Permanent privation of the hearing of either ear
  4. Privation of any member or joint
  5. Destruction or permanent impairment of the power of any member or joint
  6. Permanent disfiguration of the head or face
  7. Fracture or dislocation of a bone or tooth
  8. Any hurt that:
    a) Endangers life (Dangerous injury)
    b) Causes severe bodily pain for 15 days
    c) Prevents the victim from following ordinary pursuits for 15 days

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Laceration over the cheek: While not inherently grievous, if it results in permanent disfigurement of the face, it qualifies under grievous hurt as defined by the BNS.

 

Option B. Severe bodily pain for 15 days: A hurt causing severe bodily pain for 15 days meets the BNS criteria for grievous hurt.

 

Option D. Both B and C: While B qualifies as grievous hurt, C does not. Hence, this option is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Grievous hurt under BNS is defined by specific injuries resulting in significant, permanent harm or prolonged suffering (15 days or more). 
  • Temporary or superficial injuries, such as abrasions, do not meet the criteria unless they leave permanent disfigurement.

choices.text: Documenting the mode of death, such as heart failure or respiratory failure
Listing conditions contributing to death that are unrelated to the primary disease process
Detailing all antecedent causes leading to the immediate cause of death
Providing the approximate interval between onset and death for each condition

questions.text: During a training session on completing death certificates, a physician is asked to explain the purpose of Part II of the certificate. Which of the following best describes the role of Part II in documenting the cause of death?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Listing conditions contributing to death that are unrelated to the primary disease process

 

  • Part II of the death certificate is used to document significant conditions that contribute to death but are not part of the causal sequence listed in Part I. 
  • For example, conditions like diabetes or chronic kidney disease may be listed in Part II if they influenced the course of the patient's illness but were not directly related to the cause of death.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Documenting the mode of death, such as heart failure or respiratory failure: Modes of death (e.g., heart failure, respiratory failure) are not documented in this section as they do not represent diseases or conditions.

 

Option C. Detailing all antecedent causes leading to the immediate cause of death: Antecedent causes are recorded in Part I, not Part II.

 

Option D. Providing the approximate interval between onset and death for each condition: This information is recorded in Part I alongside each listed condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Part II of the death certificate is used to document significant conditions contributing to death that are not directly related to the causal sequence listed in Part I.

questions.text: Which amino acid is formed by adding a hydroxyl group to the benzene ring of phenylalanine?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tyrosine

 

  • Tyrosine is synthesized from phenylalanine through the addition of a hydroxyl group to the benzene ring. 
  • This reaction is catalyzed by the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase, with tetrahydrobiopterin (BH₄) serving as a cofactor. 
  • Tyrosine plays a crucial role in the synthesis of neurotransmitters (dopamine, norepinephrine, and epinephrine), thyroid hormones, and melanin. 
  • A deficiency of phenylalanine hydroxylase results in the accumulation of phenylalanine, leading to phenylketonuria (PKU).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serine: Serine is a non-essential amino acid that is synthesized from 3-phosphoglycerate, an intermediate of glycolysis. It does not involve phenylalanine as a precursor.

 

Option C. Valine:  An essential branched-chain amino acid involved in protein synthesis, not derived from phenylalanine.

 

Option D. Threonine: Threonine is an essential amino acid with a hydroxyl-containing side chain, but it is not derived from phenylalanine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tyrosine is synthesized from phenylalanine via the addition of a hydroxyl group to the benzene ring, a reaction catalyzed by phenylalanine hydroxylase. 
  • Deficiency in this enzyme leads to phenylketonuria (PKU) due to the accumulation of phenylalanine.

questions.text: Which of the following permanent teeth do not erupt in the sockets of temporary teeth?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Molars

 

  • Permanent molars erupt in new sockets and do not replace any temporary (deciduous) teeth. In contrast:
  • Temporary incisors, canines, and molars are replaced by their corresponding permanent successors:
    • Temporary incisors → Permanent incisors
    • Temporary canines → Permanent canines
    • Temporary molars → Permanent premolars
  • Permanent molars do not replace any temporary teeth; instead, they erupt posteriorly in the dental arch as new teeth in new sockets.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Premolars: Incorrect. Premolars are the permanent successors of temporary molars. They replace the temporary molars in their sockets.

 

Option C. Canines: Incorrect. Canines erupt in the sockets of their corresponding temporary canines.

 

Option D. Incisors: Incorrect. Permanent incisors replace the temporary incisors in their respective sockets.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Permanent molars are unique among permanent teeth as they do not replace any temporary teeth but instead erupt in new sockets posteriorly. 
  • Temporary teeth are replaced by their permanent counterparts, with molars being replaced by premolars.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presents with progressive dyspnea, fatigue, and bilateral lower limb edema. He reports unintentional weight loss and episodes of light-headedness over the past three months. On examination, he has jugular venous distension, pitting edema, and a faint systolic murmur. ECG is shown below. Echocardiography reveals marked thickening of the ventricular walls with a "granular sparkling" appearance and diastolic dysfunction. Cardiac MRI demonstrates diffuse late gadolinium enhancement, and laboratory tests show elevated NT-proBNP and a normal troponin level. Given the likely diagnosis, which of the following medications should be avoided in this patient to minimize the risk of complications?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Digoxin

 

  • Digoxin should be avoided in this patient because infiltrative cardiomyopathies, such as amyloid cardiomyopathy, alter myocardial structure, leading to preferential binding of digoxin to abnormal proteins (amyloid fibrils). 
  • This can cause excessive accumulation and a significantly increased risk of digoxin toxicity, even at therapeutic doses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Spironolactone: Spironolactone is a safe and effective option for managing fluid retention in heart failure, including restrictive cardiomyopathies.

 

Option B. Metoprolol: Beta-blockers like metoprolol are not contraindicated but may require careful monitoring due to the potential risk of bradycardia or worsening symptoms in certain cases.

 

Option D. Diltiazem: Calcium channel blockers, especially nondihydropyridines like diltiazem, are generally avoided in restrictive cardiomyopathies due to their negative inotropic effects, but their contraindication is not as strong as that of digoxin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In patients with restrictive cardiomyopathy, particularly due to infiltrative processes like amyloidosis, digoxin is contraindicated because of its increased risk of toxicity. 
  • Diagnosis and management require careful selection of therapies to address symptoms and minimize adverse effects.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents with a feeling of pelvic pressure and urinary incontinence. Examination reveals a vaginal bulge, where the bladder has prolapsed into the vaginal canal, as shown in the image below. What is the best treatment option for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anterior colporrhaphy

 

  • The given condition in the image is consistent with cystocele (anterior vaginal wall prolapse). An anterior colporrhaphy is the primary surgical treatment for cystocele, where the bladder descends into the vaginal canal. 
  • This procedure strengthens the anterior vaginal wall by reinforcing the tissues, preventing further bladder descent and alleviating associated symptoms such as pelvic pressure and urinary incontinence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Posterior colporrhaphy: This procedure is used for rectocele (posterior vaginal wall prolapse) and strengthens the posterior vaginal wall. It is not appropriate for cystocele repair.

 

Option C. Vaginal hysterectomy: A vaginal hysterectomy is performed in cases of uterine prolapse. It is not the preferred treatment for isolated cystocele unless accompanied by uterine prolapse.

 

Option D. Sacro-colpopexy: Sacro-colpopexy is a procedure for apical (uterine or vaginal vault) prolapse. It involves using mesh to suspend the vaginal apex to the sacrum. It is not used for anterior vaginal wall prolapse alone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cystocele (bladder prolapse) presents as an anterior vaginal bulge and is best treated with anterior colporrhaphy to reinforce the anterior vaginal wall and prevent bladder descent.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with duodenal ulcers and elevated gastrin levels has increased vagally mediated gastrin secretion. Which hormone facilitates this process?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) GRP (Gastrin-releasing peptide)

 

  • Gastrin-releasing peptide (GRP) is a neuropeptide released by vagal nerve endings in the stomach. 
  • GRP binds to G cells in the antrum of the stomach, stimulating the secretion of gastrin, which in turn promotes gastric acid production. 
  • This mechanism is a key component of the cephalic phase of digestion and plays an important role in conditions associated with excessive acid secretion, such as Zollinger-Ellison syndrome and peptic ulcer disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. VIP (Vasoactive intestinal peptide): VIP is a neuropeptide that inhibits gastric acid secretion and promotes smooth muscle relaxation. It is associated with increased intestinal fluid secretion and vasodilation, not stimulation of gastrin secretion.

 

Option B. GIP (Gastric inhibitory peptide): GIP is an incretin hormone that inhibits gastric acid secretion and stimulates insulin release in response to glucose. It does not facilitate gastrin secretion.

 

Option D. GLP (Glucagon-like peptide): GLP is also an incretin hormone that enhances insulin secretion and delays gastric emptying. It does not have a direct role in gastrin release.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • GRP (Gastrin-releasing peptide) is released from vagal nerve endings and stimulates G cells in the stomach to secrete gastrin, which increases gastric acid secretion.

choices.text: Global erectile dysfunction due to psychogenic causes
Performance anxiety with no underlying pathology

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is undergoing a medico-legal evaluation in the context of a divorce proceeding. He reports being unable to engage in sexual intercourse with his spouse, describing significant anxiety and difficulty achieving or maintaining an erection only in her presence. He denies any difficulties in sexual activity with other women or during self-stimulation. Physical examination and laboratory investigations, including testosterone levels, penile blood flow studies, and nocturnal penile tumescence testing, are all normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Impotence quod hanc

 

  • Impotence quod hanc refers to a situation where a man is specifically impotent towards one particular woman, as described in this case. The presence of normal sexual function with other partners and in other contexts (e.g., self-stimulation) strongly suggests that the condition is not related to a physical or systemic cause.
  • It is often attributed to psychological factors, such as unresolved interpersonal conflict, emotional incompatibility, or subconscious aversion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Global erectile dysfunction due to psychogenic causes: Global erectile dysfunction due to psychogenic causes would result in difficulties across all partners and situations, not just with one individual.

 

Option B. Medically-induced erectile dysfunction: Medically-induced erectile dysfunction (e.g., due to medications or chronic illness) would have a physiological basis and affect all sexual interactions, not just one specific partner.

 

Option D. Performance anxiety with no underlying pathology: Performance anxiety may overlap with this condition but is usually not specific to one partner; it tends to be generalized across situations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Impotence quod hanc is a psychosexual condition where a man experiences erectile dysfunction exclusively with one specific partner, despite normal function in other contexts. 
  • It is often related to psychological or interpersonal factors rather than physical causes.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents with a 2-week history of fever, weakness, and bleeding gums. Peripheral blood smear reveals pancytopenia, and a bone marrow biopsy shows 26% blasts with Auer rods and mature myeloid cells. Additionally, neutrophils with pseudo Pelger-Huet anomaly are detected. Which of the following cytochemical stains is most likely to be positive?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Myeloperoxidase

 

  • The presence of Auer rods and myeloid blasts strongly suggests a diagnosis of acute myeloid leukemia (AML). 
  • Specifically, the finding of Auer rods, which are clumps of granular material, indicates myeloid differentiation. 
  • The myeloperoxidase (MPO) stain is the most likely to be positive in this case, as it is used to detect the activity of myeloperoxidase, an enzyme found in the primary granules of myeloid cells. 
  • A positive MPO stain confirms the diagnosis of AML, particularly in cases where Auer rods are present.
  • The bone marrow finding of 26% blasts further supports the diagnosis of AML, as the threshold for AML diagnosis is ≥20% blasts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Non-specific esterase Non-specific esterase is a cytochemical stain that is typically used to identify monoblasts, which are cells of monocytic lineage. It is useful for diagnosing acute monocytic or monoblastic leukemia (M5 subtype) of AML. Since this case involves Auer rods and myeloid cells, which are indicative of a different subtype of AML, non-specific esterase is not the correct stain here.

 

Option B. Acid phosphatase: Acid phosphatase is primarily used in the diagnosis of hairy cell leukemia and other lymphoid malignancies. It is not typically associated with myeloid leukemias, making it an unlikely choice in this scenario.

 

Option D. Toluidine blue: Toluidine blue is a stain used to identify mast cells and basophils, which are involved in mast cell disorders and basophilic leukemias, respectively. This stain is not relevant in the diagnosis of myeloid leukemias, and thus, it is not appropriate for this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In acute myeloid leukemia (AML), particularly when Auer rods are present, myeloperoxidase (MPO) is the most likely cytochemical stain to be positive, confirming myeloid differentiation.

questions.text: A pulmonologist is evaluating a patient with recurrent respiratory infections. Sputum cultures reveal a slow-growing, acid-fast bacillus with positive niacin production and positive arylsulfatase activity. The organism is resistant to thiophene-2-carboxylic acid hydrazide (TCH). What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mycobacterium simiae

 

  • M. simiae is a slow-growing non-tuberculous mycobacterium that is niacin-positive and arylsulfatase-positive. 
  • TCH resistance further supports this diagnosis, as it is resistant like other NTMs (Nontuberculous mycobacteria ).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mycobacterium tuberculosis: While niacin-positive, M. tuberculosis is arylsulfatase-negative and not typically resistant to TCH.

 

Option B. Mycobacterium bovis: M. bovis is niacin-negative and arylsulfatase-negative, ruling it out.

 

Option D. Mycobacterium avium complex: MAC is typically niacin-negative, unlike M. simiae.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • M. simiae is a slow-growing NTM that can produce niacin, is arylsulfatase-positive, and resistant to TCH, distinguishing it from other mycobacterial species.

questions.text: Match the following congenital malformations with their radiological findings:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) iii-A, iv-B, i-C, ii-D

 

  1. Duodenal atresia (C - Double bubble sign): The "double bubble" appearance on imaging is classic for duodenal atresia, caused by dilation of the stomach and proximal duodenum.
  2. Jejunal and ileal atresia (D - Multiple air-fluid levels): These present with multiple air-fluid levels on abdominal radiographs, indicative of small bowel obstruction.
  3. Sigmoid volvulus (A - Coffee bean sign): Sigmoid volvulus shows the characteristic "coffee bean" appearance due to twisted sigmoid colon.
  4. Achalasia cardia (B - Bird beak sign): Achalasia cardia results in a "bird beak" tapering of the lower esophagus on barium swallow imaging.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Understand the radiological signs associated with common congenital gastrointestinal and esophageal conditions to aid in accurate diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old man presents to the emergency department with fever, headache, and generalized body aches for the past 5 days. He recently returned from a hiking trip in rural Assam. On examination, his temperature is 39.5°C (103.1°F), blood pressure is 112/74 mm Hg, and pulse is 98/min. On examination, he has peculiar looking rash which is shown below.

 

 

He also has cervical lymphadenopathy and a faint maculopapular rash on his trunk. Laboratory results show:

 

  • Hemoglobin: 13.2 g/dL
  • Platelets: 90,000/mm³
  • Leukocytes: 8,500/mm³
  • Serum creatinine: 1.2 mg/dL
  • ALT: 56 U/L, AST: 82 U/L

 

Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Doxycycline

 

  • The patient’s presentation, including fever, recent outdoor activity in an endemic area, and the presence of an eschar (black necrotic lesion), strongly suggests scrub typhus caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi. 
  • Doxycycline is the treatment of choice for scrub typhus, effectively targeting the rickettsial organism responsible for the disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ceftriaxone: Ceftriaxone is used for bacterial infections such as meningitis or typhoid fever but is ineffective against rickettsial infections like scrub typhus.

 

Option C. Acyclovir: Acyclovir is an antiviral used for herpes infections and is not effective against bacterial or rickettsial infections.

 

Option D. Amphotericin B: Amphotericin B is an antifungal agent used for systemic fungal infections and is not relevant for scrub typhus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Scrub typhus should be suspected in patients with fever, eschar, and a history of outdoor exposure in endemic areas. 
  • Prompt treatment with doxycycline is critical to prevent complications such as multiorgan failure.

choices.text: Test A has higher validity but lower reliability compared to Test B.
Test A has higher reliability but lower validity compared to Test B.
Test A has both higher reliability and validity compared to Test B.
Test A has lower reliability and lower validity compared to Test B.

questions.text: A laboratory is comparing two tests for measuring hemoglobin levels. Test A produces results consistently around 12 g/dL, while Test B produces results that range from 9 g/dL to 15 g/dL. The true hemoglobin value is 13 g/dL. Which of the following is true regarding these tests?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Test A has higher reliability but lower validity compared to Test B.

 

  • Test A produces consistent results around 12 g/dL, indicating high reliability but lower validity (as the true value is 13 g/dL). 
  • Test B has greater variability (low reliability) but a mean value closer to the true value (higher validity).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A reliable test produces consistent results, while a valid test produces results close to the true value. A test can be reliable but not valid, or vice versa.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with profuse watery diarrhea for the past 3 days, accompanied by lower abdominal pain and mild fever. She was hospitalized 2 weeks ago for pneumonia and treated with intravenous ceftriaxone and oral clarithromycin. Her medical history includes hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. She denies blood in the stool but reports 10–12 watery bowel movements daily. On examination, her temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F), blood pressure is 122/76 mm Hg, and pulse is 98/min. Her abdomen is mildly tender to palpation without rebound or guarding. Laboratory tests show:

 

  • Leukocyte count: 16,200/mm³
  • Serum creatinine: 1.4 mg/dL (baseline 1.0 mg/dL)

 

Colonoscopy image is shown below. 

 

 

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pseudomembranous colitis

 

  • Pseudomembranous colitis, caused by Clostridioides difficile infection, often follows recent antibiotic use, particularly broad-spectrum antibiotics like ceftriaxone or clarithromycin, which disrupt normal gut flora. 
  • This patient’s symptoms of profuse watery diarrhea, abdominal pain, leukocytosis, and a history of antibiotic use strongly suggest C. difficile colitis. 
  • The elevated creatinine indicates potential dehydration or acute kidney injury due to fluid losses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Crohn disease: Crohn disease typically presents with chronic diarrhea, abdominal pain, and systemic symptoms like weight loss. Acute, antibiotic-associated diarrhea is not typical of Crohn disease.

 

Option B. Ischemic colitis: Ischemic colitis typically presents with crampy abdominal pain and bloody diarrhea, usually in older adults with vascular risk factors. The watery diarrhea and leukocytosis in this patient are more consistent with C. difficile colitis.

 

Option D. Viral gastroenteritis: Viral gastroenteritis causes self-limiting diarrhea without significant leukocytosis or a history of recent antibiotic use. The patient’s history and laboratory findings make viral gastroenteritis unlikely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pseudomembranous colitis, caused by C. difficile infection, should be suspected in patients with watery diarrhea and leukocytosis after recent antibiotic use. 
  • Prompt diagnosis and treatment with oral vancomycin or fidaxomicin are essential to prevent complications.

questions.text: A pregnant woman with a history of cardiac disease is on warfarin therapy for anticoagulation. When should the final switch from warfarin to heparin be made to minimize the risk of fetal complications and maternal bleeding during delivery?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 36 weeks

 

  • Warfarin is a teratogenic medication that can cross the placenta and cause fetal hemorrhage, warfarin embryopathy, and fetal anomalies. 
  • However, it is often used in pregnant women with high thromboembolic risk due to mechanical heart valves, as it is more effective than heparin in preventing clot formation. 
  • The recommendation is to switch from warfarin to heparin at 36 weeks of gestation to reduce the risk of maternal bleeding during delivery and prevent fetal complications.
  • Heparin (unfractionated or low-molecular-weight heparin) does not cross the placenta and is safe for both the mother and the fetus. 
  • Switching at 36 weeks provides time for stabilization on heparin before labor or cesarean delivery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For pregnant women on warfarin due to cardiac disease or thromboembolic risk, the final switch to heparin is made at 36 weeks gestation to reduce the risk of bleeding during labor while maintaining effective anticoagulation.

choices.text: Perform daily Doppler assessments and wait for improvement
Administer corticosteroids and delay delivery until 36 weeks

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman at 35 weeks and 3 days of gestation is found to have an amniotic fluid index (AFI) of 5 cm and absent end-diastolic flow (AEDF) in the umbilical artery on Doppler ultrasound. What is the most appropriate next step in her management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Immediate delivery

 

  • Absent end-diastolic flow (AEDF) in the umbilical artery indicates severe placental insufficiency and impending fetal compromise. 
  • At 35+3 weeks of gestation, the risk of continuing the pregnancy outweighs the benefits, as the fetus is at significant risk of hypoxia and intrauterine death. 
  • Immediate delivery is recommended regardless of the AFI, as AEDF is an indication of severe fetal distress.
  • Corticosteroids may be administered if delivery can be briefly delayed, but waiting for improvement or prolonging pregnancy in this scenario is not advised.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Perform daily Doppler assessments and wait for improvement: Once AEDF is detected, daily monitoring is insufficient because the condition suggests advanced placental dysfunction. Continuing to wait may lead to intrauterine fetal demise.

 

Option B. Administer corticosteroids and delay delivery until 36 weeks: Corticosteroids are used to enhance fetal lung maturity before 34 weeks, but at 35+3 weeks, the focus is on immediate delivery rather than delaying for lung maturity, as the risks of continuing the pregnancy are high.

 

Option C. Terminate pregnancy after 37 weeks: Waiting until 37 weeks is inappropriate in the setting of AEDF, as this delay places the fetus at significant risk of stillbirth due to worsening placental insufficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Absent end-diastolic flow (AEDF) on umbilical artery Doppler indicates severe placental insufficiency.
  •  Immediate delivery is necessary to prevent fetal hypoxia and intrauterine fetal death, especially after 34 weeks of gestation.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man with chronic kidney disease presents with worsening fatigue and signs of organ dysfunction. Laboratory studies indicate elevated levels of malondialdehyde, a byproduct of lipid peroxidation. A biopsy of the affected tissue reveals extensive lipid membrane damage with minimal signs of nuclear fragmentation or caspase activation. Which of the following cell death processes best explains the observed findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ferroptosis

 

  • Ferroptosis is a form of iron-dependent, non-apoptotic regulated cell death characterized by excessive lipid peroxidation and cell membrane degradation. 
  • This process is triggered by oxidative stress, particularly when the antioxidant defense system, especially glutathione peroxidase 4 (GPX4), is impaired.
  • The accumulation of malondialdehyde (MDA), a marker of lipid peroxidation, is a hallmark of ferroptosis.

 

Key features of ferroptosis:

 

  • Absence of nuclear fragmentation or caspase activation (distinguishing it from apoptosis).
  • Lipid membrane breakdown with oxidative damage.
  • Conditions such as chronic kidney disease can increase susceptibility due to oxidative stress and iron overload.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pyroptosis: Pyroptosis is an inflammatory form of cell death mediated by caspase-1 and the gasdermin family of proteins. It involves the release of pro-inflammatory cytokines (IL-1β, IL-18) and the formation of membrane pores, leading to cell swelling and lysis. This mechanism is associated with infections and inflammatory diseases, not lipid peroxidation.

 

Option B. Apoptosis: Apoptosis is a programmed, caspase-dependent process characterized by nuclear fragmentation, apoptotic body formation, and minimal inflammatory response. Unlike ferroptosis, apoptosis does not involve lipid peroxidation or the extensive membrane damage seen in this case.

 

Option D. Necroptosis: Necroptosis is a regulated form of necrosis mediated by RIPK1 and RIPK3 kinases and MLKL. It results in cell swelling and plasma membrane rupture but does not feature significant lipid peroxidation. Necroptosis is usually associated with infections, inflammatory diseases, and ischemia-reperfusion injury.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ferroptosis is a regulated form of cell death driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation and oxidative stress. 
  • It differs from apoptosis, necroptosis, and pyroptosis in that it involves extensive lipid membrane degradation without caspase activation or nuclear fragmentation. 
  • Elevated malondialdehyde (MDA) levels serve as a biomarker for lipid peroxidation in this process.

questions.text: A 38-year-old researcher is working on isolating messenger RNA (mRNA) from a patient’s total RNA sample for genetic analysis. The purification process involves using a specific type of chromatography that binds to the poly-A tail of mRNA molecules. Which of the following methods is best suited for this purpose?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Affinity chromatography

 

  • Affinity chromatography is the most commonly used method for purifying mRNA from a mixture of total RNA. 
  • The process involves using beads coated with oligo(dT) sequences that specifically bind to the poly-A tail present on eukaryotic mRNA molecules. 
  • This selective binding allows for the isolation of mRNA while other RNA types (e.g., ribosomal RNA and transfer RNA) are washed away. 
  • After binding, mRNA is eluted and collected for further analysis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gel filtration chromatography: This technique separates molecules based on their size and is a form of size-exclusion chromatography. It is not used to purify mRNA, as different RNA types can have overlapping sizes.

 

Option C. Ion-exchange chromatography: This method separates molecules based on their charge. Since all RNA molecules have similar negative charges due to their phosphate backbone, this method cannot selectively purify mRNA from total RNA.

 

Option D. Size-exclusion chromatography: Size-exclusion chromatography also separates molecules based on size and is ineffective for mRNA purification due to overlapping RNA sizes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Affinity chromatography using oligo(dT) beads is the standard method for purifying mRNA due to the specific interaction between the poly-A tail of mRNA and oligo(dT). 
  • This ensures selective isolation of mRNA from total RNA.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man with HIV presents with a two-week history of malaise and non-productive cough. He has been non-compliant with his HIV medications and has no history of prior hospitalizations. On examination, his temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), blood pressure is 122/70 mm Hg, pulse is 112/min, and oxygen saturation is 90% on room air. Bilateral sternocleidomastoid prominence is observed with respiration, and scattered rhonchi are heard on lung auscultation. Laboratory studies show leukopenia, anemia, and thrombocytopenia. A chest X-ray reveals bilateral patchy interstitial infiltrates. He is started on high-dose intravenous trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX) for presumed Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PJP). The patient should be specifically monitored for which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hyperkalemia

 

  • High-dose trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX) can cause hyperkalemia due to the potassium-sparing effect of trimethoprim, which acts similarly to amiloride by blocking sodium channels in the distal nephron.
