  • Patients receiving TMP-SMX, especially at high doses, should be closely monitored for hyperkalemia, particularly those with underlying renal impairment or other risk factors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anion gap metabolic acidosis: TMP-SMX does not typically cause metabolic acidosis. While metabolic acidosis may occur in sepsis or other conditions, this is not a specific concern related to TMP-SMX therapy.

 

Option C. Hypoglycemia: Hypoglycemia is not a known side effect of TMP-SMX. It is more commonly associated with medications like insulin or sulfonylureas.

 

Option D. Hypophosphatemia: Hypophosphatemia is not a recognized complication of TMP-SMX. Electrolyte disturbances like hyperkalemia and hyponatremia are more relevant concerns.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Trimethoprim in TMP-SMX can cause hyperkalemia by impairing renal potassium excretion. 
  • Close monitoring of serum potassium is essential, especially when high doses are used to treat Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia.

questions.text: Which of the following ligaments links the medial cuneiform bone to the base of the second metatarsal bone?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lisfranc ligament

 

  • The Lisfranc ligament is a strong ligament that connects the medial cuneiform to the base of the second metatarsal bone and is crucial for the stability of the midfoot.
  • An injury to this ligament, commonly known as a Lisfranc injury, can lead to instability and misalignment of the tarsometatarsal joint, often seen in trauma or sports-related injuries. 
  • The ligament stabilizes the midfoot by holding the bones in place and preventing splaying of the metatarsals.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Spring ligament: Also known as the calcaneonavicular ligament, it provides support to the medial longitudinal arch of the foot but does not connect the cuneiform to the metatarsal.

 

Option B. Chopart ligament: This refers to ligaments associated with the Chopart joint complex (talonavicular and calcaneocuboid joints), not the tarsometatarsal joint.

 

Option C. Deltoid ligament: This is a strong, triangular ligament complex that stabilizes the medial aspect of the ankle, not the midfoot.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Lisfranc ligament links the medial cuneiform to the base of the second metatarsal and is vital for midfoot stability. 
  • Lisfranc injuries should be promptly diagnosed to avoid long-term complications such as chronic pain and midfoot instability.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the structural characteristic that differentiates IgG from IgE?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Isotype

 

  • The isotype refers to the differences in the constant region of the heavy chains, which classify immunoglobulins into distinct types (e.g., IgG, IgA, IgE). 
  • IgG and IgE differ in their heavy chain constant regions, which are responsible for their distinct functional properties.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Idiotype: The idiotype defines antigen specificity, not the immunoglobulin class.

 

Option C. Allotypes:  Allotypes involve subtle genetic differences in constant regions but do not define immunoglobulin classes.

 

Option D. Epitope: The epitope refers to the specific part of the antigen recognized by the antibody.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Isotype differences define the immunoglobulin classes, such as IgG and IgE, based on variations in their constant regions.

choices.text: Teprotumumab to target IGF-1 receptor pathways
Immediate orbital decompression to reduce inflammation
Beta-blockers to control the underlying thyroid disease
Extraocular muscle surgery to correct restricted motility

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman with Graves disease is being managed for moderate-to-severe thyroid eye disease. She is started on high-dose systemic steroids, which provide significant relief. After tapering the steroids, she develops a recurrence of symptoms, including worsening proptosis and diplopia. Which of the following therapies is most likely to prevent progression of her disease at this stage?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Teprotumumab to target IGF-1 receptor pathways

 

  • Teprotumumab is indicated for corticosteroid-resistant or relapsing thyroid eye disease. 
  • It directly targets the IGF-1 receptor pathway involved in the pathogenesis of thyroid eye disease, reducing inflammation and proptosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Immediate orbital decompression to reduce inflammation: Orbital decompression is reserved for cases with optic neuropathy or severe proptosis causing functional impairment.

 

Option C. Beta-blockers to control the underlying thyroid disease: Beta-blockers manage hyperthyroidism but do not directly impact the pathophysiology of thyroid eye disease.

 

Option D. Extraocular muscle surgery to correct restricted motility: Extraocular muscle surgery is performed later in the disease course to improve motility and binocular vision.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Teprotumumab is effective in relapsing thyroid eye disease by inhibiting IGF-1 receptor signaling, reducing inflammation, and preventing disease progression.

choices.text: Increased urinary coproporphyrin and δ-aminolevulinic acid (ALA)
Decreased serum ferritin with increased total iron-binding capacity (TIBC)
Positive hemoglobin electrophoresis showing HbS and HbA
Decreased vitamin B12 with increased homocysteine

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with fatigue, weakness, and pale conjunctiva. She works at an antique restoration shop and frequently handles old ceramics and paints. A peripheral smear is performed and finding is shown in the image. Which of the following additional laboratory findings is most consistent with her diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Increased urinary coproporphyrin and δ-aminolevulinic acid (ALA)

 

  • The patient’s occupational exposure and the peripheral smear findings suggest lead poisoning. 
  • Lead inhibits ALAD and ferrochelatase, leading to accumulation of δ-aminolevulinic acid and coproporphyrin, which can be detected in the urine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Decreased serum ferritin with increased total iron-binding capacity (TIBC): Iron deficiency anemia causes microcytic anemia without basophilic stippling or elevated ALA.

 

Option C. Positive hemoglobin electrophoresis showing HbS and HbA: HbS is seen in sickle cell disease, unrelated to lead poisoning.

 

Option D. Decreased vitamin B12 with increased homocysteine: Vitamin B12 deficiency causes macrocytic anemia, not basophilic stippling.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Lead poisoning is characterized by elevated urinary δ-aminolevulinic acid and coproporphyrin due to inhibition of heme synthesis enzymes.

questions.text: A 9-year-old child is brought to the clinic with multiple flat, brownish spots on her cheeks and forehead. The lesions have been gradually increasing in number over the past few months and are especially prominent along lines where she frequently rubs her face against her schoolbag. The spots are smooth and do not cause any itching or discomfort. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Plane Warts

 

  • Plane warts, also known as verruca plana, are characterized by flat-topped, brownish papules that commonly appear on the face, hands, and other areas of the body. 
  • These lesions are typically asymptomatic and can increase in number through the Koebner phenomenon, where new lesions develop along lines of skin trauma or irritation.
  • In this case, the child's lesions following areas of friction from her schoolbag are indicative of the Koebner phenomenon, which is consistent with plane warts. 
  • Plane warts are caused by specific strains of the human papillomavirus (HPV), particularly types 3 and 10. 
  • They present as smooth, flat lesions without significant scaling, erythema, or pruritus, aligning with the description provided.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Molluscum Contagiosum: Molluscum contagiosum presents as dome-shaped, umbilicated papules that are flesh-colored to pink. These lesions are caused by a poxvirus and typically do not exhibit a flat-topped appearance or follow lines of trauma. The absence of umbilication and the presence of umbilicated centers help differentiate it from plane warts.

 

Option C. Psoriasis: Psoriasis typically manifests as well-demarcated, erythematous plaques with silvery scales, commonly found on extensor surfaces like elbows and knees, as well as the scalp. Psoriatic lesions are often itchy and may be associated with nail changes and arthritis. The described brownish, flat-topped lesions without scaling or erythema do not align with the clinical features of psoriasis.

 

Option D. Lichen Planus: Lichen planus presents as pruritic, purple, polygonal, flat-topped papules often found on flexural surfaces and mucous membranes. It is associated with Wickham striae, which are fine, white lines on the surface of the lesions. The absence of pruritus, purple coloration, and Wickham striae in this case makes lichen planus an unlikely diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Plane warts (verruca plana) are identified by their asymptomatic, flat-topped brown papules that commonly appear in children and can spread along lines of skin trauma through the Koebner phenomenon.

questions.text: What is the most common type of lesion in Pott’s Spine?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Paradiscal

 

  • In paradiscal lesions, the infection affects the region adjacent to the intervertebral disc and spreads into the vertebral bodies. 
  • The paradiscal area refers to the portion of the vertebral body near the disc but not directly involving the disc itself. 
  • The infection tends to spread laterally across the vertebral bodies, leading to collapse and significant deformity.
  • Paradiscal lesions are the most common type of tuberculosis involvement in the spine.
  • This type of lesion typically leads to vertebral body destruction, which can result in spinal deformity, kyphosis (hunched back), and neurological deficits due to compression of the spinal cord or nerves.
  • Paravertebral abscesses are commonly seen with this type of lesion, especially in the lower thoracic and upper lumbar regions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anterior:

 

  • Anterior lesions affect the front portion of the vertebral body, and while they may occur in the context of Pott’s spine, they are not as common as paradiscal lesions. The infection may spread forward into the intervertebral disc space, leading to disc collapse.
  • Anterior involvement may result in vertebral body collapse and the formation of an abscess.
  • While anterior lesions do contribute to spinal deformity, they are not the most common pattern seen in Pott's spine.
  • Not the most common lesion in Pott's spine. It can occur but is less typical than paradiscal lesions.

 

Option C. Appendiceal:

 

  • The term appendiceal lesion is not a typical term used in the context of Pott's spine. It may refer to involvement of the appendicular skeleton, which is not a common feature of spinal tuberculosis. 
  • Spinal tuberculosis generally affects the vertebrae and does not usually involve other bones such as the appendicular skeleton (limbs and pelvic girdle).
  • This term is likely misplaced or incorrectly used in this context.
  • Appendiceal involvement does not typically occur in the context of Pott’s spine.

 

Option D. Central:

 

  • Central lesions in Pott’s spine would refer to infection occurring in the central portion of the vertebral body, which is less common compared to paradiscal involvement. 
  • Tuberculosis of the spine usually begins at the paradiscal region and can then progress centrally to affect the vertebral body.
  • While central involvement can contribute to vertebral collapse and deformity, it does not have the same frequency of occurrence as paradiscal lesions.
  • Central lesions may lead to destruction of the vertebral body, but the spread of the infection is more commonly seen at the paradiscal region, which causes both vertebral body destruction and deformity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Paradiscal lesions are the most common type of involvement in Pott’s spine. 
  • This involves the regions adjacent to the intervertebral disc and is typically the starting point of the infection, leading to destruction of the vertebral body, collapse, deformity (such as kyphosis), and the potential formation of abscesses.

choices.text: Turbidity levels of >4 NTU can only be detected by instruments.
Color levels >15 TCU are detectable by the naked eye and are an aesthetic concern.
Taste, odor, and temperature are critical health indicators for water quality.
Turbidity levels <1 NTU always indicate microbial safety.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the physical parameters of drinking water quality as per WHO guidelines is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Color levels >15 TCU are detectable by the naked eye and are an aesthetic concern.

 

  • According to WHO guidelines, color levels >15 TCU are visible to the naked eye and primarily affect water acceptability. 
  • Turbidity >4 NTU is also visible, and taste, odor, and temperature are not health-based indicators. 
  • Turbidity <1 NTU reduces, but does not guarantee, microbial safety.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Turbidity levels of >4 NTU can only be detected by instruments: Turbidity >4 NTU is visible to the naked eye.

 

Option C. Taste, odor, and temperature are critical health indicators: These are aesthetic indicators and not directly health-based.

 

Option D. Turbidity levels <1 NTU always indicate microbial safety: While <1 NTU reduces microbial risks, it does not guarantee safety without further testing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • WHO guidelines emphasize that aesthetic parameters like color and turbidity influence water acceptability, while microbial and chemical tests are necessary for ensuring safety.

choices.text: Identifying populations at risk for targeted interventions
Providing feedback to policymakers for resource allocation
Estimating the economic burden of specific diseases
Monitoring the effectiveness of public health interventions

questions.text: Which of the following activities is not considered a core function of public health surveillance?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Estimating the economic burden of specific diseases

 

  • Estimating the economic burden of diseases is not a core function of public health surveillance. 
  • Surveillance systems focus on the continuous, systematic collection, analysis, and interpretation of health-related data to guide public health actions.
  • These functions include identifying at-risk populations, monitoring the effectiveness of interventions, and providing actionable feedback to policymakers. 
  • Economic assessments, while valuable for decision-making, fall under health economics and cost-effectiveness analysis rather than surveillance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Identifying populations at risk for targeted interventions: This is a core function of public health surveillance. Surveillance data help identify high-risk populations, enabling the design and implementation of targeted health interventions to reduce morbidity and mortality.

 

Option B. Providing feedback to policymakers for resource allocation: Surveillance data are crucial for informing policymakers about disease trends, population health status, and resource needs. This feedback ensures that health resources are allocated effectively.

 

Option D. Monitoring the effectiveness of public health interventions: One of the key objectives of surveillance is to evaluate the impact of public health interventions. By tracking health outcomes over time, surveillance systems can assess whether programs are achieving their desired effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Public health surveillance focuses on monitoring population health, identifying at-risk groups, and evaluating intervention outcomes.
  • Economic assessments, while important, are not a primary function of surveillance systems.

questions.text: Match the following terms with their most appropriate descriptions:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A-2, B-1, C-4, D-3

 

A. Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD): Characterized by obsessions (intrusive, unwanted thoughts) and compulsions (repetitive behaviors), which aim to reduce the distress caused by obsessions. This corresponds to 2.

 

B. Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD): Defined by persistent and excessive worries about minor everyday issues, accompanied by physical symptoms like fatigue, irritability, and poor concentration. This matches 1.

 

C. Depression: A mood disorder presenting with persistent sadness, anhedonia (loss of interest in pleasurable activities), and fatigue for at least two weeks. This aligns with 4.

 

D. Panic Disorder: Characterized by episodic panic attacks, which are sudden, intense periods of fear or discomfort, often with physical symptoms like palpitations, chest pain, and shortness of breath, peaking within minutes. This corresponds to 3.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Differentiate common psychiatric disorders based on hallmark features: OCD involves intrusive thoughts and compulsive behaviors, GAD is marked by excessive worry with physical symptoms, depression includes persistent sadness and loss of interest, and panic disorder presents with sudden episodes of intense fear and physical symptoms.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man is scheduled for cardiopulmonary bypass surgery. He has a history of hypertension and chronic atrial fibrillation, for which he has been taking warfarin. During preoperative planning, his warfarin is stopped, and he is bridged with low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH). What is the best perioperative anticoagulant to use during cardiopulmonary bypass to prevent catheter-induced thrombosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Switch to unfractionated heparin (UFH)

 

  • Unfractionated heparin is the anticoagulant of choice during cardiopulmonary bypass surgery because it can be monitored and reversed easily with protamine sulfate. 
  • LMWH and fondaparinux lack immediate reversal agents suitable for surgical settings, and direct thrombin inhibitors are not used due to a higher bleeding risk and difficulty in monitoring.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Continue LMWH: LMWH is less effective in high-shear environments, such as during bypass procedures, and is not easily reversed perioperatively.

 

Option C. Administer fondaparinux: While effective in preventing deep vein thrombosis, fondaparinux cannot be reversed effectively and is not appropriate for procedures requiring immediate anticoagulant reversal.

 

Option D. Initiate direct thrombin inhibitors: These agents increase the risk of bleeding and are not standard of care for cardiopulmonary bypass surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Unfractionated heparin is the anticoagulant of choice for cardiopulmonary bypass due to its rapid onset, short half-life, and reversibility with protamine sulfate.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents with a recurring pilonidal sinus, and surgical treatment is planned. The image provided shows the surgical procedure performed. Which of the following procedures is depicted for the treatment of a pilonidal sinus?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Limberg flap

 

  • The Limberg flap is a rhomboid excision with transposition flap closure. It involves excising the pilonidal sinus with its surrounding tissue in a rhomboid shape. 
  • A transpositional flap is then created from the surrounding healthy tissue to close the defect. 
  • This technique is widely used for recurrent pilonidal sinus due to its low recurrence rates and effective wound healing.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bascom Procedure: The Bascom procedure is a minimally invasive approach for pilonidal sinus management. It involves excision of the sinus tract and lateral drainage. The primary goal is to minimize wound size and recovery time, making it different from the more extensive Limberg flap.

 

 

Option C. Karydakis Flap: The Karydakis flap is an asymmetrical excision and lateral closure technique. The sinus and surrounding tissue are excised in an elliptical shape, and closure is performed with a lateralized suture line to avoid recurrence. It is also used for pilonidal sinus management but does not involve a rhomboid flap as shown in the image.

 

 

Option D. Gilles Fan Flap: This flap is primarily used in facial or soft tissue reconstruction and is not commonly employed for pilonidal sinus repair. It is not relevant to the procedure depicted in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Limberg flap is an effective surgical technique for the treatment of recurrent pilonidal sinus.
  • It involves rhomboid excision and rotational flap closure, which reduces recurrence rates and promotes rapid healing.
  • Knowledge of various surgical techniques is essential for appropriate management of pilonidal sinus based on clinical presentation and recurrence.

questions.text: What triage category is a ruptured small bowel in the setting of blast trauma going to be tagged?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Yellow

 

 

  • A ruptured small bowel is a life-threatening condition requiring urgent surgical intervention.
  • In blast trauma, this injury risks peritonitis, sepsis, and hemorrhage if not addressed promptly. Therefore, it falls under the yellow category.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A ruptured small bowel in the setting of blast trauma is classified as yellow in the triage system due to the urgent need for surgical intervention to prevent fatal complications such as peritonitis or sepsis.

questions.text: Involvement of DIP, PIP and Sparing of MCP and wrist is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Osteoarthritis

 

  • Osteoarthritis (OA) is a degenerative joint disease that commonly affects weight-bearing joints like the knees, hips, and spine. However, it can also affect the hand joints, particularly in older individuals.
  • OA primarily affects the DIP joints (often called Heberden's nodes) and the PIP joints (often called Bouchard's nodes).
  • The MCP joints and wrists are typically sparing in hand osteoarthritis, which is the distinctive feature in this case.
  • This pattern of DIP and PIP involvement with sparing of MCP and wrist is the hallmark of hand osteoarthritis, where bone spurs or joint space narrowing occur due to the wear and tear of cartilage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rheumatoid Arthritis:

 

  • Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is an autoimmune disorder that primarily affects the synovial joints, leading to inflammation and damage to the joints. RA commonly involves the MCP joints, PIP joints, and wrists, with sparing of the DIP joints.
  • RA typically affects the MCP and PIP joints symmetrically and can also involve the wrists, elbows, knees, and shoulders.
  • The DIP joints are usually spared in RA, making this a distinctive feature of the disease.

 

Option B. Psoriasis:

 

  • Psoriatic arthritis is a seronegative spondyloarthropathy associated with psoriasis, an autoimmune skin disorder. It can cause joint involvement with a variety of patterns, including asymmetrical, symmetric, and distal joint involvement.
  • Psoriatic arthritis can involve the DIP joints, PIP joints, and MCP joints. In particular, the DIP joints are more commonly affected than in rheumatoid arthritis.
  • The MCP joints can sometimes be involved, but it is often the DIP joints that are characteristically affected in psoriatic arthritis.

 

Option C. Hyperparathyroidism:

 

  • Hyperparathyroidism refers to an overactivity of the parathyroid glands, leading to elevated levels of parathyroid hormone (PTH). This condition can cause bone resorption, particularly affecting the bones of the hands.
  • Hyperparathyroidism can lead to soft tissue calcifications, osteopenia, and subperiosteal resorption (particularly in the fingers).
  • Joint involvement is less prominent compared to other conditions, but joint deformities and erosions in the DIP joints may occur.
  • However, joint involvement is typically not as pronounced in the way it is seen in osteoarthritis or psoriatic arthritis, and it does not show a characteristic pattern of sparing the wrist and MCP joints.
  • Hyperparathyroidism can cause bone changes, it typically does not lead to the specific pattern of joint involvement seen here, where the DIP and PIP joints are affected but the MCP and wrist joints are spared.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Rheumatoid arthritis typically affects the MCP and PIP joints and spares the DIP joints, so it is not the correct answer.
  • Psoriatic arthritis can involve the DIP joints, but it may also affect the MCP joints, so it does not perfectly match the described pattern.
  • Hyperparathyroidism can cause bone resorption, particularly in the hands, but it is not as characteristic of the joint involvement described here.
  • Osteoarthritis, on the other hand, most commonly affects the DIP and PIP joints and spares the MCP and wrist joints.

questions.text: The unequal distribution of ions across the plasma membrane, described by the Gibbs-Donnan equilibrium, is primarily due to the presence of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Intracellular proteins

 

  • The Gibbs-Donnan equilibrium describes the distribution of ions across a semipermeable membrane in the presence of impermeant charged molecules, such as intracellular proteins. 
  • These negatively charged proteins cannot cross the cell membrane, causing an unequal distribution of permeant ions (e.g., sodium, potassium, chloride) to maintain electrochemical balance. 
  • This leads to a higher concentration of cations (like sodium) outside the cell and anions (like chloride) inside the cell, contributing to osmotic pressure regulation and ion balance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bicarbonate ion: Bicarbonate primarily buffers the extracellular space and plays a minimal role in the intracellular ion distribution or the Gibbs-Donnan effect.

 

Option B. Calcium ion: Calcium ions are mainly found extracellularly and play a role in signaling, but they are not involved in the establishment of the Gibbs-Donnan equilibrium.

 

Option C. Sodium: Sodium (Na⁺) is a major extracellular cation and contributes to maintaining membrane potential through the sodium-potassium pump. However, its distribution across the membrane is actively maintained by ATP-dependent transport rather than being a direct result of the Gibbs-Donnan equilibrium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Gibbs-Donnan equilibrium is maintained by the presence of impermeant negatively charged intracellular proteins that create an unequal distribution of ions across the membrane to balance the electrochemical gradient.

questions.text: Which of these is the likely etiology for the given finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Filariasis

 

  • The image shows a classic presentation of lymphedema, specifically elephantiasis, which is most commonly caused by filariasis in endemic regions. 
  • Filariasis is a parasitic infection caused by the Wuchereria bancrofti or Brugia malayi worms, transmitted by mosquitoes. 
  • Chronic infection leads to lymphatic obstruction, resulting in significant swelling and fibrosis, typically affecting the lower extremities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Post ilio-inguinal block dissection: Lymphedema can occur after surgical removal of lymph nodes, such as in ilio-inguinal dissections, but this is a less common cause compared to filariasis, especially in endemic areas.

 

Option B. Varicose veins: Varicose veins can lead to chronic venous insufficiency and swelling, but they do not typically cause the severe lymphatic obstruction and skin changes seen in elephantiasis.

 

Option C. Heart failure: May lead to pedal edema, often affecting both legs symmetrically.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Filariasis is the most common cause of elephantiasis in endemic regions, leading to lymphedema due to lymphatic obstruction.
  • It is important to recognize the characteristic appearance and consider the patient's geographical background for accurate diagnosis and management.

choices.text: Reduced risk of QT interval prolongation
Minimal risk of extrapyramidal side effects
Negligible risk of metabolic adverse effects
Availability in a long-acting injectable form

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a history of bipolar disorder is being treated with quetiapine for mood stabilization. During a follow-up visit, his psychiatrist decides to switch him to ziprasidone. Which of the following best describes a major advantage of ziprasidone over quetiapine?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Negligible risk of metabolic adverse effects

 

  • Ziprasidone has a negligible risk of metabolic adverse effects, such as weight gain, hyperlipidemia, and new-onset diabetes mellitus, making it a preferred choice for patients with metabolic concerns.
  • While both ziprasidone and quetiapine are atypical antipsychotics, ziprasidone is associated with fewer metabolic complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reduced risk of QT interval prolongation: Ziprasidone has a higher potential to prolong the QT interval compared to other atypical antipsychotics.

 

Option B. Minimal risk of extrapyramidal side effects: While ziprasidone has a low risk of extrapyramidal side effects, this is not its primary advantage over quetiapine.

 

Option D. Availability in a long-acting injectable form: Ziprasidone is not available in a long-acting injectable form.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ziprasidone has a negligible risk of metabolic adverse effects, making it a preferred option for patients at risk of weight gain, hyperlipidemia, or diabetes mellitus.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman underwent a modified radical mastectomy for breast cancer. A few days after the surgery, she presents with swelling and a fluid collection beneath the skin flaps in her axillary region. Which of the following is the most common complication following mastectomy surgery?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Seroma

 

  • A seroma is the accumulation of fluid beneath the skin flaps after surgery, particularly in the axilla following mastectomy and axillary lymph node dissection.
  • It is the most common complication of mastectomy, occurring in approximately 30% of cases.
  • Seromas can lead to discomfort, delayed wound healing, and an increased risk of infection if not adequately drained.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lymphoedema: Lymphoedema is swelling that occurs due to the disruption of lymphatic drainage, which can happen after axillary lymph node dissection. While it is a well-known complication of mastectomy, it is less common than seroma formation in the immediate postoperative period.

 

Option C. Wound infection: Wound infections can occur after any surgical procedure, including mastectomy. However, the incidence of seroma formation is higher than that of wound infections.

 

Option D. Intercostobrachial nerve injury: Injury to the intercostobrachial nerve, leading to numbness or paresthesia in the upper arm, is a recognized complication of mastectomy, but it is less common compared to seroma formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Seroma is the most common complication following mastectomy, occurring in approximately 30% of cases and requires management to prevent infection and promote healing.

choices.text: Isoniazid and rifapentine weekly for 3 months

questions.text: 40-year-old woman is evaluated before starting anti-tumor necrosis factor (TNF) therapy for rheumatoid arthritis. As part of her pre-treatment screening, a tuberculin skin test is performed and shows 12 mm of induration at 48 hours. She has no symptoms such as fever, cough, weight loss, or night sweats. She immigrated from India as a child but has lived in the United States for the past 30 years. A chest X-ray is unremarkable, and sputum testing for acid-fast bacilli is negative. She has no prior history of tuberculosis (TB) or known exposure to individuals with active TB. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Isoniazid for 9 months

 

  • This patient has latent TB infection (LTBI), indicated by a positive tuberculin skin test (≥10 mm induration in individuals from TB-endemic areas) without evidence of active disease. 
  • Anti-TNF therapy increases the risk of reactivating latent TB, making treatment of LTBI essential prior to starting immunosuppressive therapy. Isoniazid for 9 months is the preferred regimen for LTBI and has been shown to significantly reduce the risk of reactivation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. No treatment: Without treatment, the patient’s LTBI could progress to active TB due to immunosuppression from anti-TNF therapy. Treatment is essential in this context.

 

Option C. Rifampin for 4 months: Rifampin is an alternative treatment for LTBI, but isoniazid for 9 months is preferred for most patients. Rifampin may be used if isoniazid is contraindicated or poorly tolerated.

 

Option D. Isoniazid and rifapentine weekly for 3 months: This regimen is an effective option for LTBI but typically requires directly observed therapy (DOT), which may not always be practical.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Screening and treatment of latent TB are essential before initiating anti-TNF therapy to prevent reactivation. 
  • Isoniazid for 9 months is the standard treatment for LTBI in most patients, especially those at high risk of reactivation due to immunosuppression.

choices.text: Extensor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis
Abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis
Abductor pollicis brevis and extensor digiti minimi
Abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis longus

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with pain along the radial side of her wrist, which began after repeatedly lifting her infant. She reports difficulty gripping objects due to pain. On physical examination, tenderness is noted over the first dorsal compartment, and ulnar deviation of the wrist while the thumb is flexed elicits sharp pain. This test result supports the diagnosis of De Quervain's tenosynovitis. Which of the following tendons are inflamed in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis

 

  • De Quervain's tenosynovitis is an inflammatory condition that affects the first dorsal compartment of the wrist. This compartment contains the tendons of:
  1. Abductor pollicis longus (APL)
  2. Extensor pollicis brevis (EPB)
  • Inflammation of the synovial sheath surrounding these tendons leads to pain during thumb movement and wrist use, especially when gripping or lifting. 

 

The Finkelstein test, where the patient makes a fist around the thumb and the wrist is ulnar-deviated, elicits pain in this condition.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • De Quervain's tenosynovitis involves the inflammation of the abductor pollicis longus (APL) and extensor pollicis brevis (EPB) tendons within the first dorsal compartment of the wrist.
  • It presents with pain during thumb abduction and extension, often confirmed by a positive Finkelstein test.

questions.text: Who is considered the father of modern anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) William Morton

 

  • William Morton is recognized as the father of modern anesthesia. 
  • He was the first to explore the properties of ether and study its use as an anesthetic. 
  • Morton's investigations laid the groundwork for the physiology of general anesthesia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. John Snow: John Snow is acknowledged as the father of anesthesia due to his pioneering work in the administration of chloroform and ether for surgical procedures. He is also considered the father of modern epidemiology for his work on cholera outbreaks.

 

Option B. August Bier: August Bier is known for his contributions to regional anesthesia and was the first to perform spinal anesthesia in a clinical setting.

 

Option D. Joseph Priestley: Joseph Priestley is credited with the discovery of oxygen and the preparation of nitrous oxide, but he is not associated with modern anesthesia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • William Morton is credited as the father of modern anesthesia due to his ground breaking work with ether as an anesthetic agent, establishing its use in surgical procedures.

choices.text: Keratinized epithelium, submucosa, and minor salivary glands
Keratinized epithelium, absent submucosa, and no salivary glands
Non-keratinized epithelium, submucosa, and minor salivary glands
Non-keratinized epithelium, absent submucosa, and minor salivary glands

questions.text: Which of the following correctly describes the features of the hard palate?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Keratinized epithelium, submucosa, and minor salivary glands

 

  • The hard palate is part of the oral cavity’s masticatory mucosa and is covered by keratinized stratified squamous epithelium. 
  • The epithelium provides resistance to friction during mastication. The hard palate also contains a submucosa, which varies in thickness and supports the epithelium. 
  • This submucosa contains minor salivary glands, which secrete mucus to aid in lubrication.

 

Key features of the hard palate:

 

  • Epithelium: Keratinized stratified squamous epithelium.
  • Submucosa: Present, containing connective tissue and minor salivary glands.
  • Function: Provides a firm surface for mastication and separates the oral and nasal cavities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The hard palate is covered by keratinized stratified squamous epithelium with an underlying submucosa containing minor salivary glands. This structure supports the masticatory function of the oral cavity.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man presents with severe shortness of breath. Echocardiography reveals mitral stenosis and left atrial hypertrophy. During surgery, vegetations are found on the mitral valve and are excised. The histopathological examination of the excised vegetations is shown in the image below. Based on the histopathological findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rheumatic heart disease

 

  • The histopathological image shows Aschoff bodies, which are characteristic of rheumatic heart disease (RHD). 
  • Aschoff bodies are granulomatous structures found in the myocardium during acute rheumatic fever. 
  • Rheumatic heart disease develops as a sequela of acute rheumatic fever, typically following an infection with group A Streptococcus. 
  • This condition leads to chronic inflammation, fibrosis, and valvular deformity, most commonly affecting the mitral valve. 
  • The presence of vegetations on the mitral valve in a patient with mitral stenosis strongly suggests rheumatic valvular disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nonbacterial thrombotic endocarditis (NBTE): Incorrect. NBTE is associated with hypercoagulable states and malignancies, leading to the formation of sterile vegetations on heart valves. These vegetations are typically non-inflammatory and lack the granulomatous changes seen in Aschoff bodies.

 

Option C. Libman-Sacks endocarditis: Incorrect. Libman-Sacks endocarditis is associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and involves the formation of sterile vegetations on heart valves, particularly the mitral and aortic valves. However, these vegetations are not associated with Aschoff bodies or the granulomatous changes seen in rheumatic heart disease.

 

Option D. Cardiac amyloidosis: Incorrect. Cardiac amyloidosis is characterized by the deposition of amyloid in the myocardium, leading to restrictive cardiomyopathy. It does not present with valvular vegetations or granulomatous inflammation like Aschoff bodies, which are specific to rheumatic heart disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Rheumatic heart disease (RHD) is a chronic consequence of acute rheumatic fever, characterized by valvular damage and granulomatous changes such as Aschoff bodies. 
  • It most frequently affects the mitral valve, leading to mitral stenosis.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man with a history of heavy smoking presents with hemoptysis and chronic cough. A bronchoscopy reveals a centrally located mass with cavitation, and a biopsy shows an undifferentiated tumor. Which immunohistochemical (IHC) marker is most useful for confirming the diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cytokeratin

 

  • History of smoking, central mass and cavitation are highly suggestive squamous cell carcinoma of the the lung.
  • Cytokeratin is an intermediate filament protein found in epithelial cells and is crucial in identifying squamous cell carcinoma 
  • Small-cell lung carcinoma (SCLC) is a high-grade, undifferentiated carcinoma of epithelial origin which on IHC shows expression of synaptophysin, and chromogranin. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HMB-45: Marker for melanocytic tumors such as melanoma. Irrelevant in lung carcinoma diagnosis.

 

Option B. Chromogranin: Marker for neuroendocrine tumors (including SCLC), but cytokeratin is essential for confirming epithelial origin in undifferentiated tumors.

 

Option C. Parvalbumin: A calcium-binding protein used to detect certain neuroendocrine neoplasms, but less commonly used in lung cancer diagnosis compared to chromogranin or synaptophysin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For undifferentiated centrally located lung tumors in heavy smokers, immunohistochemical markers like cytokeratin confirm epithelial origin, distinguishing carcinomas from other tumors such as neuroendocrine or melanoma-related malignancies.

choices.text: Prilocaine and benzocaine are metabolized to o-toluidine, which directly reduces hemoglobin levels
Benzocaine and cetacaine used as topical sprays are associated with methemoglobinemia
Methemoglobinemia caused by prilocaine cannot be treated with methylene blue
Methylene blue is ineffective in reducing methemoglobin (Fe³⁺) to hemoglobin (Fe²⁺)

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the side effects of prilocaine and benzocaine?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Benzocaine and cetacaine used as topical sprays are associated with methemoglobinemia.

 

  • Benzocaine and cetacaine, often used as topical anesthetic sprays, can cause significant methemoglobinemia, a condition where hemoglobin is oxidized to methemoglobin, impairing oxygen delivery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Prilocaine and benzocaine are metabolized to o-toluidine, which directly reduces hemoglobin levels: Incorrect. Prilocaine is metabolized to o-toluidine, which increases methemoglobin levels, not directly reducing hemoglobin levels.

 

Option C. Methemoglobinemia caused by prilocaine cannot be treated with methylene blue: Incorrect. Methemoglobinemia caused by prilocaine is effectively treated with intravenous methylene blue (1–2 mg/kg of a 1% solution over 5 minutes).

 

Option D. Methylene blue is ineffective in reducing methemoglobin (Fe³⁺) to hemoglobin (Fe²⁺): Incorrect. Methylene blue acts as a reducing agent, converting methemoglobin (Fe³⁺) back to hemoglobin (Fe²⁺).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Prilocaine and benzocaine can cause methemoglobinemia due to their metabolism. 
  • Prilocaine is metabolized to o-toluidine, while benzocaine and cetacaine, used as topical sprays, also pose significant risks. 
  • Methemoglobinemia is treated with intravenous methylene blue, which restores normal hemoglobin levels by reducing methemoglobin.

questions.text: A pharmaceutical company conducts a cross-over study to compare the efficacy of two antihypertensive medications, Drug X and Drug Y. Participants receive Drug X for 4 weeks, undergo a 2-week washout period, and then receive Drug Y for 4 weeks. Upon analyzing the data, researchers observe that blood pressure measurements during the Drug Y phase are significantly lower than during the Drug X phase. However, they also note a progressive decrease in blood pressure readings over the entire study duration, irrespective of the treatment administered. Which of the following phenomena is most likely responsible for this observation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Period effect

 

  • A period effect refers to changes in the outcome variable that occur due to the passage of time rather than the specific treatments administered.
  • In this scenario, the progressive decrease in blood pressure over time, regardless of whether the participant is receiving Drug X or Drug Y, suggests a period effect.
  • This could be due to factors such as lifestyle modifications, increased adherence to study protocols, or other time-related influences that affect blood pressure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carryover effect: This occurs when the effects of the first treatment persist into the period when the second treatment is administered. The presence of a washout period is intended to minimize this effect. In this case, the consistent decline over time does not align with a carryover effect.

 

Option C. Regression to the mean: This statistical phenomenon occurs when extreme measurements tend to move closer to the average upon subsequent testing. It does not adequately explain a continuous downward trend over the study period.

 

Option D. Sequence effect: This refers to differences in outcomes depending on the order in which treatments are administered. The observed trend is independent of treatment sequence, making this explanation less likely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In cross-over studies, period effects can influence outcomes independently of the treatments being tested. Researchers must account for these effects to ensure accurate interpretation of results.

questions.text: Mrs. Payal, 56-year-old postmenopausal woman presents with sudden onset chest pain and shortness of breath following the unexpected death of her spouse. Her ECG shows ST-segment elevation in leads V2-V4. Coronary angiography reveals no significant coronary artery stenosis. Echocardiography is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Stress Cardiomyopathy

 

  • Stress cardiomyopathy, also known as Takotsubo cardiomyopathy or "broken heart syndrome," often occurs after acute emotional or physical stress. 
  • It mimics acute coronary syndrome but is characterized by transient left ventricular dysfunction, commonly with apical ballooning on echocardiography and absence of significant coronary artery disease on angiography.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute Myocardial Infarction (AMI): AMI typically involves significant coronary artery stenosis or occlusion, which is absent in this case.

 

Option B. Pericarditis: Pericarditis presents with diffuse ST-elevation and PR-depression on ECG, not limited to leads V2-V4, and does not cause apical ballooning.

 

Option D. Dilated Cardiomyopathy: Dilated cardiomyopathy is a chronic condition leading to global ventricular dilation and systolic dysfunction, not acute apical ballooning triggered by stress.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Stress cardiomyopathy is an acute, stress-induced cardiac condition that mimics acute coronary syndrome. 
  • It is distinguished by transient left ventricular dysfunction, absence of obstructive coronary artery disease, and characteristic apical ballooning pattern on echocardiography.

questions.text: The following procedure is done for which of these conditions?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hemorrhoids

 

  • The image shows a stapled hemorrhoidopexy (commonly known as PPH—Procedure for Prolapse and Hemorrhoids). 
  • This technique is specifically performed for hemorrhoids. It involves the use of a circular stapler to excise a circumferential ring of redundant mucosa and submucosa above the dentate line, thereby lifting the hemorrhoidal tissue back into its anatomical position and reducing blood flow to the hemorrhoids. 
  • This method is commonly used for second-degree and third-degree hemorrhoids.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fissure in ano: Fissure in ano is a longitudinal tear in the anoderm and is typically managed conservatively or with lateral internal sphincterotomy. Stapled hemorrhoidopexy is not indicated for fissures.

 

Option C. Fistula in ano: Fistula in ano, an abnormal connection between the anal canal and perianal skin, is usually treated surgically with procedures such as fistulotomy, seton placement, or advancement flaps. Stapled hemorrhoidopexy is not used in this condition.

 

Option D.  Anal canal cancer: Anal canal cancer is a malignancy of the anal canal and is treated with chemoradiation or surgical resection depending on the stage. Stapled hemorrhoidopexy is not a treatment option for anal cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Stapled hemorrhoidopexy is a minimally invasive surgical procedure used for treating second and third-degree hemorrhoids. 
  • It reduces prolapse and restores normal anatomy while causing less postoperative pain compared to traditional hemorrhoidectomy.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presents with primary amenorrhea. She has a normal stature, absent breast development and her laboratory evaluation shows elevated FSH and LH levels. Her karyotype is 46, XX. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gonadal dysgenesis

 

  • Gonadal dysgenesis refers to underdeveloped or absent gonadal tissue despite the presence of a normal female karyotype (46, XX).
  •  In this condition, the ovaries fail to produce adequate estrogen, leading to primary amenorrhea and absent secondary sexual characteristics (e.g., breast development). 
  • Since the ovaries are not functioning, there is no negative feedback on the hypothalamic-pituitary axis, resulting in high FSH and LH levels. The absence of testosterone and a female phenotype with primary amenorrhea are consistent with 46, XX gonadal dysgenesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Turner syndrome: Turner syndrome (45, X) presents with short stature, webbed neck, and characteristic dysmorphic features. The karyotype is not 46, XX in Turner syndrome.

 

Option B. Testicular feminization syndrome (Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome):  In this condition, the karyotype is 46, XY, and the phenotype appears female due to androgen receptor insensitivity. However, affected individuals typically have normal breast development due to peripheral conversion of testosterone to estrogen.

 

Option D. Kallmann syndrome: Kallmann syndrome is associated with hypogonadotropic hypogonadism due to low FSH and LH levels caused by defective GnRH secretion. This differs from the elevated gonadotropins seen in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Gonadal dysgenesis in a 46, XX female presents with primary amenorrhea, absent secondary sexual characteristics, and elevated gonadotropins (FSH, LH) due to the failure of ovarian estrogen production.

choices.text: The fetus is in breech presentation
The fetus is in cephalic presentation
The fetus is in transverse lie

questions.text: A 30-year-old primigravida at 32 weeks gestation undergoes an antenatal examination. On abdominal palpation, the fundal grip reveals a broad, firm, non-ballotable structure. What is the most likely fetal presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The fetus is in cephalic presentation

 

  • In Leopold’s maneuvers, the fundal grip assesses the structure at the uterine fundus.
  • A firm, broad, non-ballotable structure at the fundus typically corresponds to the fetal breech (buttocks). 
  • This indicates that the head, which is firmer, round, and ballotable, is positioned lower in the pelvis, consistent with cephalic presentation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The fetus is in Breech presentation: In breech presentation, the fetal head, being hard, rounded, and ballotable, would be felt at the fundus rather than a broad structure like the buttocks.

 

Option C. The fetus is in Transverse lie: In transverse lie, the fetal long axis is perpendicular to the maternal axis, and neither the head nor the breech is typically palpable in the fundus. Instead, the fetus lies sideways, making palpation findings irregular.

 

Option D. The Presentation cannot be determined: In this case, the clear finding of a broad, firm, non-ballotable structure at the fundus and a non-ballotable head suggests that the presentation can be identified as cephalic with high confidence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • During abdominal examination, a firm, broad, non-ballotable structure at the fundus typically represents the fetal breech, indicating a cephalic presentation at the lower pole of the uterus.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman undergoes a normal vaginal delivery. During the third stage of labor, the placenta is observed to separate with the maternal surface presenting first, accompanied by significant bleeding. What type of placental separation pattern does this indicate?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Duncan method

 

  • The Duncan method of placental separation occurs when the maternal surface of the placenta separates first, typically from the lateral margins. 
  • This leads to a slower detachment and increased bleeding compared to the Schultze method, where the fetal side separates first. 
  • In the Duncan method, blood often tracks down along the uterine wall and exits before the placenta, appearing as continuous vaginal bleeding.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Schultze method: In the Schultze method, the placenta separates centrally, and the fetal side (shiny side) presents first. Blood is contained within the membranes and exits only after the placenta is expelled, resulting in minimal visible bleeding during placental expulsion.

 

Option C. Partial placental separation: This refers to incomplete detachment of the placenta, which can lead to retained placental tissue and postpartum hemorrhage. This condition does not describe the characteristic maternal surface presentation seen in the Duncan method.

 

Option D. Marginal placental separation: This term is not commonly used as a distinct placental separation method. It may refer to the initial point of detachment but is not a recognized clinical descriptor for full placental separation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Duncan method of placental separation is characterized by the maternal surface of the placenta presenting first, accompanied by more visible bleeding compared to the Schultze method, where the fetal surface presents first and bleeding is contained until expulsion.

questions.text: In a patient, the hypothalamic thermostat was reset from point V to point X on the graph. Which of the following happens in stage W compared to stage Y?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Shivering

 

  • In the context of thermoregulation, stage W corresponds to the phase where the body temperature is rising to meet the new hypothalamic set point (from V to X), while stage Y corresponds to the phase where the body temperature is falling back to the original set point (from X to Z). 
  • During stage W, mechanisms that generate heat, such as shivering, are activated to raise the body temperature to the new set point. 
  • In contrast, during stage Y, the body activates mechanisms to dissipate heat, such as sweating and increased blood flow to the skin, to lower the temperature.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sweating: Sweating occurs during stage Y when the body is attempting to lower its temperature after the set point has been reset to normal.

 

Option C. Increased blood flow to skin: This also happens during stage Y to help dissipate heat and lower body temperature.

 

Option D. Inhibition of chemical thermogenesis: This occurs during stage Y to reduce heat production as the body cools down.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • During stage W, when the body is raising its temperature to match a new set point, shivering is the primary mechanism activated to generate heat.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman is diagnosed with gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN). Imaging studies reveal that the neoplasm has metastasized to her lungs. According to the FIGO staging system for GTN, which stage corresponds to this finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Stage III

 

  • Gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN) is staged based on the FIGO (International Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics) classification:
  • Stage I: Disease is confined to the uterus.
  • Stage II: GTN extends to the pelvis and/or vagina.
  • Stage III: GTN has metastasized to the lungs (with or without genital tract involvement).
  • Stage IV: GTN has distant metastasis to organs beyond the lungs (e.g., brain, liver).
  • In this case, lung metastasis is consistent with Stage III disease. GTN with pulmonary metastases can still have a favorable prognosis with appropriate chemotherapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In gestational trophoblastic neoplasia, lung metastases classify the disease as Stage III according to FIGO staging. 
  • Proper staging is critical for guiding management and determining prognosis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old sexually active male presents with brownish spots on his torso, shiny moist genital lesions, and patchy hair thinning with flaky skin. He has a history of multiple unprotected sexual encounters. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Treponema pallidum

 

  • The patient's presentation is highly suggestive of secondary syphilis, which is caused by the spirochete Treponema pallidum. Key features supporting this diagnosis include:
    • Asymptomatic macules on the torso: Secondary syphilis commonly presents with a widespread macular rash that often involves the trunk and can appear as brownish spots. These lesions are typically nonpruritic and gradually increase in number.
    • Moist, grey-colored lesions in the perianal region: These are known as Condylomata lata, which are highly characteristic of secondary syphilis. They appear as moist, flat-topped, greyish lesions in intertriginous areas such as the genital and perianal regions.
    • Patchy hair loss with scaling on the scalp: Referred to as "moth-eaten alopecia," this manifestation is associated with secondary syphilis and involves patchy thinning of scalp hair accompanied by scaling.
    • History of unprotected sexual activity: The patient's recent history of unprotected sexual encounters increases the likelihood of a sexually transmitted infection like syphilis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trichophyton: Incorrect because Trichophyton species are dermatophytes that cause fungal infections such as tinea capitis (scalp ringworm) and tinea corporis. While Trichophyton can lead to patchy hair loss and scaling of the scalp, it does not account for the asymptomatic macules on the chest or the moist perianal lesions characteristic of secondary syphilis.

 

Option C. Malassezia: Incorrect because Malassezia is a genus of fungi responsible for conditions like tinea versicolor, which presents as hypo- or hyperpigmented macules on the trunk. However, Malassezia does not cause moist perianal lesions or patchy alopecia, making it an unlikely cause in this scenario.

 

Option D. Microsporum: Incorrect because Microsporum species are also dermatophytes that cause fungal infections such as tinea capitis. Similar to Trichophyton, Microsporum can lead to scalp scaling and hair loss but does not explain the chest macules or perianal moist lesions seen in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Secondary syphilis, caused by Treponema pallidum, presents with a combination of asymptomatic macular rashes on the trunk, moist Condylomata lata in intertriginous areas (such as the perianal region), and patchy alopecia with scaling on the scalp (moth-eaten alopecia).

questions.text: A 50-year-old historian is giving a lecture on ancient legal codes and their impact on society. He mentions a historical figure who was responsible for creating one of the earliest known codifications of medical practice, including detailed laws governing the conduct and fees of physicians. Which of the following individuals is most likely being referred to in this context?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hammurabi

 

  • Hammurabi, the sixth king of Babylon, is known for the Code of Hammurabi, one of the earliest and most comprehensive written legal codes in history. 
  • This code included specific provisions related to medical practice, detailing fees for services and penalties for medical malpractice. 
  • It represents one of the first attempts to standardize and regulate the medical profession, highlighting the importance of accountability in healthcare.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aristotle: Aristotle was an influential Greek philosopher and scientist whose contributions were significant in biology, ethics, and various branches of philosophy. However, he did not create any legal codes or regulations for medical practice.

 

Option B. Hippocrates: Hippocrates is often referred to as the "Father of Medicine" and is known for the Hippocratic Oath, which outlines ethical principles for physicians. However, this was not a legal codification of medical practice like Hammurabi’s code.

 

Option C. Socrates: Socrates was a classical Greek philosopher known for his contributions to ethics and epistemology. He had no association with codifying medical practices or legal systems related to healthcare.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hammurabi's Code included some of the earliest legal regulations of medical practice, emphasizing the significance of accountability and professional standards in ancient healthcare systems.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male with a history of recurrent epigastric pain and dyspepsia undergoes an upper GI endoscopy, revealing gastric mucosal inflammation with a possible ulcer. A biopsy is taken, and the image shows the result of a special stain used to identify the organism involved. Which of the following stains is most likely depicted in the image?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Warthin-Starry silver stain

 

  • The Warthin-Starry stain is a silver-based stain commonly used to detect Helicobacter pylori, a spiral-shaped, Gram-negative bacterium associated with gastritis and peptic ulcer disease.
  • In this stain, the H. pylori appear as dark, spiral-shaped structures against the background of the gastric epithelial lining, as shown in the image.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Masson-Fontana stain: This stain is used to detect melanin and other substances, such as argentaffin granules, and is not specific for bacterial organisms.

 

Option B. Periodic Acid Schiff (PAS) stain: PAS stain highlights glycoproteins, mucin, and fungal elements, which appear magenta. It is not used for identifying H. pylori.

 

Option C. Gomori's methenamine silver stain: This is primarily used for fungal organisms and is especially useful for staining Pneumocystis jirovecii cysts. It is not typically used for H. pylori detection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Warthin-Starry stain is a silver stain used to detect H. pylori, which appears as spiral-shaped, dark-staining bacteria. 
  • This stain is crucial in diagnosing H. pylori-related gastritis and peptic ulcer disease.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presents with recurrent vertebral compression fractures and a diagnosis of osteoporosis. She is started on a bisphosphonate as part of her treatment. The medication acts by inhibiting farnesyl pyrophosphate synthase. Which of the following is the primary therapeutic effect of this medication?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Induction of apoptosis in osteoclasts

 

  • Bisphosphonates, such as risedronate, inhibit farnesyl pyrophosphate synthase in the mevalonate pathway. 
  • This inhibition prevents the prenylation of small GTPase proteins required for osteoclast function, leading to disruption of cytoskeletal integrity, reduced bone resorption activity, and eventual induction of osteoclast apoptosis.
  • These effects slow bone resorption, thereby increasing bone mineral density and reducing fracture risk in osteoporosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decreased recruitment of osteoclast precursors: Incorrect. Bisphosphonates primarily act on mature osteoclasts, not by inhibiting the recruitment of osteoclast precursors.

 

Option C. Stimulation of osteoblast proliferation: Incorrect. Bisphosphonates do not directly stimulate osteoblasts; their effect is on reducing bone resorption by osteoclasts.

 

Option D. Reduction of osteocyte apoptosis: Incorrect. While bisphosphonates may have indirect effects on osteocytes, their primary mechanism involves osteoclast apoptosis.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • Bisphosphonates, including risedronate, inhibit farnesyl pyrophosphate synthase in the mevalonate pathway, leading to osteoclast apoptosis and reduced bone resorption.
  • This mechanism improves bone density and reduces fracture risk in patients with osteoporosis.

choices.text: Inform the doctor and prepare for immediate cesarean section
Gently attempt to reposition the cord back into the vaginal canal
Place the patient in the Trendelenburg or knee-chest position
Perform a detailed vaginal examination to confirm the fetal presentation

questions.text: While attending to a woman in active labor, a midwife identifies a prolapsed umbilical cord during a vaginal examination. What is the next immediate step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Place the patient in the Trendelenburg or knee-chest position

 

Cord prolapse occurs when the umbilical cord slips ahead of the presenting fetal part and into the vaginal canal, leading to compression of the cord and potential fetal hypoxia. 

 

The immediate priority is to relieve pressure on the umbilical cord to prevent compromised blood flow to the fetus.

 

  • Placing the patient in Trendelenburg (head down) or knee-chest position uses gravity to shift the fetus away from the cord, reducing compression.
  • This is followed by manual elevation of the presenting part if necessary and preparation for an emergency cesarean section, which is the definitive treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inform the doctor and prepare for immediate cesarean section: Although preparing for an emergency cesarean section is critical, the immediate action is to relieve pressure on the umbilical cord to preserve fetal oxygenation before transport to the operating room.

 

Option B. Gently attempt to reposition the cord back into the vaginal canal: Reinserting the cord is contraindicated because it can cause trauma and worsen cord compression.

 

Option D. Perform a detailed vaginal examination to confirm fetal presentation: Performing a detailed examination at this stage delays critical intervention. The presentation can be assessed after stabilizing the fetal condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In cord prolapse, the immediate management step is to relieve pressure on the umbilical cord by placing the patient in Trendelenburg or knee-chest position to prevent fetal hypoxia and prepare for emergency cesarean section.

choices.text: Plasma von Willebrand factor antigen and activity

questions.text: Ms. Sreeja, 22-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with heavy vaginal bleeding that has persisted for 5 days. She has a history of heavy menstrual periods and has required frequent pad changes every 1–2 hours. She recently recovered from an upper respiratory tract infection. Her medications include ibuprofen for headaches and iron supplementation for iron deficiency anemia. Her mother also has a history of heavy menstrual periods and frequent nosebleeds. Vital signs are stable, and bimanual examination reveals no palpable abnormalities. Laboratory results show hemoglobin of 9.0 g/dL, mean corpuscular volume (MCV) of 76 fL, platelet count of 210,000/mm³, INR of 0.8, and activated PTT of 23 seconds. Which of the following is the best next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Plasma von Willebrand factor antigen and activity

 

  • This patient’s history of heavy menstrual bleeding (menorrhagia), a maternal history of heavy bleeding, and a recent infection suggest von Willebrand disease (vWD) as the likely underlying cause. 
  • vWD is the most common inherited bleeding disorder, characterized by impaired platelet adhesion due to a deficiency or dysfunction of von Willebrand factor (vWF). 
  • Testing for plasma vWF antigen and activity is the next step to confirm the diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fibrinogen levels: Low fibrinogen levels are seen in disseminated intravascular coagulation or inherited fibrinogen deficiencies, which typically present with generalized bleeding or thrombotic complications. This patient’s clinical and lab finding do not suggest fibrinogen deficiency.

 

Option C. Mixing study: A mixing study is used to differentiate between factor deficiencies and inhibitors in patients with prolonged PTT, which is not present in this patient.

 

Option D. No further testing: Given the history of significant bleeding and a family history suggestive of a bleeding disorder, further testing is warranted to identify the underlying cause and guide treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Von Willebrand disease should be suspected in patients with a history of heavy menstrual bleeding, a family history of bleeding disorders, and normal coagulation studies. 
  • Diagnosis involves measuring plasma vWF antigen, activity, and factor VIII levels.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man presents to the clinic with complaints of dark-colored urine, fatigue, and jaundice. He has a history of cirrhosis secondary to chronic liver disease. His urine sample is amber-colored, and urinalysis shows the presence of casts as indicated in the image. Which type of cast is most likely identified in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bile casts

 

  • Bile casts are characteristic of severe liver dysfunction such as cirrhosis, hepatitis, or cholestatic conditions. 
  • The casts result from an accumulation of bilirubin and bile pigments in the renal tubules. 
  • The brownish-yellow pigmentation seen in the image strongly suggests the presence of bile within the cast.

 

Key Features:

 

  • Color: Golden-brown appearance.
  • Associated Conditions: Cholestasis, advanced cirrhosis, and liver dysfunction.
  • Clinical Presentation: Dark urine, jaundice, pruritus, and fatigue.
  • Urinalysis Findings: Positive bilirubin and urobilinogen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lipid casts: These appear as maltese crosses under polarized light due to refracted lipid. Lipid casts are typically seen in conditions such as nephrotic syndrome where there is significant proteinuria.

 

Option B. Cholesterol casts: Cholesterol casts, though rare, are generally associated with chronic glomerulonephritis or renal infarcts and may appear as crystals rather than pigmented tubular casts.

 

Option D. Hyaline casts: Hyaline casts are non-specific and can be seen in healthy individuals, particularly after dehydration or exercise. They are clear and do not have any pigment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Bile casts are strongly associated with liver dysfunction, particularly in conditions such as cirrhosis, hepatitis, and cholestatic jaundice. 
  • These casts indicate the presence of conjugated bilirubin in the urine and often correlate with impaired bilirubin excretion due to liver damage.

choices.text: Establishing domiciliary care services for bedridden elderly patients
Setting up geriatric clinics at PHCs for weekly follow-ups
Establishing super-specialty geriatric departments at medical colleges
Deploying mobile healthcare units for remote elderly populations

questions.text: A public health officer is planning the expansion of geriatric services in a district under the Rashtriya Varishth Jan Swasthya Yojana. Which of the following interventions would be most appropriate for implementation under this scheme?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Establishing super-specialty geriatric departments at medical colleges

 

  • This program emphasizes tertiary-level care by establishing super-specialty geriatric departments at medical colleges to serve as centers of excellence for elderly care, training, and referrals.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Establishing domiciliary care services for bedridden elderly patients: This is more relevant for community-level programs.

 

Option B. Setting up geriatric clinics at PHCs for weekly follow-ups: This is a feature of primary care programs and not specific to this scheme.

 

Option D. Deploying mobile healthcare units for remote elderly populations: While beneficial for rural elderly, this is outside the scope of this program.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Rashtriya Varishth Jan Swasthya Yojana aims to enhance geriatric care through specialized departments at tertiary centers for better training, research, and referrals.

choices.text: Storing vegetables in a freezer immediately after harvesting
Steaming vegetables instead of dehydrating them
Dehydrating vegetables under direct sunlight to minimize moisture
Using vacuum-sealed canning methods for preservation

questions.text: A nutritionist is preparing guidelines for food processing to preserve beta-carotene levels. Which of the following strategies would be least effective in preserving beta-carotene in vegetables?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dehydrating vegetables under direct sunlight to minimize moisture

 

  • Dehydrating vegetables, especially under direct sunlight, exposes beta-carotene to oxidative stress and UV light, which significantly degrade the compound. 
  • Freezing, steaming, and vacuum-sealed canning preserve beta-carotene by limiting oxygen and heat exposure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Storing vegetables in a freezer immediately after harvesting: This is highly effective in preserving beta-carotene.

 

Option B. Steaming vegetables instead of dehydrating them: Gentle cooking methods like steaming preserve beta-carotene better than dehydration.

 

Option D. Using vacuum-sealed canning methods for preservation: Limits oxygen exposure, effectively preserving beta-carotene levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dehydration, especially under direct sunlight, significantly reduces beta-carotene levels due to oxidation, whereas freezing, steaming, and vacuum-sealing are effective preservation strategies.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is not transmitted by the vector shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pneumonic plague

 

The vector shown in the image is a flea (Xenopsylla cheopis), which plays a key role in the transmission of several zoonotic diseases. Pneumonic plague, although caused by Yersinia pestis (the same organism responsible for bubonic plague), is not transmitted by fleas. Instead, pneumonic plague is transmitted through respiratory droplets from person to person, making it distinct from flea-borne diseases. The hallmark of pneumonic plague is rapid progression to severe pneumonia, which is highly contagious but unrelated to flea exposure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Murine typhus: Caused by Rickettsia typhi, this disease is transmitted by fleas, particularly Xenopsylla cheopis. Fleas acquire the bacteria from infected rodents and transmit it to humans through bites, leading to fever, headache, and rash.

 

Option C. Bubonic plague: Caused by Yersinia pestis, this form of plague is transmitted by flea bites. The bacteria multiply in regional lymph nodes, resulting in painful, swollen lymphadenopathy called buboes. Fleas acquire the organism from infected rodents and spread it to humans.

 

Option D. Hymenolepiasis: This parasitic infection is caused by the tapeworm Hymenolepis nana. Fleas act as intermediate hosts, and humans can acquire the infection by ingesting infected fleas, particularly in areas with poor hygiene. Symptoms include abdominal pain, diarrhea, and weight loss.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The flea (Xenopsylla cheopis) is a vector for diseases such as murine typhus, bubonic plague, and hymenolepiasis. Pneumonic plague, however, is transmitted via respiratory droplets and not by fleas.

questions.text: A middle-aged patient presented in OPD with complaints of pain in wrist around radial styloid with difficulty in performing activities of daily living. Clinical test demonstrated below is to diagnose which condition:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) De Quervain’s Tenosynovitis

 

  • De Quervain’s tenosynovitis is an inflammation of the tendons located at the base of the thumb, specifically the abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis. 
  • These tendons pass through a narrow tendon sheath at the wrist near the radial styloid.
  • Pain and tenderness around the radial styloid (base of the thumb and wrist).
  • Swelling near the affected tendons.
  • Pain that worsens with activities like gripping, pinching, or turning the wrist.
  • Positive Finkelstein's test: This involves flexing the thumb and ulnarly deviating the wrist, which causes pain in the area of the radial styloid.
  • The patient's complaint of pain around the radial styloid and difficulty with daily activities (which often involve gripping) matches the symptoms of De Quervain's tenosynovitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trigger Thumb:

 

  • Trigger thumb (also known as stenosing tenosynovitis) occurs when the flexor tendons in the thumb become irritated and inflamed. This leads to a narrowing of the tendon sheath and causes the thumb to get stuck in a bent position before it "snaps" straight.
  • Pain at the base of the thumb.
  • Difficulty moving the thumb, with a "popping" or "clicking" sensation.
  • Swelling near the thumb joint.
  • The patient's complaint is of pain around the wrist, specifically at the radial styloid, not the thumb.
  • Trigger thumb mainly affects the thumb and does not cause localized pain over the wrist near the radial styloid.

 

Option C. Carpal Tunnel Syndrome:

 

  • Carpal Tunnel Syndrome (CTS) occurs when the median nerve is compressed as it passes through the carpal tunnel at the wrist. The carpal tunnel is a narrow passageway formed by bones and ligaments in the wrist.
  • Numbness, tingling, or pain in the thumb, index, middle, and part of the ring fingers.
  • Weakness in the hand, especially in the muscles that control the thumb.
  • Symptoms are often worse at night.
  • The patient’s pain is described as being around the radial styloid, which is not typically the area affected in carpal tunnel syndrome.
  • CTS affects the median nerve, causing sensory disturbances in the fingers rather than pain in the wrist near the radial styloid.

 

Option D. Lateral Epicondylitis (Tennis Elbow):

 

  • Lateral epicondylitis (commonly known as tennis elbow) is an overuse injury affecting the tendons that attach to the lateral epicondyle of the humerus (outside of the elbow). It occurs due to repetitive motion or stress on the forearm muscles that extend the wrist.
  • Pain and tenderness on the outer part of the elbow.
  • Pain radiating down the forearm.
  • Worsened by gripping, lifting, or repetitive wrist extension.
  • This condition affects the elbow and forearm, not the wrist. The pain typically radiates from the elbow, not the radial side of the wrist.
  • There is no indication of elbow pain or issues in this patient's presentation.

 

Educational Objective:
