  • The clinical symptoms (pain around the radial styloid and difficulty performing daily activities) are most consistent with De Quervain's Tenosynovitis. 
  • This condition involves inflammation of the tendons at the base of the thumb, near the radial styloid, and is characterized by pain exacerbated by movements such as gripping or turning the wrist.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents with fever, hepatomegaly, and a history of contact with stray dogs. Blood sample reveals eosinophilia. An ophthalmologic exam shows a granuloma in the retina. Which of the following best describes the parasitic classification of the causative agent?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aberrant parasite

 

  • Toxocara canis is a dog roundworm that infects humans as an aberrant host. The aberrant  parasite cannot complete its life cycle in humans but can cause visceral larva migrans (involving organs like the liver) or ocular larva migrans (retinal granuloma).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Obligate parasite: Obligate parasites, like Plasmodium spp., require a specific host for survival and reproduction, which is not the case for Toxocara canis in humans.

 

Option B. Facultative parasite: Facultative parasites, like Naegleria fowleri, can exist as free-living organisms.

 

Option D. Accidental parasite: Accidental parasites invade atypical hosts but may still complete part of their lifecycle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Aberrant parasites, like Toxocara canis in humans, infect a host where they cannot complete their development, causing significant tissue damage.

questions.text: Which embryological structure gives rise to the inferior parathyroid glands?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 3rd branchial pouch

 

  • The inferior parathyroid glands develop from the 3rd branchial (pharyngeal) pouch.
  • The same pouch also gives rise to the thymus. During development, the thymus and inferior parathyroid glands migrate downward into the thorax.
  • Because of this extensive migration, the inferior parathyroid glands can sometimes be ectopically located.
  • Conversely, the superior parathyroid glands arise from the 4th branchial pouch and migrate a shorter distance, which is why they remain superior to the inferior parathyroid glands despite developing later.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. 3rd branchial arch: The branchial arches contribute to muscular and skeletal structures, not endocrine glands.

 

Option B. 4th branchial arch: Similar to the 3rd branchial arch, this contributes to structures like the pharyngeal muscles and cartilage, not the parathyroid glands.

 

Option C. 4th branchial pouch: The superior parathyroid glands develop from the 4th branchial pouch, not the inferior parathyroid glands.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The inferior parathyroid glands arise from the 3rd branchial (pharyngeal) pouch, along with the thymus. 
  • The superior parathyroid glands arise from the 4th branchial pouch. 
  • This developmental relationship explains why congenital syndromes affecting branchial pouches, such as DiGeorge syndrome, can result in combined thymic and parathyroid abnormalities.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presents with a history of jaundice that fluctuates over time. His jaundice intermittently worsens and then improves, without significant changes in his symptoms otherwise. He has no history of recent infections but reports occasional mild abdominal discomfort. What is the most likely cause of this waxing and waning jaundice?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Periampullary carcinoma

 

  • Periampullary carcinoma includes cancers of the head of the pancreas, distal common bile duct (CBD), and ampullary carcinoma. 
  • These tumors can cause obstruction of the bile ducts, leading to obstructive jaundice. 
  • The waxing and waning nature of the jaundice is due to central tumor necrosis and sloughing or the intermittent opening of a minimally obstructed duct, which temporarily relieves the obstruction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CBD stones: Obstructive jaundice due to CBD stones can indeed be intermittent in nature, but it is typically associated with biliary colic, which presents with sharp, localized pain. However, waxing and waning jaundice without pain is more characteristic of periampullary carcinoma than CBD stones.

 

Option B. Bile duct stricture after cholecystectomy: Bile duct strictures, particularly after cholecystectomy, can cause persistent obstructive jaundice but do not typically present with the waxing and waning nature seen in periampullary carcinoma.

 

Option C. Parasites obstruction: Parasite infestations like Ascaris can cause biliary obstruction and intermittent jaundice due to mechanical blockage, but the clinical picture is not typically one of waxing and waning jaundice as seen with periampullary carcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Waxing and waning jaundice is characteristic of periampullary carcinoma, where intermittent relief of bile duct obstruction occurs due to tumor necrosis or temporary duct opening.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male with decompensated congestive heart failure (CHF) and persistent hyponatremia is being treated with a vasopressin receptor antagonist. He was initially started on a medication that is administered orally, but his serum sodium levels have failed to improve significantly. The decision is made to switch him to an intravenous vasopressin receptor antagonist that acts on both V2 and V1a receptors. Which of the following is the most appropriate medication for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Conivaptan

 

  • Conivaptan is an intravenous vasopressin receptor antagonist that blocks both V2 and V1a receptors.
  • It is often used in the management of hyponatremia, particularly when oral medications like tolvaptan are ineffective or not feasible. 
  • Conivaptan's dual receptor blockade makes it effective in managing water retention and restoring normal sodium levels in hyponatremia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tolvaptan: An oral vasopressin receptor antagonist that selectively blocks V2 receptors. It is less effective than conivaptan in cases requiring rapid correction.

 

Option C. Desmopressin: A vasopressin agonist, not an antagonist, used for conditions like diabetes insipidus.

 

Option D. Lixivaptan: Not available for clinical use and lacks intravenous formulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Conivaptan is an intravenous vasopressin receptor antagonist with dual action on V2 and V1a receptors, making it useful in the management of severe hyponatremia.

questions.text: A 45-year-old gardener presents to the clinic with a 2-week history of painless nodular lesions on his left forearm. He recalls pricking his hand on a thorn while trimming rose bushes 3 weeks ago. The lesions began as a small papule on his hand and have since spread proximally along the forearm in a linear pattern. He denies fever, chills, or systemic symptoms. The image of the lesion is shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Itraconazole

 

  • The patient’s history of gardening, traumatic inoculation, and the presence of painless nodular lesions following a lymphatic distribution is characteristic of sporotrichosis, caused by Sporothrix schenckii. 
  • Itraconazole, an oral antifungal, is the treatment of choice for cutaneous and lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Doxycycline: Doxycycline is effective against bacterial infections and some rickettsial diseases but is not effective for fungal infections like sporotrichosis.

 

Option C. Amphotericin B: Amphotericin B is reserved for severe systemic fungal infections, such as disseminated sporotrichosis, but is not necessary for localized lymphocutaneous cases.

 

Option D. Flucloxacillin: Flucloxacillin is an antibiotic used to treat bacterial infections like cellulitis or abscesses caused by Staphylococcus aureus. It is not effective against fungal infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sporotrichosis is a subcutaneous fungal infection often associated with traumatic inoculation during gardening. 
  • The typical presentation includes nodular lesions spreading along lymphatics, and itraconazole is the first-line treatment for lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a side effect of succinylcholine?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Respiratory depression

 

  • Respiratory depression is not a direct side effect of succinylcholine. 
  • While succinylcholine causes muscle relaxation and paralysis, the primary side effects are related to cardiovascular, metabolic, and pressure-related changes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyperkalemia: Succinylcholine causes potassium release from cells, leading to hyperkalemia, which can be life-threatening in certain patients, such as those with burns, crush injuries, or neuromuscular disorders.

 

Option B. Increased intracranial pressure: Succinylcholine may transiently increase intracranial pressure due to its activation of the electroencephalogram (EEG) and effects on cerebral blood flow.

 

Option C. Sinus bradycardia: Succinylcholine can cause bradycardia, particularly in children or when repeated doses are administered, due to stimulation of muscarinic receptors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Succinylcholine has significant cardiovascular, metabolic, and pressure-related side effects, such as hyperkalemia, increased intracranial pressure, and sinus bradycardia. 
  • Respiratory depression is not a direct side effect, as the drug primarily acts as a depolarizing neuromuscular blocker.

choices.text: Dermoid cysts attached to the hyoid bone

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with a soft, non-tender swelling in the neck. On clinical examination, the swelling is noted to be non-movable during swallowing. Which of the following swellings does not move with deglutition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cystic hygroma

 

  • Cystic hygroma is a congenital malformation of the lymphatic system, usually presenting as a painless, soft, and compressible swelling that most commonly occurs in the neck.
  • It does not move with deglutition because it is not attached to the trachea or hyoid bone.
  • Unlike thyroid-associated swellings, which move with swallowing due to their attachment to the trachea and pretracheal fascia, cystic hygromas remain stationary during deglutition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thyroglossal Cyst: Thyroglossal cysts are attached to the hyoid bone and move with deglutition and tongue protrusion. They are remnants of the thyroglossal duct and are typically located in the midline of the neck.

 

Option B. Sub hyoid bursitis: Sub hyoid bursitis is an inflammation of the bursa beneath the hyoid bone. Since this structure is attached to the hyoid, it moves with deglutition.

 

Option D. Dermoid cysts attached to hyoid bone: Dermoid cysts that are attached to the hyoid bone move with deglutition due to the movement of the hyoid during swallowing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cystic hygroma is a congenital lymphatic malformation that does not move with deglutition, unlike thyroid-related swellings.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presents to the emergency department with palpitations and shortness of breath for the past 24 hours. His medical history includes hypertension, hyperlipidemia, type 2 diabetes mellitus, obstructive sleep apnea, and emphysema. He uses oxygen at night and a daily inhaler for his lung disease. On examination, his blood pressure is 132/54 mm Hg, pulse is 155/min, and faint end-expiratory wheezing is noted bilaterally. ECG is taken and shown below. Transthoracic echocardiogram shows left atrial dilation, normal left ventricular systolic function, and an estimated pulmonary artery systolic pressure of 50 mm Hg. Given the likely diagnosis, what is the most definitive treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Radiofrequency ablation

 

  • Radiofrequency ablation is the definitive treatment for atrial flutter, especially in patients with recurrent or persistent arrhythmias that are refractory to medical therapy. 
  • It targets the re-entrant circuit within the atrium, offering a high success rate in restoring normal sinus rhythm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adenosine: Adenosine is effective for terminating supraventricular tachycardia (e.g., AVNRT or AVRT) but has no effect on atrial flutter, as it does not interrupt the re-entrant circuit in the atria.

 

Option B. Digoxin: While digoxin can control ventricular rate in atrial fibrillation, it is less effective in atrial flutter due to its inability to reliably control the rapid conduction of flutter waves to the ventricles.

 

Option C. Flecainide: Flecainide is a rhythm-control drug used in atrial fibrillation/flutter, but it is not the best option for long-term management in this case. It is also contraindicated in patients with structural heart disease or significant atrial enlargement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Radiofrequency ablation is the treatment of choice for atrial flutter, offering a curative approach by interrupting the re-entrant circuit, particularly in patients who fail or cannot tolerate medical therapy.

questions.text:
Which of the following muscles contribute to the structure of the pelvic diaphragm, which provides support to the pelvic organs and aids in continence control? 

 

  1. Iliococcygeus
  2. Pubococcygeus
  3. Obturator internus
  4. Deep transverse perinei
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2

 

  • The pelvic diaphragm is composed of the levator ani muscles and the coccygeus muscle. The levator ani consists of the following components:
  1. Iliococcygeus
  2. Pubococcygeus (which includes the puborectalis)
  3. Coccygeus
  • These muscles form a supportive sling that maintains the position of the pelvic organs and controls intra-abdominal pressure during defecation, urination, and childbirth.

 

 

Other Options:

 

3. The obturator internus forms part of the lateral pelvic wall, not the pelvic diaphragm.

 

4. The deep transverse perinei muscle belongs to the urogenital diaphragm, not the pelvic diaphragm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The pelvic diaphragm is formed by the levator ani (pubococcygeus and iliococcygeus) and the coccygeus muscle. 
  • These muscles provide structural support to the pelvic organs and play a crucial role in maintaining continence and facilitating childbirth.

choices.text: Long-term steroid use causes adrenal hyperplasia, necessitating a higher dose for surgical stress.
Surgical stress requires additional exogenous glucocorticoids due to impaired endogenous cortisol production.
Prednisolone is less effective under general anesthesia, and higher doses are required.
Perioperative glucocorticoid doses prevent irreversible adrenal gland damage.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man undergoing surgery for a hip fracture has been on long-term corticosteroid therapy (15 mg prednisolone daily) for severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). He has been instructed to increase his glucocorticoid dose preoperatively. What is the rationale behind this adjustment?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Surgical stress requires additional exogenous glucocorticoids due to impaired endogenous cortisol production.

 

  • Patients on long-term corticosteroids often have suppressed HPA axis function and cannot mount an adequate endogenous cortisol response to surgical stress. 
  • To mimic the normal stress-induced cortisol surge, perioperative glucocorticoid doses are increased to prevent hemodynamic instability and adrenal crisis.
  • This adjustment ensures adequate cortisol levels during times of increased physiologic demand.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Long-term steroid use causes adrenal hyperplasia, necessitating a higher dose for surgical stress: Chronic corticosteroid use causes adrenal atrophy, not hyperplasia.

 

Option C. Prednisolone is less effective under general anesthesia, and higher doses are required: Prednisolone’s effectiveness is not influenced by anesthesia. The dose adjustment is due to suppressed adrenal function, not anesthetic effects.

 

Option D. Perioperative glucocorticoid doses prevent irreversible adrenal gland damage: The purpose of dose adjustment is to prevent adrenal crisis, not to prevent glandular damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Long-term corticosteroid use suppresses the HPA axis, impairing the stress response.
  • Perioperative glucocorticoid supplementation prevents adrenal crisis in patients undergoing surgery.

questions.text: Which skeletal muscle fibers are classified as Fast Oxidative-Glycolytic (FOG) fibers, known for their balance between speed and endurance?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Type IIA

 

  • Type IIA muscle fibers are fast oxidative-glycolytic (FOG) fibers. They possess both aerobic and anaerobic metabolic properties, making them efficient at producing ATP through both oxidative phosphorylation and glycolysis. 
  • These fibers are intermediate in terms of contraction speed and fatigue resistance, providing a balance between strength and endurance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type I: These are slow-twitch oxidative fibers, highly fatigue-resistant, with a focus on endurance rather than speed. They primarily use aerobic metabolism.

 

Option C. Type IIB: These are fast glycolytic fibers, specialized for short bursts of power and speed but fatigue quickly due to reliance on anaerobic metabolism.

 

Option D. Type IIC: These fibers are transitional fibers that appear during muscle regeneration and are not a standard classification for mature muscle fibers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Type IIA fibers (fast oxidative-glycolytic) are characterized by a balance between contraction speed and endurance, using both aerobic and anaerobic metabolic pathways.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with intermittent episodes of abdominal discomfort and altered bowel habits. The physician orders a contrast imaging study to evaluate the small bowel for any structural abnormalities or delayed transit. The following radiograph is obtained. What is the most appropriate name of the imaging study shown in the radiograph?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Barium meal follow-through

 

  • A barium meal follow-through is a fluoroscopic examination used to visualize the small intestine after the patient swallows a barium contrast solution. 
  • In this study, after initial imaging of the stomach and proximal duodenum (barium meal), serial radiographs are taken to track the movement of barium through the small intestine. 
  • The provided radiograph shows barium contrast outlining the loops of the small bowel with characteristic folds (valvulae conniventes), confirming it is a follow-through study of the small intestine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Barium enema: A barium enema is a radiographic study of the colon and rectum, where barium contrast is introduced via the rectum. The barium coats the colon, and air is often insufflated to provide a double contrast. The small bowel is not visualized in a barium enema.

 

Option B. Barium swallow: A barium swallow focuses on the esophagus, where the patient swallows a barium solution to visualize the esophageal lumen and detect any structural abnormalities such as strictures, diverticula, or masses. This study does not typically involve imaging the small intestine.

 

Option C. Barium meal: A barium meal is used to evaluate the stomach and proximal duodenum after ingestion of barium contrast. However, this study focuses on the upper gastrointestinal tract and does not involve follow-through images to examine the entire small intestine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A barium meal follow-through is a specialized fluoroscopic study that tracks barium contrast from the stomach through the small intestine to assess small bowel pathology. 
  • The small intestine is visualized by serial radiographs, showing characteristic mucosal folds (valvulae conniventes).

choices.text: Reduced permeability of the bacterial membrane to antibiotics
Lack of a peptidoglycan-containing cell wall
Efflux pumps that actively expel antibiotics

questions.text: A 21-year-old college student presents with a 2-week history of low-grade fever, fatigue, and a non-productive cough. A chest X-ray shows diffuse peribronchial infiltrates with thickened bronchial markings, but no lobar consolidation. The patient reports no significant improvement with amoxicillin started by his primary care physician a week ago. Which of the following best explains why this organism is resistant to beta-lactam antibiotics?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lack of a peptidoglycan-containing cell wall

 

  • Mycoplasma pneumoniae is a cell wall-deficient organism, which makes it inherently resistant to beta-lactam antibiotics like amoxicillin. 
  • Beta-lactams target the bacterial cell wall synthesis by inhibiting penicillin-binding proteins (PBPs), but since Mycoplasma lacks a cell wall and peptidoglycan, these antibiotics are ineffective.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Production of beta-lactamase: This mechanism is seen in some gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria, but Mycoplasma pneumoniae does not produce beta-lactamase as it does not have a cell wall.

 

Option B. Reduced permeability of the bacterial membrane to antibiotics: While some bacteria have outer membranes that limit drug penetration, Mycoplasma pneumoniae lacks such a membrane and does not rely on this mechanism.

 

Option D. Efflux pumps that actively expel antibiotics: Efflux pumps can confer resistance in some bacteria, but this is not the primary mechanism of resistance in Mycoplasma pneumoniae.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Mycoplasma pneumoniae is resistant to beta-lactam antibiotics due to its lack of a peptidoglycan-containing cell wall. 
  • This unique feature necessitates the use of antibiotics that target other bacterial components, such as macrolides or tetracyclines.

questions.text: A pathologist reviewing a case of suspected ectopic pregnancy finds histological evidence of ovarian tissue in the sac wall, intact fallopian tubes, and attachment to the uterus by the ovarian ligament. Which criteria are used to diagnose this type of ectopic pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Spiegelberg criteria

 

  • Spiegelberg criteria are the diagnostic criteria used to confirm ovarian ectopic pregnancy. 

 

These include:

 

  1. The gestational sac must be located in the ovary.
  2. The fallopian tube must be intact and separate from the ovary.
  3. Ovarian tissue must be histologically identified in the wall of the sac.
  4. The gestational sac must be attached to the uterus by the ovarian ligament.

 

These criteria help differentiate ovarian pregnancy from tubal and abdominal ectopic pregnancies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ring of fire: A term describing the hype vascular appearance around an ectopic pregnancy on Doppler ultrasound. However, this finding is non-specific and can be seen in any type of ectopic pregnancy.

 

Option B. Rubin criteria: Used to assess tubal patency during hysterosalpingography by observing the movement of contrast through the fallopian tubes.

 

Option D. Studdiford criteria: Used to diagnose primary abdominal pregnancies.  

 

The criteria include:

 

  • Normal fallopian tubes and ovaries with no evidence of fistula.
  • Evidence of pregnancy related exclusively to the peritoneal cavity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Spiegelberg criteria are used to diagnose ovarian ectopic pregnancy and include confirmation of a gestational sac in the ovary, intact fallopian tubes, ovarian tissue in the sac wall, and attachment to the uterus by the ovarian ligament.

choices.text: From conception to 20 weeks of gestation
From 28 weeks of gestation to 28 days after birth
From 22 weeks of gestation to 7 days after birth

questions.text: What is the perinatal period as defined in obstetrics and neonatology?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) From 22 weeks of gestation to 7 days after birth

 

  • The perinatal period is defined as the time starting from 22 completed weeks of gestation (154 days) and ends 7 days after birth. 
  • This period is significant as it includes critical times for both maternal and fetal health and is used in assessing perinatal mortality rates, which include stillbirths and early neonatal deaths.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. From conception to 20 weeks of gestation: This period includes embryonic and early fetal development, but it is not categorized as the perinatal period.

 

Option B. From 28 weeks of gestation to 28 days after birth: This is the definition for the late fetal and neonatal periods, not the perinatal period.

 

Option D. From birth to 7 days postpartum: This is only part of the perinatal period and does not account for the gestational weeks preceding birth.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The perinatal period is defined as the time from 22 weeks of gestation to 7 days after birth and is a critical measure in evaluating fetal and neonatal outcomes.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman with diabetic neuropathy pain is started on pregabalin. Which of the following conditions is also an FDA-approved indication for pregabalin?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Spinal cord injury pain

 

  • Pregabalin is FDA-approved for several conditions, including focal seizures, post-herpetic neuralgia, diabetic neuropathy pain, spinal cord injury pain, and fibromyalgia.
  • It works similarly to gabapentin by inhibiting presynaptic calcium channel currents.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Generalized anxiety disorder: Pregabalin has been used off-label for generalized anxiety disorder in some regions but is not an FDA-approved indication.

 

Option C. Cluster headache prophylaxis: Pregabalin is not used for headache prophylaxis.

 

Option D. Tension headache: Pregabalin is not indicated for treating tension headaches.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pregabalin is approved for treating neuropathic pain conditions, including diabetic neuropathy, post-herpetic neuralgia, and spinal cord injury pain, in addition to fibromyalgia.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with hoarseness of voice following thyroid surgery. Laryngoscopic examination shows impaired vocal cord function. Which of the following muscles is responsible for tensing these vocal cords?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cricothyroid

 

  • The cricothyroid muscle is the primary tensor of the vocal cords. It acts by tilting the thyroid cartilage forward, which increases the tension on the vocal cords and raises the pitch of the voice. 
  • This muscle is innervated by the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (a branch of the vagus nerve). 
  • Injury to this nerve, often during thyroid surgery, can lead to the inability to tense the vocal cords and result in a monotone or hoarse voice.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Posterior cricoarytenoid: This muscle is the only abductor of the vocal cords, meaning it opens the glottis by pulling the vocal cords apart. It is not involved in tensing the vocal cords.

 

Option C. Thyroarytenoid: This muscle acts as a relaxer of the vocal cords by pulling the arytenoid cartilage closer to the thyroid cartilage, thus shortening and relaxing the vocal cords.

 

Option D. Lateral cricoarytenoid: This muscle acts as an adductor of the vocal cords, closing the glottis by pulling the vocal processes of the arytenoid cartilage together.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The cricothyroid muscle is the primary tensor of the vocal cords and increases their tension by tilting the thyroid cartilage forward.
  • It is innervated by the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a 3-month history of persistent cough, low-grade fevers, night sweats, and hemoptysis. She reports unintentional weight loss. Chest X-ray reveals a cavitary lesion in the upper lobe of the right lung. A biopsy of the lesion shows caseous necrosis surrounded by epithelioid macrophages and multinucleated giant cells. Which of the following mechanisms best explains the tissue damage in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Type IV hypersensitivity reaction

 

  • The histopathological finding of caseous necrosis is a hallmark feature of granulomatous inflammation seen in tuberculosis. 
  • The primary mechanism involves a type IV hypersensitivity reaction mediated by T-helper (Th1) cells, which recruit macrophages to form granulomas. 
  • In tuberculosis, activated macrophages release reactive oxygen species (ROS) and lysosomal enzymes that cause caseation (cheese-like necrosis).
  • The granuloma serves to "wall off" the infection, but excessive immune activation leads to tissue destruction and cavitation in the lungs.

 

Key components of type IV hypersensitivity reaction:

 

  • Cytokines: IL-2, IFN-γ, and TNF-α.
  • Cells involved: CD4+ T-cells, macrophages, and multinucleated giant cells.
  • Outcome: Tissue damage from chronic inflammation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Enzyme degradation: While enzymes released by macrophages contribute to tissue damage, this is a downstream effect of the immune activation in a type IV hypersensitivity reaction, rather than the primary mechanism.

 

Option B. Sudden vascular occlusion: Sudden cut-off of blood supply leads to coagulative necrosis, typically seen in infarctions (e.g., myocardial infarction or ischemic stroke), not in granulomatous diseases.

 

Option D. Fibrinoid necrosis: Fibrinoid necrosis involves deposition of fibrin-like material in vessel walls, often seen in vasculitis or immune complex-mediated diseases (e.g., polyarteritis nodosa). It is not related to tuberculosis or cavitary lung lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Type IV hypersensitivity reactions, mediated by CD4+ T-cells and macrophages, are the underlying mechanism for granuloma formation and tissue destruction in tuberculosis. 
  • Caseous necrosis is a distinctive finding due to the interaction of activated macrophages releasing ROS and proteolytic enzymes.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset weakness on the right side of his body and difficulty speaking, which began one hour ago while he was at work. He has a history of secondary progressive multiple sclerosis diagnosed 30 years ago with multiple exacerbations, as well as hypertension and hyperlipidemia. On examination, he has weakness of the right lower face, right arm, and mild weakness of the right leg. His speech is limited to 1–2 words with great effort. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for the patient’s current presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Middle cerebral artery stroke

 

  • The patient’s presentation of sudden-onset right-sided weakness (face, arm, and leg) and expressive aphasia strongly suggests a left middle cerebral artery (MCA) stroke. 
  • The MCA supplies the motor cortex for the contralateral face, arm, and leg, and the dominant hemisphere (usually the left) includes Broca's area, responsible for speech production. 
  • This acute neurological deficit is unlikely related to multiple sclerosis, which typically causes subacute or gradual worsening.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lenticulostriate artery stroke: Lenticulostriate artery strokes typically cause lacunar infarctions that result in pure motor or pure sensory deficits, without the expressive aphasia seen in this patient.

 

Option C. Multiple sclerosis progression: Progression in secondary progressive multiple sclerosis typically occurs over months to years and would not present with the acute onset of focal neurological deficits as seen here.

 

Option D. Multiple sclerosis relapse: Relapses in multiple sclerosis usually evolve over days to weeks, not minutes to hours, and are less likely to produce symptoms such as expressive aphasia, which is more characteristic of a cortical stroke.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sudden-onset focal neurological deficits, including hemiparesis and aphasia, are hallmarks of an ischemic stroke, particularly in the distribution of the middle cerebral artery. 
  • Acute management should include urgent neuroimaging and evaluation for thrombolysis or thrombectomy.

questions.text:
Consider the following statements regarding Schizophrenia and its clinical features: 

 

Statement 1: First-rank symptoms of schizophrenia include auditory hallucinations, thought insertion, and thought withdrawal.
 

Statement 2: Schizophrenia has an earlier onset in males and is associated with a worse prognosis in females.
 

Statement 3: Negative symptoms of schizophrenia include alogia, avolition, and affective flattening.
 

Statement 4: Delusions of grandeur are more common in schizophrenia compared to delusions of persecution.

 

Which of the following is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Statements 1 and 3 are correct.

 

Statement 1: Correct. First-rank symptoms of schizophrenia, as described by Kurt Schneider, include auditory hallucinations (e.g., voices commenting or discussing the patient), thought insertion, and thought withdrawal, among others.

 

Statement 3: Correct. Negative symptoms in schizophrenia include alogia (reduced speech), avolition (lack of motivation), and affective flattening (blunted emotional expression). These symptoms often contribute to functional impairment and are harder to treat.

 

Other Options:

 

Statement 2: Incorrect. Schizophrenia indeed has an earlier onset in males (typically in late adolescence to early 20s) compared to females (mid-20s to early 30s). However, females tend to have a better prognosis than males, attributed to later onset and the protective effects of estrogen.

 

Statement 4: Incorrect. In schizophrenia, delusions of persecution (e.g., belief that others are conspiring to harm the patient) are far more common than delusions of grandeur (e.g., belief in possessing special powers). Delusions of grandeur are more typically associated with manic episodes in bipolar disorder.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Schizophrenia is characterized by positive symptoms (e.g., hallucinations, delusions), negative symptoms (e.g., affective flattening, avolition), and cognitive impairments. First-rank symptoms are pathognomonic but not exclusive to schizophrenia.

choices.text: Hematogenous dissemination of the virus following initial inoculation
Local spread due to mechanical inoculation during scratching
Autoinoculation caused by viral shedding into sebaceous glands
Activation of latent virus in the surrounding skin cells

questions.text: A pediatric dermatologist is evaluating a 6-year-old boy with a history of atopic dermatitis who presents with clusters of umbilicated, flesh-colored papules around the flexor creases of his arms. The dermatologist notes that these lesions seem to spread along the lines of skin trauma. Which of the following mechanisms best explains this pattern of lesion distribution?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Local spread due to mechanical inoculation during scratching 

 

  • The Koebner phenomenon occurs when trauma to the skin, such as scratching, causes local mechanical inoculation of infectious agents.
  •  In this case, scratching due to atopic dermatitis leads to autoinoculation of the molluscum contagiosum virus and lesion development along lines of trauma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hematogenous dissemination of the virus following initial inoculation: Molluscum contagiosum does not spread hematogenously; it spreads locally through direct contact or autoinoculation.

 

Option C. Autoinoculation caused by viral shedding into sebaceous glands: Viral shedding occurs, but molluscum contagiosum is not specifically linked to sebaceous gland involvement.

 

Option D. Activation of latent virus in the surrounding skin cells: Molluscum contagiosum does not establish latency, unlike herpesviruses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Koebner phenomenon, seen in molluscum contagiosum, describes local spread of lesions along lines of trauma due to autoinoculation.

questions.text: A bone marrow biopsy is performed on a patient with pancytopenia to identify pluripotent hematopoietic stem cells. Which of the following markers is most specific for these cells?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) CD34

 

  • CD34 is a surface glycoprotein expressed on pluripotent hematopoietic stem cells (HSCs) and progenitor cells. 
  • It is commonly used in clinical practice for identifying and isolating stem cells, particularly for bone marrow transplants.
  • CD34-positive cells are capable of self-renewal and differentiation into various lineages of blood cells (myeloid and lymphoid).
  • Flow cytometry using CD34 markers is routinely performed to quantify and select these stem cells during stem cell transplantation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CD45: CD45 is a leukocyte common antigen expressed on almost all nucleated hematopoietic cells, including lymphocytes, monocytes, and granulocytes. It is not specific for stem cells and is expressed on more differentiated blood cells.

 

Option B. CD1: CD1 molecules are MHC-like glycoproteins involved in lipid antigen presentation and are mainly associated with dendritic cells and Langerhans cells. They are not expressed on hematopoietic stem cells.

 

Option C. CD79: CD79 is a component of the B-cell receptor complex, expressed on B-lymphocytes. It plays a critical role in B-cell activation but has no role in identifying hematopoietic stem cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • CD34 is a marker for identifying pluripotent hematopoietic stem cells in bone marrow. 
  • It is crucial in stem cell transplantation and flow cytometric analysis of progenitor cells.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male undergoes a splenectomy following a traumatic injury. After surgery, the patient is at risk of several complications. Which of the following is the most common complication following a splenectomy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Left lower lobe atelectasis

 

  • This is the most common complication following splenectomy due to the proximity of the diaphragm and lungs to the surgical site. 
  • Atelectasis results in the collapse of part of the lung but is typically a self-limiting and non-fatal complication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Opportunistic post-splenectomy infection (OPSI): The most fatal complication of splenectomy is Opportunistic Post-Splenectomy Infection (OPSI). OPSI is a life-threatening condition that can result from infections with encapsulated bacteria, such as Streptococcus pneumoniae, Neisseria meningitidis, Haemophilus influenzae, and Escherichia coli. 

 

Option B. Pancreatitis: Pancreatitis can occur as a complication of splenectomy, but it is not as life-threatening as OPSI. It may result from direct trauma or manipulation during surgery but is generally managed with supportive care.

 

Option D. Pleural effusion: Pleural effusion, or fluid accumulation in the pleural space, may occur after surgery but is usually a benign condition. It can cause respiratory symptoms but is typically managed with drainage and is not life-threatening.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Left lower lobe atelectasis is the most common complication following splenectomy due to the proximity of the diaphragm and lungs to the surgical site.

questions.text: A patient with pulmonary arterial hypertension is prescribed a medication that increases the formation of cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP). Which of the following adverse effects is most likely to occur with this medication?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hypotension

 

  • Riociguat, an sGC (soluble guanylate cyclase)  stimulator, leads to vasodilation by increasing cGMP levels in the vascular smooth muscle. 
  • The relaxation of systemic and pulmonary vasculature can result in hypotension, which is a common adverse effect of the drug.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hyperkalemia: This is not associated with riociguat; it is seen with drugs like aldosterone antagonists.

 

Option C. Pulmonary edema: Riociguat is used to treat pulmonary arterial hypertension and does not cause pulmonary edema.

 

Option D. Tachycardia: Although vasodilation can sometimes lead to reflex tachycardia, riociguat typically does not cause this as a primary adverse effect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The use of riociguat in pulmonary arterial hypertension can cause hypotension due to systemic vasodilation.
